section.title: Introduction
section.p: Corporate taxpayers are subject to two taxes on income and capital, namely the corporate income tax (imposto de renda das pessoas jurídicas, IRPJ) (see section 1.10.1.) and the social contribution on net profits (Contribuição Social Sobre o Lucro Líquido, CSLL) (section 2.3.1.), both hereinafter referred to as corporate income taxes CIT.

Although the CSLL is, from a formal perspective, a social contribution, its taxable base and the general principles of its imposition are almost the same as of the IRPJ. In this sense, all income subject to IRPJ is, in general, also subject to the CSLL. For this reason, in practice, the CSLL should be viewed as a type of corporate income tax. Therefore, this chapter jointly discusses, in general, both the IRPJ and the CSLL (referred to as CIT). Nevertheless, some minor specifications of the CSLL are dealt with in section 2.3.1.
In the text, whenever the intention is to solely refer to the corporate income tax, the abbreviation IRPJ is adopted, while the social contribution on net profits is referred to as CSLL.

In addition to the CIT, Brazilian tax laws also impose two social contributions on gross revenue, namely the contribution to the Social Integration Programme (Programa de Integração Social, PIS) and the contribution for the financing of social security (Contribuição para o Financiamento da Seguridade Social, COFINS). Although formally introduced as social contributions, the PIS and COFINS should be considered as actual taxes on income, as they are imposed, in general, on all revenues of the corporate taxpayer. See section 2.3.2. for details on the PIS and section 2.3.3. for COFINS. However, different from the CSLL, such contributions are levied on gross revenue and not on net income and, for this reason, are not considered here as part of the CIT.

On 3 April 2019, the Bill for Amendment of the Constitution 45/2019 (Bill 45/2019) was presented to the Chamber of Deputies of the National Congress. Bill 45/2019 proposes a tax reform to simplify the Brazilian tax system through the unification of taxes and contributions charged on consumption. Under the proposal, the federal tax on manufactured products (imposto sobre produtos industrializados, IPI), PIS, COFINS, the interstate and intermunicipal transportation, and on communication services (imposto sobre circulação de mercadorias e serviços de transporte interestadual e intermunicipal e de comunicação, ICMS) and the municipal tax on services (Imposto sobre Serviços de Qualquer Natureza, ISS) are replaced by the “single tax on goods and services” (Imposto Único sobre Bens e Serviços, IBS) throughout a transitory period of 10 years (a trial period of 2 years in which the COFINS rate will be reduced and IBS charged at 1%; and an implementation period of 8 years in which the IPI, ICMS, ISS, PIS and COFINS rates will be progressively reduced). Bill 45/2019 is still under analysis by the Chamber of Deputies.

In parallel to Bill 45/2019, on 9 July 2019, a second bill (Bill for Amendment of the Constitution 110/2019 (Bill 110/2019)) was presented to the Senate. Bill 110/2019 also proposes a tax reform to simplify the tax system through the unification of taxes and contributions charged on consumption. Under this proposal, IPI, PIS, COFINS, ICMS, ISS, the federal tax on financial transactions (imposto sobre operações financeiras, IOF), the contribution to Intervention on the Economic Domain levied on fuel (contribuição de Intervenção no Domínio Econômico, CIDE-Combustível) and the education contribution (salário educação) are replaced by the state "tax on transactions with goods and services" (imposto sobre operações com bens e serviços, IBS) and by a federal tax on specific goods and services named "selective tax" (imposto seletivo) throughout a transitory period of 15 years.

In addition, Bill 110/2019 proposes (i) that the inheritance and gift tax – currently a state tax – becomes a federal tax collected by the federal government and (ii) to extend the taxable events for tax on automotive vehicles ownership (imposto sobre a propriedade de veículos automotores, IPVA) to cover the ownership of airplanes and vessels (with the exception of those used for commercial fishing, public transport and cargo purposes). Bill 110/2019 is still under analysis by the Senate.

On 21 July 2020, the Minister of Economy presented to the National Congress another proposal for tax reform (Bill 3887/2020), which aims at unifying the PIS and COFINS into one contribution on goods and services (Contribuição sobre Bens e Serviços, CBS). According to the proposal, CBS would be levied at a flat tax rate of 12% (5.8% for financial institutions) on gross revenue from imports and local sales of services and goods. ICMS and ISS paid would be deductible from the CBS taxable base. Digital platforms would be responsible for collecting the CBS due in transactions in which they act as intermediaries and the seller does not issue an invoice according to state and municipal legislation. Non-resident suppliers would be required to register in Brazil and collect the CBS due in cases where the importer is an individual. Nonetheless, the bill does not provide for a penalty for non-residents failing to comply with the obligation to register in Brazil. The proposal is being developed in the framework of an agreement between the Ministry of Economy, the President of the Senate and the President of the Chamber of Deputies to create a mixed commission in charge of preparing a text for a tax reform.

On 25 June 2021, another bill was submitted by the government (Bill 2337/2021) with proposals to, among others, change corporate income tax rates and individual income tax brackets, to extinguish interest on net equity type of payment (and consequently its deduction for tax purposes), and to introduce the taxation of dividends. On 2 September 2021, Bill 2337/2021 was approved (with amendments) by the Chamber of Deputies; it still needs to be voted on and approved by the Senate.
As a result, Bill 45/2019, Bill 110/2019, Bill 3887/2020 and Bill 2337/2021 are currently under consideration by the National Congress.
In addition, specific proposals to tax digital services provided by non-resident companies are also being discussed by the National Congress – see section 14.6.4.5.

On 1 July 2021 and 8 October 2021, Brazil signed joint statements with other Inclusive Framework members with an agreement to implement a two-pillar solution to address the tax challenges arising from the digitalization of the economy (see details in sections 7.3.1., 10.6. and 14.6.4.5.).
On 25 January 2022, the OECD Council decided to open an accession discussion with Brazil towards an OECD membership.

Sections 1. and 2. discuss the taxation of domestic income of resident companies. The taxation of foreign income of resident companies is discussed in section 7.2., and the taxation of non-resident companies in section 7.3.

section.title: Geographical jurisdiction
section.p: Brazilian taxing rights cover its complete territory, which includes 27 federal units. The 27 federal units are grouped in five large geographic regions: the northern region (comprising the states of Acre, Amapá, Amazonas, Pará, Roraima, Rondônia and Tocantins); the north-east region (comprising the states of Alagoas, Bahia, Ceará, Maranhão, Paraíba, Pernambuco, Piauí, Rio Grande do Norte and Sergipe); the central-west region (comprising the states of Goiás, Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso do Sul and the Federal District); the south-east region (comprising the states of Espírito Santo, Minas Gerais, Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo) and the southern region (comprising the states of Paraná, Rio Grande do Sul and Santa Catarina).
In territorial waters, Brazilian jurisdiction includes territories varying from 40 to 160 nautical miles from the main shore, several islands and the archipelagos of Marajó and Fernando de Noronha.

section.title: Statutory framework
section.p: Brazil adopts a constitutional tax system, under which the main provisions governing the taxing rights of the Federal, State and Municipal governments are included in sections 145 to 162 of the Federal Constitution.

As a consequence of the constitutional tax system, most tax claims have constitutional grounds and may be contested at the Federal Supreme Court (Supremo Tribunal Federal, STF). Tax litigation in Brazil is rather common and can last several years.

The National Tax Code (Código Tributário Nacional, CTN) contains further rules on taxation, tax administration, taxpayers, tax obligations, tax responsibility and specific rules on import and export duties, municipal tax on real estate, income tax, federal excise tax, value added taxes, tax on financial transactions, municipal service tax, municipal tax on real estate transfer, special and extraordinary taxes and general levies. Notwithstanding the provisions of the CTN, specific laws are enacted, with the detailed rules of each tax introduced by the competent taxing authority (federal, state or municipal).

Legal hierarchy applies to the Brazilian legal tax system. Therefore, the legislation concerning the CIT is primarily contained in the Federal Constitution and the CTN. In addition, CIT legislation comprises complementary laws, international treaties and conventions, ordinary laws, decrees and other regulations (i.e. normative instructions, administrative rulings, etc.). In any case, under the provisions of the Federal Constitution on the Brazilian tax system, taxes may only be imposed and/or increased only via law (the legality principle), i.e. the administrative rules may not increase or impose taxes but simply regulate the provisions of the law. The Federal Constitution, however, provides for some exceptions to this principle, mainly in connection with taxes that have a hybrid nature (which are used not only for financing the public services, but also for intervening in a specific sector of the economy).

Federal laws are enacted by the Congress. They are identified by a number and the date of issuance. Laws, provisional measures (PM), decrees and certain other official acts are published in the Federal Official Gazette (Diário Oficial da União, DOU).

The President of Brazil may propose tax-related bills of law. Once a federal law is approved by the federal Congress, it is returned to the President for his approval or veto. Laws enter into force 45 days after their publication in the Federal Official Gazette unless otherwise provided therein. However, legal provisions referring to taxes on income and capital are only effective after 90 days from the publication of the relevant law and/or in some cases from the first day of the assessment period following its publication, in situations where such legal provisions:

item.p: introduce or increase taxes;
include new taxable events; or
revoke or reduce exemptions.

section.p: Provisional measure (PM) is issued for urgent and relevant matters by the President of Brazil without the intervention of the legislative power. It is valid for a 60-calendar-day term, which may be extended for 60 days. After this term, the PM loses its effect, unless it is approved and converted into law by the Brazilian Congress. In spite of its urgent nature, PM are commonly used by the executive to introduce new legislation that could, otherwise, follow the ordinary course in the legislative power.

There are several laws dealing with CIT, some of which were even enacted prior to the 1988 Federal Constitution and have since been updated. The scattered provisions are codified from time to time into a consolidated text, via a decree enacted by the executive branch, known as the Income Tax Regulations (Regulamento do Imposto de Renda, RIR). On 16 March 2017, Normative Instruction 1,700/2017 consolidated relevant rules on CIT.
The Income Tax Regulation currently in force is Decree 9,580/2018 (RIR).

section.title: Type of tax system
section.p: Economic double taxation is avoided via a dividend exemption system under which dividends distributed by resident legal entities to either resident or non-resident shareholders (regardless of being legal entities or individuals) out of after-tax profits are not subject to any further taxation (including withholding income tax within the distribution) – for details, see section 6.1. Therefore, corporate taxpayers do not include dividends received from other resident entities in the CIT taxable base. However, dividends distributed by a non-resident legal entity to a resident legal entity are included in the taxable base and, therefore, are subject to CIT (see section 7.2.1.3.).

section.title: Taxable persons
section.p: Taxable persons for CIT purposes are:

item.p: all resident legal entities;
branches, agencies and representative offices of non-resident entities;
unincorporated business units; and
non-resident entities deriving Brazilian-source income (article 744 of the RIR).

section.p: A consortium of companies (consórcios, under article 278 of Law 6,404/1976 – corporate law) is considered to be comprised of entities with legal personality and must comply with the tax obligations that were, before the creation of the consortium, fulfilled by the participating companies. A consortium must therefore be registered as a taxpayer before federal tax authorities, although it is not actually subject to CIT on its individual capacity. Instead, companies participating in the consortium are liable for all taxes due as a result of the activities carried out in proportion to their participation in the consortium (as regulated by Normative Instruction 1,199/2011). In this sense, although a consortium may directly enter into transactions in its own name (and also benefit from tax incentives in relation to some situations, as provided by Normative Instruction 1,237/2012), it is not subject to CIT directly.

Non-profit legal entities are exempt from CIT, provided that certain conditions are fulfilled. However, such legal entities must still fulfil their accessory obligations. Failure to do so may result in penalties (see section 1.11.5.).
Brazilian law does not recognize the concept of hybrid entities, i.e. entities with legal personality that are not regarded as taxable units for tax purposes, such as transparent partnerships.
An individual entrepreneur is treated as a corporate taxpayer and is subject to CIT if such person (article 162 of the RIR):

item.p: organizes his or her business as an individual firm, being registered with the Board of Trade as an entrepreneur;
is habitually engaged in any economic activity of a civil or commercial nature which qualifies him or her as a business unit, even if not registered with the Board of Trade; or
promotes condominium buildings or land subdivisions.

section.p: In other cases, income derived by individual entrepreneurs is subject to individual income tax (see Individual Taxation section).

section.title: Definition of residence
section.p: Brazilian law refers to the concept of “domicile” rather than “residence”. As Brazilian tax law does not specify the criteria to determine when a legal person is considered to be domiciled in Brazil, the general concept of corporate domicile found in the Brazilian Civil Code is used for tax purposes. Under that code, the domicile of a legal person is the place where its headquarters or main direction is located, or the special domicile indicated in the act of incorporation. The criteria used is the place of incorporation, as the residence of a legal person is considered to be the place where it has its headquarters or place of main direction, as indicated in the act of constitution of the legal person when registered in Brazil. It does not provide, therefore, for the material analysis of the place where, in practice, the management takes place, but the formal indication in the act of incorporation of the place where it is headquartered or directed.

For legal persons the head office or place of main direction of which is outside Brazil, the Civil Code states that the place of residence is deemed to be, for the purpose of the obligations of the permanent establishment in Brazil, the place where such permanent establishment is situated. For international purposes, this is a peculiar provision, as it considers that a permanent establishment of a non-resident person is a resident of Brazil. A normal conclusion would lead to the application of the principle of universality to the permanent establishment. However, the article indicates that the residence is deemed to be in Brazil only for the purpose of obligations of the permanent establishment. In this case, it may be concluded that the Civil Code applies a restriction on the principle of universality, as regards the permanent establishment. This principle would therefore not be applicable to permanent establishments in Brazil, although they are deemed to be resident in Brazil under the civil law.

In defining the term “residence”, Brazilian treaties generally follow the OECD Model, but normally exclude the following sentence of article 4, paragraph 1 of the OECD Model: “This term, however, does not include any person who is liable to tax in that State in respect only of income from sources in that State or capital situated therein”.
Although Brazilian law refers to the concept of domicile, for the purpose of consistency, this chapter refers to domiciled and non-domiciled persons as resident and non-resident persons.

section.title: General
section.p: The CTN defines taxable income as:

item.p: proceeds resulting from capital, labour or their combination; and
income of any kind, i.e. any increase in wealth.

section.p: Hence, as income is broadly defined, CIT applies to all revenues received as the product of capital or services, or a combination thereof, as well as any and all gains resulting from the disposal of the taxpayer’s assets or rights. CIT is, therefore, imposed on income derived from industrial and commercial transactions, as well as the rendering of services. Financial revenue, income from portfolio investments and gains from the disposal of other assets or rights are also included in taxable income, whatever their source.

Resident companies are taxed on worldwide income. Under the rules introduced by Law 9,249/1995 and article 74 of PM 2,158-35/2001, a Brazilian-resident company not only must include the foreign-source income derived (whether directly or through a permanent establishment) but also the profits earned by its foreign controlled or affiliated companies in the proportion of the equity stake held in such entities (on 31 December of every year), regardless of effective distribution. It can be said that Brazil has introduced an extraterritorial system of taxation (see section 7.2.).

There are basically four different regimes for purposes of assessing and collecting CIT, namely: (i) the actual profit regime (lucro real); (ii) the presumed profit regime (lucro presumido); (iii) the simplified regime for the collection of federal taxes and contributions (Simples Nacional); and (iv) the determined profit regime (lucro arbitrado). Other specific regimes are also available for some types of activities (such as the Special Tax Regime for Real Estate Development).

The two most relevant regimes are the actual profit regime and the presumed profit regime. The presumed profit regime is an optional regime available for some legal entities and may be more efficient from a tax collection perspective, depending on the profitability level of the business.

topic.title: Actual profit regime
topic.p: Under the actual profit regime, taxable persons for CIT purposes are taxed on their actual profit, which is legally defined as the adjusted accounting profit, i.e. the accounting profit with the additions and exclusions provided for in the tax law.

As a general principle under the Federal Constitution, all sorts of income should be considered for CIT purposes. Therefore, unless otherwise provided for in the tax laws, any equity increase is considered taxable income.
Some legal entities are obliged to adopt the actual profit regime. These entities are:

item.p: those for which the total gross income in the previous tax year exceeded BRL 78 million (according to Law 12,814/2013, the new limit is effective as of 1 January 2014);
financial institutions, insurance companies, securities brokers and similar entities;
those that derive profits, income or capital gains from foreign sources (income from the export of goods and services is not included);
those that have been granted a tax incentive;
those engaged in factoring activities; and
those engaged in securitization of real estate, financial and agribusiness credits.

topic.p: As a general rule, corporate taxpayers must adopt the accrual regime for the recognition of revenues and expenses, regardless of the effective receipt of the relevant payment. In some specific cases, however, the law expressly allows that the cash regime is adopted (such as with regard to real estate developments in which the sale of units is agreed for payment in instalments).

Corporate taxpayers may opt to assess the CIT annually or quarterly. If the quarterly assessment is elected, the taxable period is deemed to actually end on the last day of each quarter (and all revenues within such quarter must be considered for the assessment of CIT). If the annual assessment is elected, the taxable period ends on 31 December.
Capital gains realized by legal entities are normally added to the taxable base and taxed as ordinary income for CIT purposes (see section 1.7.1.).
Dividends received from a resident legal entity are not subject to CIT.
Interest and royalties received from resident or non-resident entities are generally included in the CIT taxable base.
In order to determine the actual profit income, the following steps should be followed:

item.p: gross business profit (lucro bruto) is equal to the net revenue from supplies of goods and services (receita líquida) minus the related costs;

other income (e.g. interest) and business expenses in general are then added to the gross business income for the computation of business profits (lucro operacional). In this step, business profit represents the net profit of the company from its normal or ordinary course of business;

capital gains (see section 1.7.) and monetary surplus from the revaluation of assets are added to business profit. At this stage, the taxpayer has calculated its net profit (lucro líquido). Revaluation of assets was possible under the accounting rules that applied before the introduction of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). Currently, the revaluation of assets is no longer possible from an accounting or tax perspective. Nevertheless, the companies that still have those reserves in their books are allowed to keep them until the asset is disposed of. At the moment of disposal, the reserve needs to be added to the taxable profit;

under article 25(3) of Law 9,249/1995, article 74 of PM 2,158-35/2001 and IN 213/2002, a resident company must also include in its taxable base the profits derived by non-resident controlled and affiliated entities. PM 627/2013, converted into Law 12,973/2014, introduced significant changes to the Brazilian CFC rules as of 1 January 2015 (see section 10.4.); and

finally, accumulated tax losses may be set off up to 30% of the taxable profit (see section 1.8.) At this stage, generally speaking, a resident company has determined its actual profit, which is the taxable base for CIT purposes.

topic.p: As from 2010, this method for computing taxable income was affected by some changes, considering the provisions of articles 15 to 24 of Law 11,941/2009, which intended to neutralize the impacts of the new accounting methods and criteria set forth by Law 11,638/2007.

Law 11,638/2007 introduced the IFRS in the Brazilian accounting system, therefore changing some criteria usually adopted for the recognition of income, expenses and costs, and for the accounting computation of some specific transactions. Although the changes introduced by Law 11,638/2007 certainly produce effects for accounting purposes, the Brazilian government decided that such changes would not be considered for tax purposes (i.e. for tax purposes, a Brazilian-resident company would still rely on the Brazilian Generally Accepted Accounting Principles as to the recognition of revenues, expenses, etc.), establishing therefore the “tax neutrality” of the IFRS. In principle, the tax neutrality would be temporary, in order to allow Brazilian companies to gradually adapt to the IFRS. In view of the tax neutrality principle, Law 11,941/2009 introduced the “transitional tax regime” (Regime Tributário de Transição, RTT) as an option for the years 2008 and 2009. As of the year of 2010, the RTT became mandatory for all Brazilian entities, until a law governing the tax effects of the new accounting rules was enacted.

The RTT allowed the effects of Law 11,638/2007 on the criteria for the determination of revenues, costs and expenses not to impact the calculation of the legal entity’s actual profit. Therefore, in practice, the Brazilian entities maintained two different balance sheets, i.e. an “accounting balance sheet” (prepared under IFRS) and a “tax balance sheet” (prepared under the previously existing Brazilian GAAP, based on the RTT).

Recently, Law 12,937/2014, which is generally effective as of 1 January 2015, revoked the RTT and introduced several tax accounting rules. These changes are generally designed to ensure that the legal and contractual nature of the transactions prevails for tax purposes, irrespective of the accounting treatment. The main points addressed by the new law include: (i) the adoption of the new rules (early adoption before 2015 was possible); (ii) tax treatment of dividends, interest on net equity and the equity pick-up (método de equivalência patrimonial); and (iii) tax amortization of goodwill.

topic.title: Presumed profit regime
topic.p: Eligible legal entities may opt to be taxed under the presumed profit regime. Under article 13 of Law 9,718/1998, as modified by Law 12,814/2013, legal entities whose total gross income, including capital gains, did not exceed BRL 78 million (previously BRL 48 million) in the prior year (or BRL 6.5 million multiplied by the number of months of activity in the prior calendar year, previously BRL 4 million) and which are not obliged to adopt the actual profit regime may choose to be taxed under the presumed profit regime. According to Law 12,814/2013, the new gross revenue limit for opting for the presumed profit regime is effective as of 1 January 2014.
This option can be exercised on a yearly basis always before the date on which the first monthly CIT instalment must be paid.

The presumed profit regime is a simplified method for the calculation of CIT under which the legal entity assesses its taxable profit by applying a pre-determined percentage (as established in the law) to its total gross revenue earned in the quarter (in the presumed profit regime, the annual assessment is not an option). Therefore, the starting point for the assessment of CIT is the legal entity’s gross revenue, and no deductions are allowed.

The applicable percentages are different in connection with the IRPJ and the CSLL. For the IRPJ, the applicable percentages for the definition of the taxable base range from 1.6% (for income related to the sale of fuel and natural gas) to 32% (for income from the rendering of services). Commercial activities are, in general, subject to the 8% presumed profit percentage. With regard to the CSLL, the presumed profit is obtained by applying the percentages of 12% or 32% (also depending on the activity of the company). The 12% percentage generally applies to commercial activities, while the 32% applies to the rendering of services. If the legal entity is engaged in different types of activities, the specific percentage should apply to the revenue earned in view of each activity.
Capital gains, revenue from financial investments and any other income must be directly added to the taxable profit subject to CIT (i.e. no presumed percentage applies).

The tax is assessed by applying the IRPJ (15%) and the CSLL (9%) rates to the taxable profit. The IRPJ surtax of 10% is also applied, but under this regime, it is applicable to the amount exceeding BRL 20,000, multiplied by the number of months to which it relates (e.g. BRL 60,000 for a quarter).
Taxes withheld on income included in the recipient’s taxable profit are credited.

Considering the presumed profit percentages and the CIT rates, it is common to say that the CIT, under the presumed profit regime, is imposed at a maximum aggregate rate of 10.88%, in connection with the rendering of services, and of 3.08% in connection with commercial activities.

topic.title: Simplified regime for the collection of taxes and contributions (Simples Nacional)
topic.p: Resolution CGSN 140/2018, published in the DOU of 24 May 2018, consolidates the rules applicable under the Simples Nacional regime. Accordingly, micro enterprises, currently considered by law as those with an annual gross income of less than BRL 360,000, and small enterprises, whose annual gross income does not exceed BRL 4.8 million, may opt for a simplified regime for the joint collection of federal, state and municipal taxes and contributions. Individual entrepreneurs treated as corporate taxpayers (see section 1.1.4.), referred to as MEI by the Law, may also adopt the simplified regime, provided that their annual gross revenue does not exceed BRL 81,000.
Small and micro enterprises are entitled to an extra annual gross income limit of BRL 3.6 million for revenues arising from exported goods and services.

Some legal entities may not qualify for the Simples Nacional regime, even if the above revenue thresholds are respected. Among others, the following entities do not qualify: (i) an entity incorporated as a corporation (sociedade anônima, SA), (ii) an entity having a non-resident shareholder and (iii) an entity whose shares are held by other legal entities. As of 1 January 2015, Complementary Law 147/2014 extended the list of business activities eligible for the Simples Nacional regime to include any service activity duly regulated and of an intellectual, technical, scientific, sportive, artistic or cultural nature, provided that certain conditions are met. This means that professionals such as lawyers, doctors and engineers are able to opt for the simplified tax regime.

The regime consists of a single monthly payment covering IRPJ, CSLL, IPI (see section 13.4.), COFINS (see section 2.3.2.), PIS (see section 2.3.3.), ICMS (see section 14.6.4.1.), ISS (see section 14.6.4.2.) and a contribution of the employer to the social security (contribuição patronal previdenciária para a seguridade social) (see section 4.1.). Under the regime, the total liability for the taxes is calculated via application of a percentage to the legal entity’s gross revenue. The rates vary in accordance with the activity that generated the revenue (which leads to the imposition or not of some of the taxes) and it is progressive according to the level of revenue.

The Brazilian states may adopt reduced thresholds in relation to the possibility of the legal entity adopting the Simples Nacional regime for the collection of the ICMS. When said reduction is in place, the same threshold applies for the adoption of the Simples Nacional regime for the collection of the ISS due in relation to the municipalities within the borders of that state. In those cases, the Simples Nacional regime would still apply for the collection of federal taxes and contributions, but the regular collection regimes would apply for the ICMS and the ISS.
The monthly payment is calculated at progressive rates ranging from 4% to 22.90%, although it may be increased in some specific situations provided for in the applicable laws.
The following legal entities do not qualify for the simplified tax regime, among other restrictions:

item.p: any company incorporated as a corporation (sociedade anônima, SA);
those having a non-resident member;
subsidiaries, branches and permanent establishments of foreign companies;
those with capital held by a legal entity (i.e. only entities held by individuals may adopt such regime);
those resulting from mergers or spin-offs occurred within the last 5 calendar years;
those which have a partner that holds 10% or more of the equity of another legal entity that is not eligible for the Simples Nacional regime;

special listed business activity enterprises. As of January 2015, professional activities such as lawyers, doctors and engineers could not qualify for the simplified regime. However, Complementary Law 147/2014 extended the list of business activities eligible for the regime to include any service activity duly regulated and of an intellectual, technical, scientific, sportive, artistic or cultural nature, provided that certain conditions are met; and
those that have pending debts with the social security system.

topic.title: Determined profit regime
topic.p: The determined profit regime is not an optional regime, but rather a regime adopted by tax authorities in case the taxpayer does not comply with his CIT and ancillary obligations.
An income tax assessment based on profit as determined by the tax authorities is generally applicable where:

item.p: the taxpayer fails to maintain commercial and tax records in accordance with applicable tax laws;

the taxpayer’s bookkeeping evidences fraud, defects or errors which make it impossible to verify actual transactions undertaken or to determine the corporate income taxes due and payable by the taxpayer based on the actual profit; or
the taxpayer inappropriately opts to calculate and pay corporate income taxes under the presumed profit regime.

topic.p: Under the determined profit regime, the taxable base is calculated by applying percentages specified by law to the gross income derived by the company. These percentages range from 1.92% to 45%, depending on the business activity of the taxpayer.

Income tax is payable at the rate of 15% on the determined profit. An additional income tax of 10% is levied on the determined profit in excess of BRL 20,000 accrued monthly (or BRL 240,000 in the calendar year). Also, a CSLL is imposed at the rate of 9%.

section.title: Taxable period
section.p: Under the actual profit regime, legal entities may opt to assess the CIT due on a quarterly basis or on an annual basis. If the election for the annual basis is made, legal entities must pay CIT on a monthly basis, based on an estimation procedure, so that the final income tax liability is determined on 31 December, when the taxable event for CIT is deemed to occur. The estimate is calculated based on a pre-established percentage to be applied to the gross revenue of the month. The percentages range from 8% to 32% in accordance with the activity of the taxpayer.
Under the presumed profit regime, CIT is assessed on a quarterly basis.

The accounting year is the period between the two closing dates of the company’s balance sheet. Under corporate law, the accounting period is 1 year and ends on the date established in the company’s by-laws. Corporate taxpayers may select any annual accounting period (i.e. the accounting period does not necessarily begin on 1 January and end on 31 December).

The tax period is the budget year of the federal government (currently this coincides with the calendar year, i.e. from 1 January to 31 December). The assessment period is the year in which the tax is due.

section.title: Exempt income
section.p: The Federal Constitution establishes a constitutional exemption (immunity) for the wealth, income or services of political parties, foundations, labour unions, and educational and welfare entities, as long as they are not-for-profit and meet the requirements established in the legislation. Brazilian political subdivisions (states, federal district and municipalities) and religious temples are also constitutionally exempt from taxes, including CIT. A constitutional exemption also applied to books (including e-books - Binding Precedent 57/2020), newspapers, periodicals and to the paper used for printing.
Philanthropic, recreational, cultural and scientific not-for-profit organizations may also enjoy CIT exemption, as long as certain requirements are met.

Few items of income are exempt from tax, including domestic-source dividends (see section 6.1.3.) – the taxation of dividends at source at the rate of 15% is, however, being considered under Bill 2337/2021. Equity pick-up gains are also tax-free.

The Brazilian government grants several tax exemptions to Brazilian companies, conditioned on the performance of determined activities or the establishment of companies in a specific Brazilian region (see section 1.9.).

section.title: Valuation
section.p: Brazil is in the process of harmonizing its accounting system with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) (see section 1.2.1.). Although, currently, the effects of such process for tax purposes are neutralized by the RTT, this is an aspect that may be affected in the future. Recently, Law 12,973/2014 revoked the RTT with effect from 1 January 2015 – early adoption was possible. As a result of the new law, tax accounting rules should be aligned with IFRS. The law provides mechanisms to ensure the changes are tax neutral, but also provides conditions for its application as well as various exceptions.

For Brazilian income tax purposes, transactions should reflect their market value. However, under Brazilian tax law, there are several transactions that may be performed at book value (for example amounts transferred for increasing the capital of a Brazilian resident company and a capital reduction for the devolution of assets to shareholders).

section.title: Inventory
section.p: For tax purposes, merchandise and raw materials are valued at the lesser of their market value or acquisition cost. The acquisition cost of merchandise intended to be sold includes transportation and insurance costs up to the taxpayer’s establishment (i.e. the cost, insurance, freight value), as well as non-recoverable taxes paid upon the local acquisition and importation.
Goods for eventual consumption, whose value is not above 5% of the total cost of the products sold in the preceding tax year, may be registered as costs.

The cost of merchandise sold and the cost of consumed raw materials are calculated on the basis of permanent registration of inventory or on the basis of inventory as registered at the end of the period.
Finished and semi-finished products are valued at their production cost.
The production cost of goods and services includes:

item.p: the acquisition cost of raw materials and any other goods or services used or consumed in the production process;
the cost of personnel working in production or used in direct supervision, maintenance and custody of productive installations;
lease, maintenance and restoration costs of productive assets, as well as depreciation thereon;
amortization directly related to production; and
depletion of natural resources used in the production.

section.p: In general, recognized methods of inventory pricing, such as the weighted average cost and FIFO (first in, first out), are acceptable to the tax administration. The LIFO (last in, first out) method, however, is not accepted for tax purposes.

If a corporate taxpayer maintains an integrated cost system which is coordinated with other records, it may rely on such system for purposes of valuing the costs of finished products and raw materials. On the other hand, if there is no coordinated system:

item.p: semi-finished products are valued at 150% of the value of raw materials acquired in the period or at 80% of the value of finished products established as in (2), which means 56% of the highest sales price of finished products; and
finished products are valued at 70% of the highest price of sales in the tax period.

section.p: Under article 310(IV) of the RIR, it is not possible to adjust the acquisition or production cost to the market value if this is lower.

section.title: Depreciable assets
section.p: Fixed assets and intangibles are, in general, subject to depreciation or amortization. Depreciable/amortizable assets include buildings, patents, goodwill (provided that certain requirements are met) and machinery. For such purposes, they are originally valued at acquisition cost.
Law 11,638/2007 introduced the impairment concept for accounting purposes. However, the impairment of assets has no effect for tax purposes in view of the RTT.

section.title: Non-depreciable assets
section.p: Land, participations in other companies and securities, among other assets, are non-depreciable. They are valued at their acquisition cost (impairment provisions under the new IFRS rules in Brazil have no tax effect in view of the RTT).

section.title: Debt claims and liabilities
section.p: Brazilian resident legal entities are taxed on an accrual basis. If debt claims and liabilities are spread across more than one taxable period, they are usually considered on a pro-rata basis for income taxation purposes.
Debt and claims are valued at their nominal adjusted cost in accordance with the correspondent index at the closing date of the period.

section.title: Foreign currency assets and liabilities
section.p: Changes in the value of assets and liabilities in view of currency fluctuations are treated as financial income or expense and considered for the assessment of the CIT. They are booked considering the original cost of the right or obligation.

Brazilian corporate taxpayers may opt to record, for tax purposes, currency gains and losses related to liabilities and credit rights on either an accrual basis or a cash basis, situations in which the gains and losses will be considered for CIT purposes only when the corresponding transaction is liquidated.

section.title: General principles
section.p: Deductions are only allowed with regard to the assessment of the CIT based on the actual profit regime. As a general rule, costs and expenses paid or incurred during the tax period may be deducted, to the extent that they qualify as necessary for the production of taxable income or for the maintenance of the source of that income. The necessity of an expense is determined based on its relation to the activity of the company. In order to be deductible, expenses must be ordinary and normal for the transactions or activities of the enterprise.

Special rules apply to certain categories of expenses, namely advertising expenses, amortization, bad debts, gifts and contributions, entertainment expenses, insurance premiums, interest payments, directors’ remuneration and research expenses. Deductibility depends on specific conditions being fulfilled and is often limited.

Normative Instruction 1,556/2015 established that if taxpayers do not deduct depreciation allowances of a fixed asset in a given period, they are neither allowed to cumulatively deduct the depreciation expenses in a different period in which the asset was used, nor to recover the non-deducted amounts by using rates higher than the maximum rates allowed.

The acquisition cost of fixed assets is not considered as a business expense, except for assets the single value of which is not above BRL 326.61 or assets with a maximum useful life of 1 year. However, depreciation of fixed assets, when allowed, generates deductible expenses.
Payments made to persons located in low-tax jurisdictions or benefiting from privileged tax regimes are deductible only if certain conditions are met. For details, see section 10.6.1.
For thin capitalization rules, see section 10.3.

section.title: Employees’ remuneration
section.p: The deduction of salaries or other kinds of remuneration is not subject to any limits (Law 9,430/1996). Profits distributed to employees under general rules are deductible.

Incurred entertainment expenses, including reimbursement of an entity’s officers’ and employees’ expenses, may be deducted. A deduction is allowed for insurance premiums relating to employees (such as life, accident, disability and health insurance of employees).

Social security contributions are deductible, provided that they are paid within the prescribed deadlines. Social assistance services for employees, including the supplementation of retirement payments made to official social security institutions, are deemed to be operating expenses and therefore deductible for CIT purposes (up to the limit of 20% of the total amount of salaries and compensation paid to employees and officers).

section.title: Directors’ fees
section.p: Under article 368 of the RIR, payments of fixed monthly fees (pro-labore) as remuneration for services provided by partners, managers and members of the board of directors are deductible for CIT purposes.
Payments to non-resident members of a company’s board of directors are not deductible.

section.title: Dividends
section.p: Dividends are not considered a deductible expense for CIT purposes. This is in line with the general principle under which dividends are not subject to withholding income tax or to any taxation at the level of the beneficiary.

section.title: Interest
section.p: Legal entities may deduct, at the end of each accounting period, the interest which becomes due, even if not paid, calculated on a pro-rata basis in accordance with the accrual basis. As any other expense, deductibility of interest is available if the general deductibility conditions are respected.
Interest due during the start-up period of a company may be deferred in order to be amortized (with the generation of deductible expenses) after the company begins to operate.

Interest directly or indirectly paid to local shareholders must respect market standards in order to be deductible, in view of the Brazilian rules on disguised distribution of profits (Distribuição Disfarçada de Lucros, DDL) (articles 528 to 532 of the RIR).

For limitation on deductibility of interest paid to non-resident shareholders or to companies resident in low-tax jurisdictions (jurisdições com tributação favorecida, JTF) or benefiting from privileged tax regimes (regimes fiscais privilegiados, RFP), see section 10.6. For thin capitalization rules, see section 10.3., and for transfer pricing rules, see section 10.2.).
Interest paid in connection with the non-payment of taxes by their due date is deductible as a financial expense, as is interest paid in connection with contractual obligations.
Under Law 9,959/2000, interest paid or credited to controlled or affiliated companies, on an amount equivalent to the profits which were not distributed to the shareholder, is not deductible.
For interest on net equity, see section 1.4.9.3.

section.title: Royalties
section.p: As a general rule, royalties are deductible provided that they are necessary for the production or maintenance of taxable income.
However, some limits are imposed by the applicable laws, such as:

item.p: as a general rule, the deduction of payments related to patents, trademarks and know-how is limited to 5% of the net revenues from the sale of the relevant products;

where patent, trademark and know-how royalties are paid to non-residents, they are deductible up to a percentage (between 1% and 5%) set by the Ministry of Finance, depending on the type of royalty, product or industry involved (e.g. 4% for patent royalties related to chemical, pharmaceutical, or electrical products, and 1% for trademark royalties);

patent, know-how and trademark royalties are deductible only if the related contract is registered with the Brazilian Patent and Trademark Institute (Instituto Nacional de Propriedade Intelectual, INPI). If the recipient is a non-resident, the contract, in addition to registration with the INPI, must also be registered with the Central Bank of Brazil; and

royalties paid by the Brazilian legal entity to a non-resident who has direct or indirect control over the Brazilian entity are deductible provided they are related to contracts signed after 1991 and duly registered with INPI and the Central Bank of Brazil.

section.p: Some payments are, however, not deductible (article 363 of the RIR):

item.p: royalties for patents, formulas, trademarks paid by a Brazilian branch of a non-resident company in favour of the foreign head office;
royalties paid by a resident legal entity to individual and corporate shareholders, directors, or to their relatives or dependents;
royalties paid by the Brazilian legal entity to a non-resident who has direct or indirect control over the Brazilian entity, in case of contracts signed before 1991;

royalties paid by the Brazilian legal entity to a non-resident who has direct or indirect control over the Brazilian entity, in case of contracts signed after 1991 but not registered with the INPI and the Central Bank of Brazil.

section.p: Therefore, Brazilian legislation has an inconsistent rule of not allowing deduction of royalty payments to resident shareholders but allowing deduction of royalty payments to a foreign controller (after 1991), provided that the contract is duly registered.

section.title: Service and management fees
section.p: Fees for management services, commercial and industrial know-how, and other similar services, are deductible in computing taxable profit as long as the payments are necessary for the income-producing activity of the company.

Payments to non-residents for technical, scientific or administrative assistance (either as a lump sum or as recurring royalties) may be deducted as business expenses under certain conditions, including:

item.p: the payment must relate to services actually rendered to a resident company through technicians, designs or instructions sent to Brazil or technical studies performed abroad on behalf of the Brazilian company;

the payment must not exceed a certain percentage set by the Ministry of Finance, depending on the type of product or industry involved (e.g. 4% for service fees relating to chemical, pharmaceutical, or electric products, and 5% for fees relating to the communications and the hydrocarbon industry); and
the technical assistance agreement must be registered with both the INPI and the Central Bank of Brazil.

section.p: However, payments for technical, scientific and administrative assistance made by a branch of a non-resident company in favour of its foreign head office are not deductible.

Technical assistance fees are deductible for a maximum period of 5 years from the introduction of the industrial process to which they relate. This period may be extended for an additional 5-year period.

section.title: Research and development
section.p: Research expenses for the development or improvement of industrial products are deductible, provided that the research has a scientific or technological nature, with the exception of land which is non-depreciable, and buildings and equipment acquired for that purpose, for which only normal depreciation is allowed.
For incentives on research and development, see section 1.9.4.7.

section.title: Taxes
section.p: Taxes and contributions are deductible on an accrual basis. A deduction is also allowed for interest paid in connection with the late payment of taxes. Penalties imposed on tax assessments are not deductible, while penalties paid in view of late collection (without a tax assessment being brought) are deductible.

Taxes paid in connection with purchases of tangible fixed assets may be registered as acquisition cost or deducted as a business expense, at the taxpayer’s election, except for recoverable taxes which may not be deducted.

section.title: Provisions
section.p: Under Brazilian legislation, provisions are computed as a reduction on the equity of the legal entity due to a future and certain obligation or an obligation that is likely to happen in the future.
Under article 339 of the RIR, provisions are not deductible unless expressly authorized by law, such as provisions for holiday payments, the 13th bonus salary for employees and qualifying bad debts.

Article 340 of the RIR establishes the possibility of deducting technical reserves of insurance companies, capitalization companies, and open private pension entities which are required by the regulatory authorities. In this regard, CNSP Rule 162/2006 (modified by CNSP Rules 181/2007, 195/2008 and 204/2009) and SUSEP Rule 424/2011 established several reserves that the aforementioned entities are required to create, such as for (1) unearned premiums; (2) unpaid claims reported; (3) claims incurred but not reported; (4) unexpired risks; (5) general contingency/solvency; (6) equalization; (7) premium deficiency; and (8) expired risks.

section.title: Interest on net equity
section.p: In addition to dividends, a company may elect to make a payment of interest on net equity (juros sobre capital próprio, JCP). JCP is a statutory remuneration to be paid to the shareholders, based on the net equity amount of the company. It has similarities to a dividend in terms of the legal procedures for its distribution (profit existence dependency, resolution on shareholders’ meeting, etc.) but it is subject to specific regulations.

The election to make a JCP payment can be made at the end of the year or during the year on an interim basis. The amount of JCP that is available to be paid out by a company is calculated by multiplying the company’s net equity balance by an official remuneration rate (taxa de juros de longo prazo, TJLP) announced quarterly by the Central Bank of Brazil.

Under Laws 9,249/1995 and 9,430/1996, the Brazilian legal entity is allowed to deduct from its CIT base the JCP amount paid or credited to the shareholder. For the limitations applicable on the deductibility of JCP, see section 10.3.2.
Bill 2337/2021, which is currently under discussion by the National Congress, proposes to extinguish JCP from the Brazilian legal framework.

section.title: Meals
section.p: Under article 383 of the RIR, meal expenses paid without distinction to all employees are deductible.

section.title: Donations and contributions
section.p: Under article 13(VI) and (2) of Law 9,249/1995, as a rule donations and contributions are not deductible, with the exception of (1) those made to or through qualifying cultural entities (under Law 8,313/1991); (2) those made to qualifying Brazilian non-profit welfare entities, limited to 2% of the donor’s taxable income before this deduction is taken; and (3) those made to educational and research institutions, limited to 1.5% of the donor’s taxable income before this deduction is taken.

section.title: Advertising
section.p: Advertising expenses are deductible with respect to (1) salaries paid to employees or self-employed professionals engaged in advertising, (2) payments to registered advertising agencies, newspapers, radio and television networks, (3) acquisition of copyrights or royalties paid to authors or artists and (4) distribution of free samples or specimens, limited to 5% of the sales proceeds from the product. In order to be deductible, advertising expenses must be directly related to the taxpayer’s activity. Expenses for gifts are generally not deductible.

section.title: Travel and transportation
section.p: Under case law, travel expenses are deductible only where the taxpayer can prove that they are necessary for the enterprise’s business. Expenses paid or incurred by the taxpayer in order to provide transportation services to and from work for employees is allowed as a deduction. If the expenses for transportation to and from work are directly incurred by the employee and reimbursed by the employer, the deductibility will depend on the treatment attributed to those values: (i) if they are considered indirect salary paid to the employer (subject to social security and labour charges), they will be deductible and (ii) if they are not treated as salary, they would, in principle, not be deductible, considering that only the transportation paid under the terms of the law (transportation tickets granted to the employee or charter services paid by the employer) are deductible.

section.title: Rent or lease payments
section.p: Rent payments (article 361 of the RIR) are deductible as an expense if they are (1) directly related to the operating activities of a taxpayer; (2) necessary for the use of immovable property; (3) not actual capital applied to the acquisition of goods and rights; and (4) not disguised distributions of profits.

Finance lease payments are deductible, provided that the transaction complies with the requirements set forth by Law 6,099/1974 (as to the mandatory contractual provisions, maximum financed amount, etc.). Lease payments not regulated by Law 6,099/1974 are subject to the provisions set forth in Law 12,973/2014 which aims at harmonizing Brazilian GAAP to IFRS.

Law 12,973/2014 established that financial expenses incurred by the lease holder in commercial leasing contracts are not taxed. On the other hand, the new law also established that the financial expenses relating to considerations paid or credited pursuant to a commercial leasing contract are deductible for corporate income tax purposes, provided that the contract concerns moveable or fixed assets intrinsically related to the production or commercialization of goods and services.

section.title: Start-up expenses
section.p: These expenses may be amortized, generating deductible expenses, over a minimum period of 5 years.

section.title: Non-deductible expenses
section.p: Expenses that do not comply with the general principles or specific rules, when applicable, are not deductible.

Under article 13(II) and (III) of Law 9,249/1995, rent or lease payments are not deductible unless they relate to the production or trading of goods or services (i.e. if they relate to income-generating activities). This limitation also applies to payments in respect of depreciation, amortization, taxes, insurance premiums, repair or conservation fees and any other expenses on movable or immovable property. Moreover, certain items are not deductible under certain circumstances, including those listed below.
Under article 13(IV) of Law 9,249/1995, meals paid to shareholders, quotaholders, partners or administrators are not deductible.

Salaries and profit-sharing paid to non-resident members of boards of directors of SAs are not deductible. Payments under profit-sharing programmes are also not deductible in connection with statutory managers and directors (even if Brazilian residents).
Under Law 9,316/1996, the CSLL and the IRPJ are not deductible for CIT purposes.

Under the disguised distribution of profits rules, local transactions carried out by local associated entities are subject to the restrictions on deductibility, via adjustments (additions) to the net profit, aiming at assuring that those transactions are performed at arm’s length.
Payments made to persons located in low-tax jurisdictions or benefiting from privileged tax regimes are not deductible, unless certain conditions are met. For details, see section 10.6.1.
For thin capitalization rules, see section 10.3.

section.title: General principles
section.p: Resident companies assessing CIT under the actual profit regime may benefit from depreciation of assets, as well as amortization of certain rights and capitalized expenses for CIT purposes.

As a rule, depreciation of tangible fixed assets used in the taxpayer’s business or income-generating activities must be calculated at an annual percentage, under the straight-line method. Rates are calculated based on the useful life of the asset and published by the tax authorities – currently under Normative Instruction 1,700/2017.

Under Law 4,506/1964, deductions for depreciation are at the taxpayer’s discretion and according to some (non-binding) administrative tax rulings, depreciation may be postponed. In loss years, depreciation must be accounted for the company’s net operational losses.

As a general rule, no deduction is allowed for depreciation in excess of generally accepted rates, unless previously approved by the tax authorities (the request must be supported by an appraisal from the National Technology Institute or another recognized institution).

The depreciation starts at the time the asset is installed, is available for operation or is in a condition to produce, even in loss years. Legal entities are allowed to use a lower rate for depreciation or even to not compute depreciation during a certain period, but they are not allowed to claim those amounts in the following periods by using depreciation in excess of generally accepted rules.
Depreciation of land, of assets which value normally increases within time (i.e. antiquities, pieces of art), or assets that are not used for the business activity is not allowed.
If an asset becomes useless before the end of the depreciable life, the balance may be written off as an expense in the year in which the loss of value occurs.
Depreciation of fixed assets prior to the operating phase must be capitalized as pre-operating expenses, which may be amortized over a minimum period of 5 years.

Depreciation allowances are calculated yearly on the useful life of the new asset (article 320 of the RIR). In the case of second-hand assets, depreciation is calculated on the greater of (1) half the useful life of the asset when it was new or (2) the remaining useful life (article 322 of the RIR). There are specific rules governing the accelerated depreciation of equipment and machinery.

In the absence of a specific rate for a given type of asset, a standard straight-line depreciation of 10% a year is allowed. In case of doubt as regards depreciation percentages, the taxpayer or the administration may request an expert judgement from the National Institute of Technology. The useful life established by that institute prevails unless amended by a higher authority or by a court ruling on the basis of a valid expert report.
If an asset becomes useless before the end of the depreciation period, the balance may be written off as an expense for the year in which the loss of value occurs (see section 1.5.8.).
For accelerated depreciation, see section 1.9.2.

Pre-operating expenses may be amortized over a minimum period of 5 years. Intangible assets, limited contractual rights and concessions related to the business activity of the corporate taxpayer may also be amortized over the period during which the right is exercised.

section.title: Right to claim depreciation
section.p: The right to claim depreciation belongs to the entity that holds the economic burden of the deterioration of the asset, according to the conditions of property, possession or use of this asset. Therefore, in the case of leasing contracts, the lessor will be entitled to depreciate. However, the burden can sometimes be borne by an entity that is not the owner, in which case a new and identical asset must be returned after its use.
The depreciation allowances are granted from the moment the asset is installed and available for operation or is in a condition to produce.

section.title: Immovable property
section.p: Buildings used for the production process, as well as constructions made of steel, aluminium or iron (towers and bridges), can be depreciated at the annual rate of 4% during 25 years using the straight line method.

section.title: Plant, machinery and equipment
section.p: A deduction is allowed for the depreciation of tangible fixed assets from the date on which the asset was installed, put into service or became suitable for production, using the straight-line method. Only Brazilian-situs fixed assets may be depreciated.
Under IN 1,700/2017, the depreciation of fixed assets or intangibles should not exceed the following percentages:

entry.p: TV sound and image devices and equipments
Iron or steel bridges and towers
Automotive vehicles (depending on type and purpose)

section.title: Trademarks and patents
section.p: The costs for acquisition of a right over an invention patent, manufacturing formula or process, copyright, licence, authorization or concession may be amortized when its use is limited to a certain period of time.

However, the capital used for the acquisition of a trademark is normally not subjected to amortization, because, as the right over the trademark can be renewed every 10 years, its use is not therefore limited to a certain period of time.

Amortization is computed by the application of the annual rate on the original value of the capital invested or of the registered expenses. The annual rate is fixed considering the remaining life (years) of the rights.

section.title: Goodwill
section.p: The capital invested in the acquisition of goodwill, such as improvements to the facilities, may be amortized when the rights involved are exercised or used only within a specified period. The annual amortization rate is fixed considering the remaining life (years) of the rights and is applied on the original value of the capital invested or of the registered expenses.

Law 12,973/2014 regulated the tax amortization of the premium paid in the acquisition of goodwill. The acquiring entity must account investment’s costs in a separate sub-account to clearly demonstrate the amounts relating to: (i) net equity of the acquired company; (ii) the fair value of the net assets; and (iii) the goodwill derived from future profitability – which is the remaining balance from items (i) and (ii).

Furthermore, apart from the requirement of an appraisal report prepared by an independent party, the goodwill is only deductible for tax purposes if the acquisition transaction is carried out by unrelated parties. This requirement was introduced by Law 12,973/2014 (prior to this Law, the amortization of internal goodwill was allowed).

section.title: Other assets
section.p: The costs for the acquisition of assets exclusively used for exploring mines, jazidas – natural accumulation of a particular type of rock – and forests may be subject to depreciation, when the period of the exploration activity is shorter than the assets’ life time. The rates vary in accordance with (1) the term of the mining or forest concession; (2) the term of the exploration agreement; or (3) the production volume for each year vis-à-vis the total volume of the mine/forest.

A premium paid within the acquisition of an investment (i.e. a positive difference between the equity value of the acquired investment and the respective acquisition price) may be amortized by the corporate taxpayer, provided that certain conditions are met. Generally speaking, the conditions are that the premium paid is justifiable based on the future profitability of the invested company and evidenced as such by an appraisal report, and that there is a merger between the investor and the invested company. The tax amortization of the premium must take place over a minimum 5-year term. In this regard, structures where premium amortization has been applied and that have been regarded as abusive by the tax authorities, have been questioned several times over the last years. Therefore, the benefit of premium amortization is currently a very controversial matter in Brazil.

section.title: Cessation of use, transfer or disposal of assets
section.p: The net book value of obsolete fixed assets no longer in use may be written off and deducted for tax purposes.

Brazilian laws permit write-downs to market value and write-offs of worthless stock and investments, except for write-offs of investments qualifying for a tax credit under incentive rules which are not deductible. When inventories are written off, the merchandise must be physically destroyed in the presence of a tax inspector.

Upon the disposal of an asset, its acquisition cost for purposes of calculating taxable capital gains is the original acquisition cost reduced by the depreciation accumulated over the years. There are no recapturing or balancing allowances under Brazilian law.

section.title: Unutilized depreciation or amortization allowances
section.p: Expenses such as depreciation must be booked, for tax purposes, in accordance with the accrual method. If, however, the accrual method is not observed by a company, it will only result in a tax charge if such inobservance leads to an improper reduction of the CIT taxable base. However, the expense may be used in a different year (i.e. the postponement of a deduction is, in principle, allowed).

section.title: Reserves and provisions
section.p: Under Brazilian legislation, provisions are computed as a reduction on the net equity of the legal entity due to a future and certain obligation or an obligation that is likely to happen in the future. Reserves are the amounts set aside before the distribution of profits for the purpose of increasing the net equity of the legal entity, for the payment of costs and expenses that may happen in the future.

As a rule, under article 13 of Law 9,249/1995, reserves and provisions are not deductible except for holiday payments and the 13th salary bonus for employees (see section 1.6.1.). Technical provisions for companies in the fields of insurance, capitalization or pension plans are deductible where such provision is required by law.

section.title: Bad and doubtful debts
section.p: The deduction of provisions for bad debts is not allowed for CIT purposes. However, under certain conditions, credits that are likely not to be received by the company may be written off and recognized as a deductible expense. Such conditions include (Law 9,430/1996):

item.p: the credits must relate to the taxpayer’s economic activities;
the credits must be related to debtors whose insolvency has been declared by a court decision;

with regard to credits without guarantee, the following write-offs are allowed: (1) credits of up to BRL 15,000 per transaction (until 8 October 2014, BRL 5,000), which have been outstanding for over 6 months, independently of whether judicial action has been taken for collection; (2) credits of more than BRL 15,000 (until 8 October 2014, BRL 5,000) and less than BRL 100,000 (until 8 October 2014, BRL 30,000) per transaction, which have been outstanding for over a year, provided that administrative procedures for collection have been adopted; (3) credits over BRL 100,000 (until 8 October 2014, BRL 30,000) which have been outstanding for over 1 year, provided that judicial actions for collection have been filed and are pursued; and

for credits with guarantee, they must be outstanding for over 2 years, and judicial actions for the collection or the execution of the guarantees must have been pursued in cases of credits over BRL 50,000 (until 8 October 2014, this requirement applied regardless of the amount of the credit).

section.p: Bad debts relating to credits granted to a controlling, subsidiary or related company are not deductible.

section.title: Replacement of assets
section.p: There are no special rules on replacement of assets reserve.

section.title: Other reserves and provisions
section.p: There are no other rules regarding reserves and provisions.

section.title: General
section.p: Capital gains arising from the disposal of assets or rights registered as the company’s permanent assets (including equity investments, fixed assets and financial investments) are included in the CIT taxable base (under both the actual profit regime and the presumed profit regime). Capital gains are comprised by the positive difference between the sales price of an asset or right and its book value.
Taxable capital gains are recognized upon any type of disposal of an asset or right, such as a sale, donation or contribution to the capital of another entity.

Gains arising from the sale of portfolio investments are also considered taxable income for CIT purposes in a way similar to capital gains (in those cases, however, the tax laws call it net gains – “ganhos líquidos”). However, such gains may be subject to specific regimes and withholding taxes (which are considered as anticipation of the final CIT liability).

section.title: Capital assets
section.p: Under section 501 of the RIR, the disposal of any permanent asset is subject to the assessment of capital gains.
The disposal of portfolio investments is subject to the assessment of net gains(ganhos líquidos, which are similar to capital gains, but with some peculiarities).

Virtual currencies (bitcoins) are treated as financial assets for tax purposes and must be declared under the category “other goods” in tax returns, provided that the taxpayer holds over the equivalent of BRL 1,000 in bitcoins by the end of the year. As a result, operations with bitcoins exceeding the value of BRL 35,000 are subject to a 15% income tax on the corresponding capital gain.

section.title: Realization
section.p: Capital gains will be realized upon the actual disposal of any kind of goods or rights composing the company’s permanent assets. There are no rules under which a deemed disposal occurs.

In the past, fixed assets could be revalued according to the market price. The monetary surplus was not immediately taxable (provided that the revaluation was based on an appraisal made by an independent appraiser). The asset’s appreciation required that a revaluation reserve be booked, such reserve being taxable upon the actual disposal of the assets that generated the reserve.

Currently, the revaluation of assets is no longer accepted under Brazilian accounting rules. However, revaluation reserves which still exist on the legal entity’s balance sheet may be maintained and should be subject to CIT when the asset or right that gave rise to the reserve is disposed of.

section.title: Computation of capital gains and losses

topic.title: Regular assets
topic.p: With regard to regular assets, capital gains are comprised by the positive difference between the sales price of the asset and the corresponding acquisition cost (net of depreciation, when applicable).

With regard to investment in other companies, the acquisition cost may correspond to the actual price paid for the acquisition of the investment (cost method) or to the actual price paid for the acquisition of the investment and the variation of the equity value of the investment (equity pick-up method). The equity pick-up method is mandatory with regard to investments in controlled and affiliated companies (as defined in Brazilian corporate law – Law 6,404/1976).
Capital gains must be included in the taxable base of the CIT of the period in which they are realized.

topic.title: Portfolio investments
topic.p: The disposal of shares of closed-end legal entities not listed in the stock exchange market or in any organized over-the-counter market is subject to the assessment of capital gains based on the general regime.

Transactions regarding acquisition and disposal of shares of listed companies and other securities performed in the stock exchange market or in organized over-the-counter markets qualify as variable income investments in the financial and capital markets. Upon disposal of these assets the net gains (ganhos líquidos) derived within the transaction must be assessed.

Net gains (ganhos líquidos) follow the same principle of capital gains, i.e. they are assessed based on the positive difference between the acquisition cost and the disposal price. However, the net gains are not calculated in connection with each transaction, but rather it must consider all transactions involving the disposal of variable income investments performed during the month.

Gains from the disposal of securities within the stock exchange market or in an organized over-the-counter market (mercado de balcão organizado) are subject to withholding income tax at the rate of 0.005% on the sales price (article 2, paragraphs 1 and 2 of Law 11,033/2004 and article 52 of Normative Instruction 1,022/2010). Such withholding tax may be credited against the final CIT liability.
In connection with day trade transactions, the withholding tax is imposed at a 1% rate (article 8 of Law 9,959/2000 and article 54 of Normative Instruction SRF 1,022/2010).

For the purposes of assessment of the monthly net gains, losses incurred in variable income transactions may be set off against gains derived in future variable income transactions of the same kind, in the same month or in subsequent months if the losses were not fully deducted in the month in which they were incurred. Losses incurred in connection with day trade transactions may not be deducted by corporate taxpayers under the actual profit regime.

Additionally, all expenses effectively incurred and outlined in trading invoices (such as brokerage fees and other related expenses) that were necessary for the acquisition and disposal of the securities may be deducted for purposes of assessing the net gains (article 27 of Law 8,383/1991, article 841, paragraph 2 of the RIR and section 45, paragraph 3 of Normative Instruction 1,022/2010).
Gains from the redemption of units of specific funds are subject to the following withholding tax rates:

item.p: share fund (fundos de ações): 15% (article 1 of Law 11,033/04 and article 18 of Normative Instruction 1,022/2010);
private equity fund: 15%, provided that the requirements on the composition of the fund portfolio are respected (article 2 of Law 11,312/2006); and
real estate fund: 20% (articles 17 and 18 of Law 8,668/1993 and article 27 of Normative Instruction 1,022/2010).

topic.p: The capitalization of securities is deemed to be a sale according to Declaratory Act 7/2007, so that taxpayers who capitalize investment funds with their own securities are deemed to derive capital gain (subject to income tax at the rate of 15%) on the difference between the market value and the acquisition cost of the security. For this purpose, investors must demonstrate the acquisition cost of the securities; otherwise, the acquisition cost is deemed to be zero. According to Provisional Measure 651/2014, converted into Law 13,043/2014, with effect from 1 January 2015, the administrator of the investment fund is responsible for the calculation and collection of income tax levied on capital gains realized by investors who use their own securities to capitalize the investment fund.

The actual payment of the CIT imposed on the net gains depends on the CIT regime adopted by the taxpayer and the mechanisms adopted for the collection. In general, under the actual profit regime, the net gains are collected separately and are not included in the monthly estimates. The gains are added to the taxable base of the CIT to determine the final CIT liability. If the taxpayer in a given month does not collect the CIT on the estimated base, in view of the assessment via a suspension or reduction balance sheet (see section 1.11.4.) the net gains are included in such balance sheet and do not need to be collected separately. Under the presumed profit regime, the net gains must be taxed separately.

Finally, the positive results obtained in transactions not performed in the stock exchange market or in the organized over-the-counter market (such as in non-organized over-the-counter markets) are treated as regular capital gains.

section.title: Exempt capital gains
section.p: Gains derived in view of the compulsory sale to the state of rural property in view of agrarian reform programmes are exempt from CIT.

section.title: Deferment of tax on capital gains
