section.p: If the payment of the amount is partially or totally made after the end of the calendar year following the sale, the company can include the proportional gains in each respective period in which payment is made. This deferment is allowed regarding sales of fixed assets and if at least part of the amount of the sale is accorded in the contract to be paid after the end of the calendar year following the purchase (late payments are not accepted for deferment purposes).

There is also a deferment on capital gains regarding compensation for compulsory purchase by the state (other than for rural land reform purpose), if the entity transfers the capital gains to special profits reserve and uses the amount for the acquisition of another fixed asset in the following 2 years.

topic.title: Operating losses
topic.p: The main rules governing the treatment of losses are currently contained in article 42 of Law 8,981/1995, article 15 of Law 9,065/1995 and articles 25(5) and 31 of Law 9,249/1995.

Accounting losses, which are those verified in the balance sheet of the company after the consideration of all income, costs and expenses, may be set off against accounting profits without limitation.

Nevertheless, accumulated tax losses, which are those verified upon the assessment of CIT, based on the adjusted accounting profit or loss (i.e. accounting profit or loss with the additions and exclusions provided for the assessment of the CIT) may be set off against the taxable profit up to 30% of the taxpayer’s taxable profit in a given year. Accumulated losses may be carried forward indefinitely. There is no carry-back of losses.

The limitation of accumulated losses to 30% of taxable profit has been challenged in court by taxpayers as unconstitutional. Although there have been some preliminary decisions of lower courts preventing tax authorities from collecting taxes from taxpayers who have set off the full amount of accumulated losses (i.e. without taking into consideration the 30% limit), on 27 June 2019, the Federal Supreme Court confirmed that the limitation is constitutional (Extraordinary Appeal 591,340).
Accumulated tax losses may no longer be enjoyed by the taxpayer if there is a change in the control of the company cumulatively with a change in its activities.

topic.title: Non-operating losses
topic.p: Non-operating losses, i.e. the losses arising from the disposal of fixed assets, investment and intangibles, are also subject to the 30% limit and may be compensated only against profits from the same nature.
Foreign-source losses are discussed in section 7.2.2.

section.title: Capital losses
section.p: Losses incurred in the general course of a company’s business may be set off for CIT purposes if considered necessary for the company’s activities.

Capital losses from the destruction or damage of fixed assets due to accidents or other force majeur events, or the replacement of such assets due to technical obsolescence, are deductible in respect of the non-depreciated portion thereof, except when covered by insurance.

section.title: Incentives
section.p: Brazil has made extensive use of incentives to promote the development of specific regions and activities. The incentive scheme covers export promotion, sectorial incentives and regional incentives. Regional incentives have proven to be the most elaborate and successful group.

On 30 August 2017, the World Trade Organization (WTO) issued panel reports on Brazil’s measures concerning automotive and information technology programmes (Dispute Settlements 472 and 479). The reports concluded that the Programme for the Development of the Semiconductor Industry (Programa de Apoio ao Desenvolvimento da Indústria de Semicondutores, PADIS) (see section 1.9.4.8.), the IT Law incentive (see section 1.9.4.7.), the Digital Inclusion Programme (no longer available), the Incentive Programme of Technological Innovation of the Production Line of Automotive Vehicles (Programa de Incentivo à Inovação Tecnológica e Adensamento da Cadeia Produtiva de Veículos Automotores, INOVAR-AUTO) (no longer available) and the R&D incentive for Digital TV Industry (Programa de apoio ao desenvolvimento tecnológico da indústria de equipamentos para a TV digital, PATVD) (no longer available) are inconsistent with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (SCM Agreement) and the Agreement on Trade-Related Investment Measures (TRIMs Agreement).

Additionally, the panel concluded that the tax suspensions granted under the incentive for acquisition of inputs, intermediary products and packaging by export companies (Programa Preponderantemente Exportador, PEC) and the incentive for acquisitions of capital goods by export companies (Regime especial de aquisição de bens de capital para empresas exportadoras, RECAP) (see section 1.9.4.7.) programmes qualify as prohibited subsidies within the scope of the SCM Agreement.

To the extent that aspects of the challenged programmes are inconsistent with WTO rules, the panel recommends that Brazil brings the challenged measures into conformity with its obligations under the covered agreements and that it withdraws the subsidies identified without delay. Brazil has filed a notice of appeal in both dispute settlements. On 13 December 2018, the WTO appeals body issued its report in which it accepted Brazil’s argument in both cases in respect of the PEC and the RECAP and therefore reversed the panel’s decision on these incentives.

section.title: Accelerated depreciation
section.p: Under article 324 of the RIR, accelerated rates of depreciation may be established for new fixed assets used in modernization or expansion of certain industries.

Article 323 of the RIR provides for accelerated depreciation for assets in accordance with the amount of hours used per day in the production process. The coefficients are: (i) 1 for 8 hours of operation; (ii) 1.5 for 16 hours of operation; and (iii) 2 for 24 hours of operation. As an example, one industrial machine with a normal depreciation rate of 10% is depreciated at 15% if it operates 16 hours a day, or at a 20% rate if it operates 24 hours a day.

Law 11,196/2005 provides for accelerated depreciation for acquisitions of assets used for technological research and innovation (R&D) and also for acquisitions made between 2006 and 2018 of assets by companies that were granted the incentives of the Superintendency for the Development of the Northeast (Superintendência do Desenvolvimento do Nordeste, SUDENE) and the Superintendency for the Development of the Amazon (Superintendência do Desenvolvimento da Amazônia, SUDAM) (see section 1.9.4.5.). Those assets may be integrally depreciated in the year of acquisition.

Accelerated depreciation was also provided for by Law 11,774/2008 for assets acquired between 2008 and 2010 which are used by companies producing fixed assets. The depreciation rate is four times the normal depreciation rate. This same accelerated depreciation was granted to companies acquiring assets for the production of vehicles and their parts.

Law 12,788/2013 provides for accelerated depreciation for specific assets, acquired or ordered between 30 September and 31 December 2012, to comprise the fixed assets of the taxpayer and to be used in the transportation of cargo and merchandise. Under article 1 of Law 12,788/2013, the depreciation for tax purposes would be calculated based on the general depreciation rate usually adopted for each specific asset multiplied by 3. The eligible assets are the vehicles listed in the Law, including some types of trucks, trains and railway cars.

Law 12,794/2013 provides for accelerated depreciation for specific assets, acquired or ordered between 30 September and 31 December 2012, to comprise the fixed assets of the taxpayer and to be used in its activities. Under article 4 of Law 12,794/2013, the depreciation for tax purposes would be calculated based on the general depreciation rate usually adopted for each specific asset multiplied by 2. The assets may be depreciated until the acquisition cost is reduced to zero. There are 346 eligible assets listed in Decree 7,854/2012, including air generators, steam turbines, air compressors and reservoir tanks.

section.title: Investment deduction
section.p: Investment deduction is granted under specific incentive regimes (see sections 1.9.4.6., 1.9.4.7. and 1.9.4.15.).

section.title: Investment credit
section.p: Investment credit is granted under specific incentive regimes (see sections 1.9.4.5., 1.9.4.14. and 1.9.4.16.).

section.title: Regional investment funds
section.p: By Decree-Law 1,376/1974, the government established the North-East Investment Fund (Fundo de Investimento do Nordeste, FINOR) and the Amazon Investment Fund (Fundo de Investimento da Amazônia, FINAM). These investment funds are primarily funded with a portion of the IRPJ liability of legal entities that made this option, being such funds managed/controlled by special agencies. The amounts deposited in the funds are invested in the purchase of securities issued by companies operating in the relevant regions.

Corporate taxpayers are entitled, after making the proper deposits, to receive securities representing interests in the pertinent fund, which may later be changed into securities belonging to the fund’s portfolio. Profits derived from the investments in the FINAM and FINOR may not be remitted as dividends to foreign investors.

The Brazilian Securities Commission (Comissão de Valores Mobiliários, CVM) controls and regulates companies receiving funds derived from fiscal incentives and regulates the transfer and brokerage of securities issued by such enterprises.

section.title: Assembly operations
section.p: Export Processing Zones (EPZs) are regulated by Law 11,508/2007, as amended by Law 11,732/2008, and Decree 6,814/2009). EPZs are industrial areas where companies therein established enjoy incentives regarding taxes and social contributions on condition that at least 80% of the production is exported.

Companies operating in EPZs are entitled to a temporary deferral of import-related taxes, IPI and the tax on financial transactions (imposto sobre operações financeiras, IOF), the freight surcharge for merchant marine renewal (AFRMM) and social security contributions related to imported or domestic goods and services acquired for use in the production process, under certain conditions. After 2 years, the deferral is converted into an exemption, unless it is proved that the company exported less than 80% of its production or if fixed assets acquired for the use in the production were sold before the 2-year period. In those cases, taxes previously deferred become due with interest and penalties.

When authorizing the establishment of an enterprise, the government may guarantee that the treatment provided under this scheme will last for a maximum period of 20 years, which may be extended for additional periods of 20 years, in the case of major investments that need a long term for amortization.
Brazil currently has 19 EPZs in implementation process in 17 Brazilian states:

item.p: North region: Senador Guiomard (Acre state), Barcarena (Pará state), Porto Velho (Rondônia state), Boa Vista (Roraima state) and Araguaína (Tocantins state);
Northeast region: Ilhéus (Bahia state), Pecém (Ceará state), Suape (Pernambuco state), Parnaíba (Piauí state), Sertão/Assu (Rio Grande do Norte state) and Macaíba (Rio Grande do Norte state);
Middle-west region: Cáceres (Mato Grosso state), Bataguassu (Mato Grosso do Sul state) and Corumbá (Mato Grosso do Sul state);
Southeast region: Aracruz (Espírito Santo state), Teófilo Otoni (Minas Gerais state), Uberaba (Minas Gerais state), Itaguaí (Rio de Janeiro state) and Fernandópolis (São Paulo state); and
South region: Imbituba (Santa Catarina state), Rio Grande (Rio Grande do Sul state).

section.title: Savings and investment plans
section.p: Decree-Law 2,292/1986 authorizes the organization of Savings and Investment Plans (Planos de Poupança e Investimento, PAITs) aimed at promoting the voluntary formation, for the benefit of employees, through portfolio investments, of profit-sharing and savings funds, which are organized by either employees or enterprises.

The plans provide an attractive fringe benefit for employees – especially managers and those at the higher end of the pay scale – and important tax savings for the employer. The plans’ greatest benefits are tax advantages; in addition, a plan may be used as an incentive for employees for sales or performance.

Resources of PAITs organized by enterprises must be used in PAIT investment funds or administered by an authorized institution (bank or brokerage house). Contributions to PAITs organized by enterprises are additionally subject to the following rules:

item.p: contributions made by the enterprise, as well as income derived from their investments, are not treated as salaries for labour and social security purposes; and
contributions made by the enterprise are deductible as business expenses, provided that they are made under general standards and benefit at least 50% of the enterprise’s employees.

section.title: Free economic and trade zones and bonded warehouses
section.p: Based on article 40 of the Transitory Constitutional Provisions, the government has established a free economic zone in Manaus (Zona Franca de Manaus, ZFM) and grants a number of tax advantages to industries operating within such zone and to products manufactured or marketed therein. Under Constitutional Amendment 42/2003, such tax benefits may be effective until 2023 (instead of the limit originally determined by the Transitory Constitutional Provisions, which was 2013). The scheme is governed by Decree-Law 288/1967, regulated by Decree 61,244/1967.

The ZFM is a free economic area for imports and exports established for the purpose of creating an industrial, commercial and agricultural centre within the Amazon Basin. The area of the free economic zone is defined by article 2 of Decree 61,244/1967, its main point of reference being the Port of Manaus, the left banks of the Negro and Amazon rivers, the Urubu river and the Cuieiras river.

Companies established at the ZFM are entitled to an exemption of import tax and IPI for goods imported for certain purposes, such as use in manufacturing other products, re-exportation, internal consumption or the operation of industries and performance of services. Goods used for other purposes than those listed in Decree-Law 288/1967 and Decree 61,244/1967, as well as goods imported through the ZFM for trade outside this zone, are subject to normal taxation. Exported goods are exempt from export duties.

Decree-Law 356/1988 extends the tax incentives granted under Decree-Law 288/1967 to goods received, improved or manufactured in the ZFM for local utilization and consumption in pioneer areas, frontier zones and other places of the West Amazon. The West Amazon consists of the states of Amazonas, Acre, Rondonia and Roraima.
These incentives are not available with respect to weapons and ammunition, perfumes, tobacco, alcoholic beverages and domestic products exported and subsequently imported through the ZFM.
The ZFM area is within the area of SUDAM (i.e. the Amazon region), so that all tax incentives available for the SUDAM area are also available for the ZFM.
Other free trade zones (e.g. Santana Free Trade Zone, Boa Vista Free Trade Zone, etc.) exist, which compose the Amazon Free Trade Zones (Áreas de Livre Comércio da Amazônia).

The applicability of the tax benefits in all free trade zone areas created until 11 August 2014 expires on 31 December 2050. The tax benefits granted within the free economic zone of Manaus expire in 2073.

section.title: Regional development
section.p: The government has used incentive programmes to stimulate development of the less economically developed areas of the country, namely the northeast and amazon regions. Those incentives are commonly known as SUDENE (for the northeast region) and SUDAM (Amazon region) incentives.

Corporate taxpayers with projects of installation, modernization, expansion or diversification of industrial or agricultural enterprises in the SUDENE or SUDAM regions, and approved by 31 December 2023, are subject to: (i) a fixed reduction of 75% of the income tax due for a period of 10 years (for certain business sectors), accelerated depreciation and credits for PIS and COFINS; (ii) exemption of corporate income tax for the period of 10 years for projects investing in the production of items of the digital inclusion program; or (iii) reinvestment of 30% of corporate income tax due in projects for the modernization of equipments.

section.title: Social, cultural and sports development
section.p: Corporate taxpayers may, in addition to the deduction of donations allowed under the RIR, deduct as business expenses the amount of donations and promotional contributions made to cultural and sport projects approved by the Ministry of Culture and by the Ministry of Sports.
The tax benefits granted to donors or contributors in respect of cultural and sport projects are also subject to the limitations of:

item.p: 4% (cultural) and 1% (sports) of the CIT liability in the case of corporate taxpayers taxed under the actual profit regime; and
a lump-sum amount in Brazilian reals for each cultural project and year.

section.p: Eligible investments must have prior approval by the Cultural Promotion Institute (Instituto de Promoção Cultural, ICP) of the Ministry of Culture, or the Ministry of Sport. Cultural projects must be approved by the Secretariat of Culture.

section.title: R&D, REPES, RECAP and PEC
section.p: Law 11,196/2005 introduced several tax incentives, the most important of which are summarized below.
For the WTO report on this incentive, see section 1.9.

topic.title: Incentive for R&D
topic.p: Law 11,196/2005 introduced several tax incentives for R&D, including:

item.p: corporate income tax deduction of R&D expenses;
accelerated depreciation (see section 1.9.1.) and amortization (in certain cases);
a reduction of 50% of the IPI imposed on goods used for R&D proposes;
an exemption from withholding tax on remittances made abroad relating to the registration and maintenance of trademarks, patents and registered plant varieties; and
subventions from 40% to 60% of the remuneration paid to top qualified researchers involved in R&D programmes.

topic.p: In addition, as from 1 January 2006 companies are allowed to exclude from taxable profit (under the actual profit regime) 60% of the expenses incurred on R&D. This exclusion may be increased to up to 80%, depending on the number of employees (researchers) hired by the company and some other conditions.
A special reduction of IPI is granted to IT companies carrying out R&D activities (Law 13,674/2018 – the so-called IT Law incentive (incentivo Lei de Informática), valid until 2029).

topic.title: Incentive for software development and information technology services (REPES)
topic.p: Qualifying entities are those engaged in the development of software and rendering of information technology (IT) services which, upon the request for the tax incentive, commit to export at least 60% of their production or services (based on the total annual gross revenue).
These companies are eligible for a suspension of:

item.p: COFINS and PIS (federal contributions imposed on gross revenues and on the import of goods and services) on:
the import of new capital assets and services designed to develop software and IT services; and
the domestic supply of those capital assets and services to other qualifying entities;
PIS and COFINS, which are suspended for a period varying between 3 to 4 years and thereafter converted into a 0% rate; and
IPI on the import of capital goods without an equivalent in the Brazilian market for a period varying between 3 to 4 years and thereafter converted into an exemption.

topic.title: Incentive for acquisitions of capital goods by export companies (RECAP)
topic.p: Qualifying entities are those primarily engaged in export transactions, defined by law as a legal entity with at least 70% of its gross revenue in the preceding tax year originating from export transactions and which commits to maintain this level of exports for the subsequent 2 years.
Qualifying entities are eligible for a suspension of COFINS and PIS on:

item.p: the import of new machinery, equipment and other listed instruments; and
the domestic supply of such goods to other qualifying entities.

topic.p: PIS and COFINS are suspended for a period varying between 2 to 6 years and thereafter converted into a 0% rate, if conditions are fulfilled.

topic.title: Incentive for acquisition of inputs, intermediary products and packaging by export companies (PEC)
topic.p: Under this incentive, companies deriving more than 70% of their revenue from exports benefit from the suspension of PIS and COFINS on the acquisition of inputs, intermediary products and packaging – although article 40 of Law 10,865/2004 stipulates the threshold of 50% for qualification for the regime, Private Ruling 99003/2019 clarified that the threshold in Normative Instruction 595/2005 (i.e. 70%) is the one applicable.

section.title: Tax incentives introduced by the Growth Acceleration Programme
section.p: The federal government announced a package of measures to foster accelerated growth of the Brazilian economy. This package, named the Growth Acceleration Programme (Programa de Aceleração do Crescimento, PAC), provided for public and private investments, including tax incentives.

PAC offered a set of measures intended to foster credit and funding activities, lower taxes for specific segments, aiming at generally improving the environment for investments in strategic sectors. These strategic sectors comprise, among others, the manufacturers of semiconductors and equipment for digital television sets, by creating special support programmes directed at the development of such activities in Brazil.

Law 11,484/2007 introduced the PADIS and the PATVD. Both programmes seek to encourage the set-up, in Brazil, of companies engaged in the development and manufacture of semiconductors, displays and radio signal transmission equipment for digital television. To that end, a number of tax reduction measures were adopted, as outlined below:

item.p: PADIS (valid until 31 December 2026):

a legal entity qualifying for PADIS may import or acquire in the domestic market capital goods and inputs at a 0% rate with regard to the following taxes and contributions: PISPIS, COFINS; PISPIS on imports; COFINS on imports; and IPI. In addition, overseas remittances of royalties for technology may be made at a 0% rate for the Contribution for the Intervention in the Economic Domain (Contribuição de Intervenção no Domínio Econômico, CIDE);

a legal entity qualifying for PADIS is taxed at a zero rate for PISPIS and COFINS contributions on its revenues, as well as for the IPI tax levied on its industrial output, with the possibility of reducing by 100% the IRPJ calculated based on the exploitation profit; and
tax reductions under PADIS are expected to last for 15 years. The reduction in the income tax rate will be valid for 12 or 16 years, depending on the level of value added by the company.
PATVD:

a legal entity qualifying for PATVD may import (or acquire in the domestic market) capital goods and inputs at a 0% rate with regard to the following taxes and contributions: PIS; COFINS; PIS and COFINS on imports; and IPI. In addition, overseas remittances of royalties for technology may be made at a 0% rate for CIDE; and
a legal entity qualifying for PATVD is taxed at a 0% rate for PIS and COFINS contributions on its revenues, as well as for the IPI tax levied on its industrial output.

section.p: For the WTO report on this incentive, see section 1.9.

section.title: Special Regime for Incentives to the Development of the Oil Industry’s Infrastructure in the North, Northeast and Middle-west Regions (Regime Especial de Incentivos para o Desenvolvimento de Infraestrutura da Indústria Petrolífera nas Regiões Norte, Nordeste e Centro-Oeste, REPENEC)
section.p: Law 12,249/2010 created a special regime for the development of the oil and gas industry in the North, Northeast and Middle-west regions (REPENEC). The incentive is granted to legal entities established in those regions and that are engaged in projects related to the petrochemical industry, oil refinement and production of ammonia and urea from natural gas, provided that such projects are approved by the Ministry of Mines and Energy.

Beneficiary legal entities are granted a suspension of the imposition of import tax (II), IPI, PIS and COFINS in case of local purchases or import of new machinery, equipment, instruments and materials to be used or applied in the infrastructure works that will be later incorporated to the taxpayer’s fixed assets. Suspension will then be converted into a 0% rate.
This incentive is granted for 5 years.

section.title: Special Regime for the Aeronautical Industry (Regime Especial para a Indústria Aeronáutica Brasileira, RETAERO)
section.p: Law 12,249/2010 also created a special tax incentive to the Brazilian aviation industry (RETAERO). It focuses on legal entities that produce equipment, systems, parts, raw material and inputs applied to the maintenance, repair, conservation, modernization or industrialization of certain airplanes, under certain conditions.
Benefits also apply to legal entities that provide certain services to RETAERO beneficiaries.
Benefits include:

item.p: suspension of IPI, PIS and COFINS on the domestic purchase and importation of services and goods for both beneficiaries of the regime and companies that provide services to such beneficiaries;
suspension of IPI, PIS and COFINS on the rental of equipment and machines by the beneficiaries of the regime.

section.p: Suspension is converted into a 0% rate after the building in or utilization of the goods and/or their exportation. Qualification for the regime may be granted for 5 years.

section.title: Special Regime for the Development of Infrastructure (Regime Especial de Incentivos para o Desenvolvimento de Infra-Estrutura, REIDI)
section.p: The REIDI, created by Law 11,488/2007, was created in order to incentivize the development of the Brazilian infrastructure. The incentive is granted to legal entities that have an approved project related to infrastructure in the fields of transportation, ports, energy, basic sanitation and irrigation.

The benefit is basically related to the suspension of PIS and COFINS on the domestic purchase and importation of goods destined to the fixed asset of the importer or of goods to be built in in the construction of assets and services related thereto that will comprise the fixed assets of the beneficiary of the regime in the scope of the infrastructure project. Private Ruling 28/2019 clarified that the suspension of PIS and COFINS does not apply to acquisitions made by entities qualifying under this special regime if the goods or services acquired were sold or provided by an entity which is under the simplified regime (Simples Nacional).

The suspension is converted into a 0% rate after the building in or utilization of the goods and/or their exportation. The regime is available for a 5-year term counted from the agreement for the acquisition of the good or service.

section.title: Special Tax Regime for the Defence Industry (Regime Especial Tributário para a Indústria de Defesa, RETID)
section.p: The RETID, established by Law 12,598/2012, grants several tax benefits to qualifying legal entities engaged in activities deemed to be of strategic interest for the national defence, which include the research, projecting, development, manufacturing of items considered as defence products and strategic defence products.
To qualify for the RETID, legal entities must meet the following requirements:

item.p: have their headquarters, place of management and industrial establishment in Brazil;
have know-how, in Brazil, for carrying out technical and scientific research, development of technology, product or process related to the defence activity;
assure that the voting power of foreign shareholders does not exceed two thirds of the total votes exercised by Brazilian shareholders;

be engaged in (a) the production of national defence products, as defined by the executive branch, or be engaged in the rendering of services related to the maintenance, conservation, repair and industrialization of such national defence products; (b) be engaged in the production of parts, pieces, tools, components, equipment, systems, inputs and raw materials to be applied to the production of national defence products; or (c) be engaged in the rendering of services related to basic industrial technology, projects, research, development, technology innovation, technical assistance and transfer of technology to be applied as inputs in the production and development of the products listed under (a) and (b).

section.p: Benefits include:

item.p: suspension of the PIS, COFINS and IPI on the local acquisition of goods to be applied to activities listed above;
suspension of the PIS, COFINS and IPI on the import of goods to be applied to the activities listed above;
suspension of the PIS and COFINS on the local rendering of services to be applied to the activities above;
suspension of the PIS and COFINS on the import of services to be applied to the activities above

section.p: The suspension of taxes and contributions is converted into a 0% rate once all of the conditions for the fruition of the regime, as outlined by Law 12,598/2012, are fulfilled.
The regime is available until 22 March 2032.

section.title: Special Tax Regime for the Development of Cinematographic Exhibition Activities (Regime Especial de Tributação para Desenvolvimento da Atividade de Exibição Cinematográfica, RECINE)
section.p: The RECINE, introduced by Law 12,599/2012, was introduced to foster the construction of movie theatres in less developed regions as well as in popular neighbourhoods of major cities. The regime was initially available until 31 December 2019 but it was later extended to 31 December 2024.

The beneficiaries of the RECINE are legal entities that have cinematographic exhibition projects approved by the Brazilian National Cinema Agency (Agência Nacional de Cinema, ANCINE), involving the implementation or operation of cinemas or the lease of equipment to exhibition rooms, and have no debts before the Brazilian Revenue Service.

Benefits are related to the domestic acquisition and import of new machinery, devices, instruments and equipment, destined to the beneficiaries’ fixed assets, and materials to be used as inputs in the construction of movie theatre complexes, including:

item.p: suspension of PIS and COFINS on the domestic acquisitions and import transactions;
suspension of IPI on domestic acquisitions and import transactions; and
suspension of II on import transactions, in relation to the goods or materials destined to the construction and cannot be replaced by a similar product manufactured in Brazil.

section.p: The above-mentioned suspensions are converted into exemptions with respect to the II and IPI and a 0% rate in relation to the PIS and COFINS, provided that all conditions of the regime are complied with. The tax benefits are granted for 5 years.
For the purpose of assessing the taxable base for income tax, entities may also deduct the amounts:

item.p: invested in the production or sponsoring of Brazilian audio-visual works, provided that certain conditions were met; and
used to purchase quotas in Funds for the Financing of National Cinematographic Industry (Fundos de Financiamento da Indústria Cinematográfica Nacional, FUNCINES).

section.title: Tax incentive for the coffee industry
section.p: Law 12,599/2012 brought some tax incentives addressed to the production of coffee in Brazil.
The tax incentive is granted to any entity engaged in the production of coffee (regardless of having a specific project) and comprises:

item.p: suspension of the PIS and COFINS due on gross revenues arising from the sale of coffee beans, provided that such sales are not destined to final consumers;

granting of presumed credits of the PIS and COFINS to the legal entities that are subject to the non-cumulative regime of said contributions (see sections 2.3.2. and 2.3.3.), as follows: (a) 0.925% on the gross revenues from the coffee export and (b) 1.32% on the acquisition cost of coffee that is applied to the production of roasted beans, scents and extracts of coffee.

section.title: Greater Brazil Plan (Plano Brasil Maior)
section.p: On August 2011, and in the context of the global crisis that also had effects on the Brazilian economy, the Brazilian government launched the Greater Brazil Plan (Plano Brasil Maior), which would guide some of the industrial, technological and foreign trade policies of the country in the coming years. As it was widely stated by the government, the intention of the plan was to sustain the growth of the Brazilian economy in the context of the unfavourable global scenario, in order to allow Brazil to exit the global crisis in a better position than it had entered.

In this scenario, besides several economic measures, the Greater Brazil Plan introduced several tax benefits, aiming at providing tax relief to specific business sectors deemed as key to the Brazilian economy and also to foster the consumption power of the citizens, so that more resources would circulate in the economy.

Among the tax benefits, originally introduced by Law 12,456/2011, it is valid to mention: (i) reduction of IPI rates for the automotive industry, (ii) granting of presumed PIS and COFINS credits for the biodiesel industry, (iii) allowance of increased deductions in relation to certain R&D activities, (iv) replacement of the 20% social security contribution due by the Employers over the payroll by a social contribution on gross revenues in relation to some specific business sectors and (v) the special tax refund regime for exporting companies (Regime Especial de Reintegração de Valores Tributários para as Empresas Exportadoras, REINTEGRA).

section.title: Special tax refund regime for exporting companies (REINTEGRA)
section.p: The REINTEGRA regime introduced by Law 12,456/2011 expired in 2013. However, it was re-introduced by Law 13,043/2014. Under the REINTEGRA, exporters of manufactured goods are entitled to a tax refund calculated as a percentage (varying from 0.1% to 3%) on the exports gross income. An additional two percentage points may be granted to the export of goods meeting certain requirements. The refund may either be used for (i) the payment of federal tax or contributions debts or liabilities, or (ii) paid in cash under conditions established by the tax administration.
Currently, according to Decree 9,393/2018, the percentage of the tax refund is set at 0.1% for an indefinite period (previously, the percentage of 2% applied).:
The tax credit under the REINTEGRA regime is granted under the condition that the exported goods are:

item.p: manufactured in Brazil with the use of imported inputs whose costs do not exceed a percentage of the export price to be indicated by the Ministry of Finance; and
listed in the federal tax on manufactured products table (Tabela de Imposto sobre Produtos Industrializados, TIPI) and in the ordinance to be published by the Ministry of Finance.

section.p: The tax refund received by exporters of manufactured goods is excluded from the taxable base of the listed taxes and contributions.
The new REINTEGRA regime has no expiration date.

section.title: Special customs regimes for the oil and gas industry

topic.title: REPETRO
topic.p: Provided that certain conditions are met, the temporary importation of equipment used for the exploration and exploitation of oil and natural gas may be subject to a special customs regime for the suspension of customs duty, taxes and contribution (Regime Aduaneiro Especial de Exportação e Importação de Bens Destinados às Atividades de Pesquisa e Lavra de Jazidas de Petróleo e Gás Natural, REPETRO). This incentive is in the process of phasing out in view of the introduction of a new incentive regime (see below). As a result, and according to Normative Instruction 1,796/2018, applications for joining the REPETRO regime may be submitted until 31 December 2018. The REPETRO regime granted under the rules in force until the publication of Normative Instruction 1,781/2017 (i.e. 2 January 2018) is valid for the period agreed for the regime by the tax authorities. For goods imported and applications presented after this period, but no later than 31 December 2018, the REPETRO regime granted will apply until 31 December 2020. Applications presented after 31 December 2018 will be granted under the new regime (see below). Goods admitted under the REPETRO regime until 31 December 2018 may also migrate to the new regime (see below).

topic.title: REPETRO-SPED
topic.p: Law 13,586/2017, published in the DOU of 29 December 2017, implemented a new special customs regime for the economic use of goods in the exploration and exploitation of oil and natural gas (Regime aduaneiro especial de utilização econômica destinado a bens a serem utilizados nas atividades de exploração, desenvolvimento e produção das jazidas de petróleo e de gás natural, REPETRO-SPED). Normative Instruction 1,796/2018, published in the DOU of 5 March 2018, amends the regulations on the new special customs regime and introduces transitory rules from the former special customs regime (REPETRO). Under the regime, customs duty, taxes and contribution are suspended and then converted into an exemption after 5 years. The benefit also applies to the importation and acquisition in the internal market of raw materials, intermediary products and packaging material used in the production process.
The REPETRO-SPED regime may be granted under the modalities of:

item.p: exportation with no goods effectively exiting the country;
importation on a temporary basis for the economic use of the goods;
importation on a permanent basis; and
importation and internal acquisition of raw, intermediary and packaging material to be used entirely in the production process.

topic.p: The REPETRO-SPED regime is valid until 31 December 2040.

topic.title: REPETRO-Industrialization
topic.p: Decree 9,537/2018 implemented the special regime for the industrialization of goods used for the exploration, production and exploitation of oil, natural gas and other fluid hydrocarbons (REPETRO-Industrialization).

The regime applies to companies importing or purchasing in the internal market raw materials, intermediary products and packaging materials to be used in the industrialization process of goods used for the exploration, production and exploitation of oil, natural gas and other fluid hydrocarbons. Under this regime, the levy of IPI, PIS and COFINS is suspended for a period of 1 year (extendable to up to 5 years).

After the full use of the good for the purpose required by the law (i.e. exploration, production and exploitation of oil, natural gas and other fluid hydrocarbons), the suspension is converted into exemption or zero rating.
The regime is valid until 31 December 2040.

section.title: Drawback regime
section.p: Article 12 of Law 11,945/2009 provides for a drawback regime, under which import duty, IPI, PIS and COFINS normally levied on the import or purchase of goods in the internal market are suspended, provided that the said goods are used or consumed in the manufacturing of products to be exported. The regime is granted for the period of 1 year, which may be extended for another year (longer periods may be granted for certain products requiring longer period of production). The suspension of taxes is converted into exemption upon the actual export of the products.
In view of the COVID-19 pandemic, the drawback regime term’s ending in 2021 was extended by 1 year (Provisional Measure 1,079/2021).

section.title: Special customs regimes of industrial warehouse
section.p: Normative Instructions 1,291/2012 and 1,612/2016 provide for the Special Customs Regimes of Industrial Warehouse under Computerized Control (Regime Aduaneiro Especial de Entreposto Industrial sob Controle Informatizado - Recof) and under Computerized Control of the Public Digital Bookkeeping System (Regime Aduaneiro Especial de Entreposto Industrial sob Controle Informatizado do Sistema Público de Escrituração Digital - Recof-Sped). Under these regimes, beneficiaries may import or buy in the domestic market, with the suspension of payment of taxes, goods to be industrialized for export or sales in the domestic market. To remain a beneficiary of the regimes, companies must export industrialized products at the minimum annual amount equivalent to 50% of the total amount of the goods admitted to the regime. In addition, they must use, during the industrialization process, at least 70% of admitted goods annually. The regime is granted for the period of 1 year, which may be extended for another year (longer periods may be granted for certain products requiring longer period of production).

section.title: Income
section.p: The following rates apply:

item.p: IRPJ: 15%;
IRPJ surtax: 10% (on yearly taxable profit exceeding BRL 240,000); and

CSLL: 9% (for banks: 20% from 1 January 2022 (a 21% rate applies, however, between 1 August 2022 and 31 December 2022); for private insurance companies, capitalization companies, leasing companies, credit card administrators and credit cooperatives: 15% from 1 January 2022 (a 16% rate applies, however, between 1 August 2022 and 31 December 2022)).

section.p: Therefore, it is common to say that CIT is imposed at a maximum aggregate rate of 34% (for non-financial companies).

In view of the COVID-19 pandemic, a zero IRPJ and CSLL rate applies for entities under the emergency programme for the recovery of the events sector (Programa Emergencial de Retomada do Setor de Eventos) (Law 14,148/2021 and Ordinance 7,163/2021).

Under Bill 2337/2021, the reduction of the corporate income tax rates is being considered by the National Congress as follows: the standard IRPJ rate from 15% to 8% and the CSLL rate (gradually and conditioned to the removal of certain tax incentives) from (i) 9% to 8% in general, (ii) 20% to 19% for banks and (iii) 15% to 14% for other financial institutions, which reduces the aggregate rate from 34% to 26% (the 10% surtax for larger companies would remain unchanged).

Under article 3 of Law 9,249/1995, the IRPJ is charged at a flat rate of 15%. However, under article 3(1) of Law 9,249/1995, as amended, all resident legal entities are subject to the IRPJ surtax at a flat rate of 10% on taxable profit exceeding the amount resulting from multiplying BRL 20,000 by the number of months of the relevant assessment period. Thus, for corporate taxpayers which have opted to pay income tax quarterly, the surtax applies on quarterly taxable profit exceeding BRL 60,000. Taxpayers which chose to assess their income tax annually and make monthly income tax payments are subject to the surtax on annual taxable profit exceeding BRL 240,000 and must make monthly payments on taxable profit exceeding BRL 20,000 a month. This surtax applies to all resident companies (including financial institutions) and farming enterprises.
