section.title: Capital gains
section.p: Capital gains arising from the sale of assets or rights registered as the company’s permanent assets are included in the taxable base for CIT purposes, therefore subject to the IRPJ at a 15% rate (and to the IRPJ surtax at a 10% rate, on gains exceeding BRL 240,000 per year) and the CSLL at the 9% rate (for financial institutions: 15% until 29 February 2020 and 20% as of 1 March 2020). With effect from 1 January 2017, small and medium-sized businesses, including those under the Simples Nacional regime, are subject to progressive rates ranging from 15% to 22.5%.

Net gains, which are the gains derived in connection with the disposal of portfolio investments, are also included in the taxable base for CIT purposes. However, in some situations, the disposal of portfolio investments is subject to withholding income tax (see section 1.10.3.).

section.title: Dividends
section.p: Under article 10 of Law 9,249/1995, dividends paid out of after-tax profits are not subject to withholding income tax – however, the taxation of dividends at source at the rate of 15% is being considered by the National Congress under Bill 2337/2021.

section.title: Interest
section.p: The tax treatment, for withholding income tax purposes, of interest received by corporate taxpayers depends on the nature of the interest.

The payment of JCP (see section 1.4.5.) is subject to withholding income tax, which is imposed at a 15% rate (Provisional Measure 694/2015, which proposed an increase of the rate from 15% to 18% with effect from 1 January 2017, was revoked on 10 March 2016) in connection with payments made to local shareholders and to foreign shareholders not located in low-tax jurisdictions (JTFs, see section 10.6.). JCP payments to shareholders located in JTFs are subject to withholding income tax at a 25% rate.

Interest received from other legal entities in view of credit transactions (loans and any other type of financing) is taxed as fixed income from financial investment, therefore subject to withholding tax at regressive rates, from 22.5% to 15%, depending on the lifetime of the transaction, as follows:
In all cases, the withholding income tax is creditable against the final IRPJ.

section.title: Royalties
section.p: There is no withholding tax on the payment of royalties to Brazilian legal entities. There is also no imposition of VAT.

topic.title: Service fees paid to residents
topic.p: As a rule, service fees received by Brazilian legal entities are treated as ordinary taxable income and subject to CIT accordingly.
However, with regard to some listed services, as provided by articles 718 and 719 of the RIR, payment of the fees are subject to withholding income tax at a 1.5% rate:

item.p: commissions, broker’s fees or intermediation of any civil or commercial transactions;
advertisement and publicity service fees. Amounts directly paid to radio, television, newspaper and magazine enterprises are not included in the taxable base for withholding tax purposes; and
fees paid to professional associations or cooperatives.

topic.p: Under article 716 of the RIR, fees for cleaning or security services are subject to the withholding tax at a 1% rate.

Fees for assistance on credit and market evaluation, credit management, evaluation of risks and management of payables and receivables are also subject to the 1.5% withholding tax. The withholding tax is creditable against the final IRPJ liability.

topic.title: Fees paid to professional companies
topic.p: Fees paid by a legal entity to another legal entity (e.g. civil company) as consideration for professional services (e.g. legal, auditing, consulting, architecture) are subject to withholding income tax at a 1.5% rate. The withholding income tax is creditable against the final IRPJ liability.

If the recipient of the fees is a civil company which is directly or indirectly controlled by individuals who are directors, managers or controlling shareholders of the paying entity, the withholding tax is calculated at the progressive rates shown in Individual Taxation section 1.10. Services rendered by exempt legal entities are not subject to this withholding tax.

In addition, Law 10,833/2003 provides a list of services which are subject to withholding of CSLL, PIS and COFINS, at the aggregate rate of 4.65%, corresponding to 1% for CSLL, 0.5% for PIS and 3% for COFINS. The amounts withheld are creditable against the final liability with regard to those impositions.

topic.title: Financial investments
topic.p: The rates of withholding income tax on income and net gains arising from financial investments made by Brazilian legal entities vary in accordance with the nature of the investment. In all cases, income arising from financial investments must be considered in the taxable base of the CIT, and the withholding income tax may be credited against the final IRPJ liability.
Normative Instruction 1,720/2017, published in the DOU of 24 July 2017, regulates the taxation of income and net gains from financial and capital markets.

topic.title: Fixed-income investments
topic.p: Income arising from fixed-income investments is subject to withholding income tax at regressive rates, depending on the lifetime of the investment.
The rates above are applicable to all kinds of fixed income investments. However, some specifics apply to fixed-income investment funds.

Additionally, Law 12,431/2011 introduced a special kind of debenture that may be issued by special purpose vehicles in specific situations outlined in article 2 of said law. Generally speaking, such debentures must be issued in view of specific infrastructure projects to be developed by the issuer and must comply with some requirements provided for in article 1 of Law 12,431/2011 (such as having a minimum average term greater than 4 years, pre-established interest rate, minimum term between interest payments of 180 days).

If the conditions are met, income arising from the investment in the debentures has a different tax treatment. In this case, the payments will be subject to withholding income tax at a 15% rate as final taxation with regard to the IRPJ (i.e. it is not subject to the regressive rates and such income should not be included in the taxable base of the IRPJ).

Nevertheless, as the law did not mention the CSLL, the income received should be considered in the taxable base of the CSLL to be subject to a 9% rate (for financial institutions: 15% until 29 February 2020 and 20% as of 1 March 2020).
Therefore, investment in the qualifying debentures provides for a tax benefit related to the non-imposition of the IRPJ surtax.

topic.title: Fixed-income investment funds
topic.p: The withholding income tax imposed on income arising out of the redemption of quotas of fixed-income investment funds depends on the classification of the fund as a short-term investment fund or a long-term investment fund.

For long-term investment funds, classified by the tax laws as those with a portfolio composed of fixed-income assets with an average redemption term exceeding 365 days, the withholding income tax is imposed based on regressive rates (22.5% to 15%), according to the lifetime of the transaction (same tax treatment of general fixed income investments).

Short-term investment funds, classified by the tax laws as those with portfolio composed of fixed-income assets with an average redemption term shorter than 365 days, are subject to the withholding income tax at regressive rates from 22.5% to 20%, according to the lifetime of the transaction. For transactions of 6 months or less, a 22.5% rate applies. For transactions of more than 6 months, a 20% rate applies.

Notwithstanding the imposition of the withholding income tax on the redemption of quotas, Brazilian tax laws also impose a half-year tax, regardless of effective distributions by the fund. Historically, investors in open-ended funds are subject to the automatic assessment of withholding tax on a semi-annual basis (on the last day of May and November – the so-called come quotas) at the rates of 15% or 20% (depending on the classification of the portfolio of the fund) and regardless of the actual distribution of cash from the fund to the investor. On the other hand, investors in closed-end funds were generally subject to the assessment of withholding tax only upon the redemption, amortization or disposition of the quotas of the fund.

Upon redemption of the quotas of investment funds, the complementary withholding income tax is applied (in order to reach the regressive rates in view of the lifetime of the investment). The chart below summarizes the effects of the withholding income tax in those cases.

topic.title: Share funds
topic.p: Income arising from share funds and other variable income investment funds, such as a private equity fund, are subject to the withholding income tax at a 15% rate, at the time of redemption of the quotas, provided that the requirements established by Brazilian tax law, and the regulations of the CVM, are met.

As a general rule, an investment fund (mutual investment funds and investment clubs, amongst others) the portfolio of which is composed for at least 67% of shares of publicly held companies and other securities is regarded as a share fund and taxed at a 15% rate.
With regard to private equity funds, the regulations of the CVM currently require that at least 90% of the portfolio of the fund be invested in shares and other securities.
If the requirements of the tax law and the CVM are not met, the tax treatment of the fund is the same as that of regular fixed-income funds.
Share funds are not subject to the half-year withholding income tax.

topic.title: Real estate investment funds
topic.p: Income arising from investment in real estate investment funds is subject to withholding income tax at a 20% rate.
Under the regulations issued by the CVM, real estate investment funds are required to distribute at least 95% of their profits on 30 June and 31 December of every year.

topic.title: Portfolio transactions performed on the stock exchange market and the organized over-the counter market
topic.p: Gains arising out of the disposal of investments on the stock exchange and the organized over-the-counter market are treated as net gains by Brazilian tax laws and added to the CIT taxable base.

However, disposal of the investments is subject to a withholding income tax, which is imposed at a Brazilian Revenue Service 0.005% rate. The intention of such withholding income tax is to allow Brazilian tax authorities to better inspect the transactions performed on the stock exchange and the organized over-the-counter market, considering that the net gains arising from such transactions are fully subject to self-collection mechanisms.

The taxable base for the imposition of the 0.005% withholding income tax varies in accordance with the market on which the transaction was performed (i.e. spot market, futures market, forward contracts, etc.), as follows:

item.p: in futures markets, tax is imposed on the positive algebraic sum of the mark-to-market values at the closing of the position, whether prematurely or upon maturity;
in the options markets, the results (if positive) of the algebraic sum of the premiums paid and received on the same day;

in forward contracts: (1) when there is a physical delivery of the asset, the positive difference between the forward price and the spot price on the transaction date, and (2) if there is only financial settlement of the asset, the financial settlement value provided for in the contract; and
in the spot market, the selling value of the traded asset.

topic.p: The 0.005% withholding income tax is also creditable against the final CIT liability.

topic.title: Payments to unidentified recipients
topic.p: A withholding tax rate of 35% applies to payments made to unidentified recipients or payments without a justified cause, as well as in cases where the taxpayer does not prove that the transaction effectively occurred (article 61 of Law 8,981/1995).

section.title: Tax returns
section.p: Brazil uses the self-assessment system under which all companies must file a tax return and declare their own tax liability. Legal entities must electronically file the Digital Tax Bookkeeping (Escrituração Contábil Digital, ECD) and the Fiscal Tax Bookkeeping (Escrituração Contábil Fiscal, ECF) by the last working days of May and July of the year following the taxable year (in view of the COVID-19 pandemic, the deadlines for 2022 have been postponed to the last business days of June and August, respectively).

Legal entities adopting the Simples Nacional regime for the collection of taxes (see section 1.2.1.) and inactive entities may submit a simplified tax return. Charitable institutions and non-profit organizations, even though exempt from income tax, must also file the annual tax return.

Companies applying the actual profit regime may elect to adopt a quarterly taxable period or elect to compute taxable profit on an annual basis with monthly payments of an estimated CIT calculated on their turnover. Under both options, entities must also report their results annually and file an annual tax return.
Agents of non-resident entities must file a separate declaration for the profit earned in Brazil on behalf of their principal.
Returns are also required from entities upon termination of their activities and the execution of merger or spin-off transactions.

On 1 October 2012, tax authorities introduced the Alert Program (Programa Alerta) allowing taxpayers the possibility to amend filing mistakes in the tax returns and tax ascertainment before a tax inspection is started.

Tax authorities are willing to inform, prior to establishing a tax inspection, the inconsistencies found upon the data crossing performed by the tax authorities’ electronic systems. The existence of conflicts between the amount informed in the tax return and the one obtained by the tax authorities controls will be promptly informed to taxpayers with the procedures on how to amend/review their declarations.
Initially, three transaction groups were elected to the Alert Program:

item.p: revenue from sales to the federal administration;
inconsistencies related to liquor and beverage business sector; and
exempt entities (charity entities).

section.p: Tax authorities expect to encourage taxpayers to review the tax declarations, and in case of inconsistencies, to promote the self-amendment of the amount informed in order to avoid inspections and possible litigation procedure. The amended tax return does not trigger penalties and can be performed until a tax inspection is formally initialized.

Corporate taxpayers are required to keep their tax books and other supporting documents of the transactions performed for the time of the statute of limitations of the corresponding obligations. The statute of limitations under Brazilian tax laws is 5 years.

Companies must also report their foreign trade transaction in specific systems controlled and monitored by tax authorities. In this sense, transactions involving the export and import of goods must be informed in the Foreign Trade Integrated System (Sistema Integrado de Comércio Exterior, SISCOMEX), which is currently regulated by Normative Instruction 1,288/2012. The SISCOMEX is a tool used by Brazilian tax authorities to inspect foreign trade transactions and the collection of taxes arising from those transactions.

An electronic system existed for the registration of cross-border transactions with services, intangibles and other situations that may have impacts to the equity of Brazilian taxpayers (such as lease agreements and other types of transactions) – the Integrated System for the foreign trade of services, intangibles and other transactions that have impacts to one’s equity (Sistema Integrado de Comércio Exterior de Serviços, Intangíveis e Outras Operações que Produzam Variações no Patrimônio, SISCOSERV). However, on 17 August 2020, the Ministry of Finance and the tax authorities announced that, in order to reduce ancillary obligations and the tax compliance burden for taxpayers, the SISCOSERV would be shut down. On 21 October 2020, SISCOSERV was officially abolished through Ordinance 22,091/2020.
The penalty for failure to attend a request for information issued by the tax authority within the deadlines provided in the request is BRL 500 per month.

The penalty for failure to provide accurate and complete information is 3% on the commercial or financial transactions related to the legal entity or to third persons for which the legal entity is responsible for tax purposes. The corresponding amount cannot be lower than BRL 100.

topic.title: Regular assessment
topic.p: As a rule, CIT is subject to self-assessment by taxpayers.

topic.title: Official assessments
topic.p: The tax administration is entitled to make an official assessment of the CIT if:

item.p: the taxpayer does not file an income tax return;

the taxpayer fails to provide the information or clarifications as required by the tax administration upon tax inspection procedures or if the information or clarifications provided are not satisfactory; or
the taxpayer’s return is not accurate.

topic.p: Additionally, if the legal entity fails to collect the CIT due (including amounts due in anticipation of the tax under the annual actual profit regime), the tax administration may issue a tax assessment.

In view of the COVID-19 pandemic, the tax authorities have been periodically suspending notifications and certain procedural mechanisms for enforcement of administrative collection of federal taxes. The measure also includes the suspension of exclusion of taxpayers from instalment regimes or the registry of non-compliance of requirements for purposes of tax registration

topic.title: Arbitrated profit regime
topic.p: The arbitrated profit is not an optional regime and it is generally applied by tax authorities upon the issuance of a tax assessment when:

item.p: the taxpayer fails to maintain commercial and tax records in accordance with applicable laws;

the taxpayer’s bookkeeping evidences fraud, defects or errors which make it impossible to verify the actual transactions undertaken or to determine the CIT due and payable by the taxpayer based on the actual profit; or
the taxpayer inappropriately opts to calculate and pay CIT under the presumed profit regime.

topic.p: Under the arbitrated profit regime, the taxable base is calculated by applying percentages specified by the tax laws to the gross income derived by the company. These percentages may range from 1.92% to 45%, depending on the business activity of the taxpayer. The general CIT rates apply to the arbitrated profit.

topic.title: Administrative level
topic.p: Taxpayers may challenge a tax administration’s assessment by filing a written appeal with the local office of the tax administration within a 30-day period from the official acknowledgement of issuance of the tax assessment. The taxpayer’s appeal is decided at the first level by the head of the subregional judgement office (Delegado de Julgamento da Receita Federal do Brasil). The appeals from financial institutions and equivalent entities are decided at the first level by the head of the Special Office of Financial Institutions (Delegado Especial das Instituições Financeiras).

The taxpayer may challenge the decision of the head of the tax administration within a 30-day period of its formal acknowledgment by filing a voluntary appeal with the administrative court of tax appeals (Conselho Administrativo de Recursos Fiscais). The administrative tax court is an administrative independent body composed of public officials (members of the tax administration) appointed by the Ministry of Finance and citizens, representing the taxpayer, which are appointed by private associations.

Decisions of the administrative court of tax appeals may be appealed against within 5 days in the case of a motion for clarification (embargos de declaração) or 15 days for a special appeal (recurso especial), to the High Administrative Tax Court (Câmara Superior de Recursos Fiscais), which is composed of the presidents and vice-presidents of the chambers of the administrative court of tax appeals. An appeal is permitted if the decision was based on an interpretation of tax law other than that given by one of the chambers of the administrative tax court or by the High Administrative Tax Court.

If the taxpayer is successful in the discussion with tax authorities at the administrative level, the tax assessment is cancelled and no further actions may be pursued by the tax authorities with regard to that matter.

Regarding tax treaties, Normative Instruction 1,846/2018, published in the DOU of 29 November 2018, regulates the implementation of the mutual agreement procedure (MAP) of tax treaties in the context of Action 14 of the Action Plan on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (AP-BEPS). Accordingly, the procedure may be (i) unilateral, when Brazilian tax authorities are able to conclude the procedure after reviewing the subject or (ii) bilateral, when Brazilian tax authorities contact the competent authority of the treaty partner in order to find a solution for the case.

topic.title: Judicial remedies
topic.p: If the final decision at the administrative level is not favourable to the taxpayer, it may challenge the assessment by filing a lawsuit before the ordinary judicial courts (i.e. the federal courts in the case of federal taxes and the state courts with respect to taxes imposed by the states or municipalities).

There are different kinds of lawsuits which are applicable to specific situations. Generally speaking, with regard to discussions before judicial courts, there are also two levels of trial. After that, in some specific situations, as provided for in the Federal Constitution, the taxpayer may appeal to the STF and to the Superior Court of Justice (Superior Tribunal de Justiça, STJ).

topic.title: Payment of tax
topic.p: The payment of tax depends on the regime adopted by the taxpayer for the collection of CIT (i.e. actual profit regime or presumed profit regime; see section 1.2.1.).
Legal entities subject to CIT under the actual profit regime may choose to assess and pay the CIT on either a quarterly basis or an annual basis.

With regard to the assessment on a quarterly basis, the actual profit subject to CIT considers all transactions performed within the quarter, and the end of each quarter is viewed as the end of the assessment period. The CIT rates are than applied to said taxable base, and the payment of CIT must be made by the last working day of the month following the quarterly period.

If the annual basis is elected, the taxable base is calculated by applying a given percentage (which varies, depending on the activity of the company) on the monthly gross income, including capital gains and any other income, except the income already taxed (the percentages range from 8% to 32%, depending on the legal entity’s activity). The CIT rates are then fully applied to said base. The tax must be paid monthly by the last working day of the month following the assessment. The CIT collected is treated as an advance payment and may be credited against the final CIT liability to be assessed on 31 December (when the taxable event is really deemed to occur). During the year, if the taxpayer believed that it is collecting more CIT based on the estimate than if the actual profit were considered, it may stop the collection of the estimate based on a reduction or suspension balance sheet. In this situation, an intermediary balance sheet is prepared by the company in which all of the transactions performed up to that moment are considered and the effective CIT due is calculated. If the taxpayer has collected more CIT based on the estimate than the CIT due based on the actual calculation according to the balance sheet, the taxpayer may suspend the collection of the estimates until there is an equalization of the tax due.

If upon the final assessment of the CIT on 31 December there are any outstanding amounts to be collected by the taxpayer, such CIT must be collected up to the last day of March of the following year. On the other hand, if the CIT collected throughout the year was higher than the final CIT liability assessed on 31 December, the excess CIT may be either (i) offset against the CIT due by April of the following year or (ii) reimbursed in cash to the taxpayer or offset against other federal taxes upon a specific request.

With regard to CIT to be paid on a quarterly or annual basis (including the monthly estimate payments), the legal entity may consider the withholding income tax paid in connection with the income included in the taxable base.
The election for the assessment of CIT on a quarterly or annual basis must be made upon the payment of the first instalment of the CIT in the year and may only be changed for the subsequent year.

Legal entities subject to the CIT under the presumed profit regime are required to assess and collect the CIT on a quarterly basis, therefore considering the transactions performed within the quarter for purposes of defining the taxable revenue to be subject to the presumed percentages (which is the taxable base of the presumed profit regime). The CIT rates are than applied.

Under the presumed profit regime, the taxpayer is allowed to adopt the cash method for the recognition of revenue with regard to the transactions performed and contracted for receipt in instalments. Therefore, in a given quarter, the taxable base will only consider the amounts effectively received by the taxpayer.
With regard to the CIT to be paid for each quarter, the legal entity may consider the withholding income tax paid in connection with the income included in the taxable base.
The CIT must be collected up to the last business day of the month following the quarter to which the CIT is related.
The election for assessment of the CIT under the presumed profit regime must be made upon the payment of the first instalment of CIT in the year and may only be changed for the subsequent year.
In view of the COVID-19 pandemic, the deadlines for payment of federal taxes under the Simples Nacional regime were postponed by 3 months in 2020 and 2021.

topic.title: Refunds
topic.p: Under Complementary Law 118/2005, a 5-year limitation period, counted from the date when the tax was paid, applies for taxpayers to claim the refund or offsetting of unduly paid taxes.

There was a discussion as to whether said Law could be applied retroactively (considering that a 10-year limitation applied before its enactment) or only with regard to taxes collected after the Law entered into force.

A decision of the STF rejected the retroactive application of the 5-year limitation, so that the refund with regard to taxes collected prior to Complementary Law 118/2005 remains subject to the 10-year statute of limitations, while claims filed after the law came into effect (9 June 2005) will be subject to the 5-year statute of limitations. This decision is final and binding to the taxpayers and tax authorities.
If the tax administration refuses the claim, the taxpayer may engage in administrative litigation with regard to said credit and follow the general route applicable to tax assessments.

section.title: Interest
section.p: Taxes not paid by the legal deadline are subject to interest on late payments, calculated from the day following that on which the tax was due. Interest is calculated based on the SELIC rate. With regard to the first month following the deadline, a deemed interest rate of 1% is applied.

From time to time, special modalities of debt payment are announced by the government and normally apply for a specific period, allowing the payment of tax debts in better conditions (e.g. reduced interest rates and fines, payment in several instalments).

section.title: Penalties
section.p: In case of late payment without any notice from the tax authorities, a monetary penalty of 0.33% per day is applied, limited to 20% of the amount of tax due.

If a tax assessment is issued, a general 75% penalty is applied to the tax liability. If a wilful intention to commit fraud or simulation is proven by tax authorities, a 150% penalty applies. A 50% reduction in the penalty is granted if the taxpayer pays the assessed tax without dispute within 30 days of the date of the notice of the assessment.
If a taxpayer subject to the assessment of CIT under the annual actual profit regime does not collect the monthly estimates, a 50% penalty applies to the amount that was not collected.

If the taxpayer fails to timely present the income tax return or does not present such return, a penalty of 0.25% per month of the annual net profit before taxes (maximum 10% of net profit or BRL 100,000 for net profits up to BRL 3.6 million or BRL 5 million for net profits above BRL 3.6 million) applies, reduced by:

item.p: 90% (if filed within 30 days following the original deadline);
75% (if filed within 60 days following the original deadline);
50% (if filed before notification); or
25% (if filed within period given by notification).

section.p: On 12 December 2014, the Supreme Federal Court confirmed that tax penalties exceeding 100% of the value of the tax due are unconstitutional. The decision, given in the Extraordinary Appeal 833106/GO, concerned a state tax (i.e. not an income tax) of which the tax penalty amounted to 120%. The Court considered that the levy of penalties exceeding the amount of the tax due was a violation of the constitutional principle that forbids confiscation by the state. The decision is binding only on the parties involved, but may serve as a precedent for complaints regarding tax penalties above 100% of the tax (including income tax) due imposed by federal, state and municipal authorities.

Taxpayers with tax debts under the special administrative collection procedure (i.e. taxpayers with tax debts over BRL 10 million) are subject to additional non-monetary penalties in case they do not regularize their tax debts (e.g. restrictions imposed by financial institutions on granting public credit and financing and exclusion from special programmes for the payment of tax debts).

From time to time, special modalities of debt payment are announced by the government and normally apply for a specific period, allowing the payment of tax debts in better conditions (e.g. reduced interest rates and fines, payment in several instalments).

section.title: Statute of limitations
section.p: The audit of returns and the assessment of taxes must be effected within 5 years from the discharge of the tax obligation.

The statute of limitations for tax authorities assessing the taxpayers for the collection of taxes (and penalties for ancillary obligations) is 5 years, computed as from the date on which the assessment has become final, either because it has not been appealed against or because the notice of a final decision thereon has been served.

Under article 45 of Law 8,212/1991, the statute of limitations for collecting social security contributions to the National Social Security Institute (Instituto Nacional da Seguridade Social, INSS) was 10 years. Recently, the STF enacted Binding Precedent 8/2008, which established that the CTN provisions regarding the rights of tax authorities to assess tax credits, as mentioned above, should also be applicable to social security contributions.

section.title: Rulings
section.p: In Brazil, rulings can only be requested in the case of doubt regarding the application of existing legislation.

A request for an advance ruling relies on the right to petition, guaranteed under article 5(XXXIV)(a) of the Federal Constitution. This provision establishes that the right to petition the public authorities to defend one’s rights is guaranteed to all people.

For an advance tax ruling to be considered valid, it is necessary to clearly identify the uncertainty to be addressed by tax authorities, and such uncertainty must be justified by the taxpayer with regard to a certain and specific fact. That is, in theory, an advance tax ruling cannot decide on general aspects but rather only on specific situations faced by the taxpayer.

Matters that have already been reviewed by the tax authorities or that are the subject matter of an interpretation expressed under administrative rules cannot be the subject of an advance ruling. Actually, the purpose of an advance ruling is to clarify an uncertainty of the taxpayer, leading it to adopt a certain procedure based on the interpretation of the tax authorities, therefore avoiding litigation in the future.

As this is a preventive measure, the immediate effect of requesting an advance ruling is that it prevents the tax authorities from filing any tax procedure against the taxpayer with regard to the issue under consultation, from the date the request for advance ruling is filed up to the 30th day following the final decision on said request (article 48 of Decree-Law 70,235/1972).

Moreover, should the response to the request for an advance ruling be unfavourable to the taxpayer, meaning that taxes are payable, article 161(2) of the CTN provides that these tax liabilities will not be subject to penalties or interest if spontaneously collected by the taxpayer after the decision. This is because filing of the request for an advance ruling stays the term for payment of the taxes until the tax authorities pronounce an opinion on the matter. Decisions are binding only for the requesting taxpayer.

Decree 8,853/2016 amended the regulations on the consultation procedure to establish that taxpayers may also question the classification of goods, services and intangibles based on the Brazilian classification of service, intangibles and other transactions for international trade purposes. Another relevant change incorporated by said decree is related to reimbursement of tax requests relating to anti-dumping rights that now must be judged by the Brazilian Revenue Service. Decree 8,853/2016 also determined that the Brazilian Revenue Service has up to 360 days, counted from the date of the protocol, to decide on the consultation request.

The exchange of information on tax rulings (within the framework of improving transparency relating to rulings under Action 5 of the BEPS Action Plan of the OECD on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting) was implemented and regulated by Normative Instruction 1,689/2017. According to the OECD peer review report released on 4 December 2017, Brazil has met all aspects of the terms of reference for the year in review, except with respect to the timely provision of future rulings to the competent authority. However, as no future rulings were issued in this period, there has been no practical impact on the effectiveness of Brazil’s implementation of the transparency framework. No recommendation is made as Brazil has addressed this issue by ensuring that future rulings will be identified after they are issued.

topic.title: Mutual agreement procedure
topic.p: Normative Instruction 1,669/2016 introduced formal regulations to the mechanism for solving tax treaty controversies (MAP). Accordingly, any Brazilian resident – individual or corporate – may present the requirement for a formal procedure whenever it is understood that the application of the tax treaty is not in accordance with the wording of the agreement and there is no administrative or judicial ruling on the matter.

section.title: Tax audit/examination
section.p: The tax authorities can examine documents or request information from any taxpayer. The procedure for tax audit is ruled by Decree 70,235/1972 (Administrative Fiscal Procedure Ruling). Through this procedure, tax authority officers are able to investigate tax returns, books and invoices, and collect information about legal entities and transactions. The access by tax authorities to taxpayers' information held by financial institutions for tax investigation purposes is regulated by Decree 3,724/2014. Accordingly, tax authorities are allowed to examine taxpayers' information in documents, books, and registries of financial institutions (including information on deposit accounts and financial investments), provided that a tax audit is ongoing and such information is considered indispensible for the tax audit.

Decree 3,724/2014 lists the situations in which the access to information is considered indispensible for the tax audit, such as in the case of lack of documentation justifying loans with non-financial institutions and transactions engaged with persons resident of low-tax jurisdictions. On 5 September 2014, Decree 8,303/2014 amended Decree 3,724/2014 to add the following situations to the mentioned list:

item.p: transactions engaged with persons who benefit from a privileged tax regime, as defined by the Brazilian tax legislation; and
exchange of information required on the basis of international treaties, agreements or protocols for the purpose of tax inspection and collection.

section.p: The tax audit starts with a notification sent by tax authorities to the legal entity in order to indicate that the procedure will take place. This notification can indicate a tax examination procedure (mandado de procedimento fiscal – fiscalização) or a specific diligence audit (mandado de procedimento fiscal – diligência). If the tax authorities believe that the legal entity may hide proof or evidence, the procedure can be initiated without any previous notification.
According to Decree 8,303/2014, before accessing the information, tax authorities must notify taxpayers, who may respond by either:

item.p: authorizing the direct access by tax authorities to the information held by financial institutions; or
voluntarily presenting such information, with the confirmation of its veracity and integrity and of observation of applicable penal law.

section.p: The access to such information may be requested by the Brazilian tax authorities by means of a notification to the President of the Brazilian Central Bank, the President of the Brazilian Securities and Exchange Commission, the President of the Financial Institution or to the manager of the branch of the financial institution.

After the conclusion of the audit, the tax authorities may decide, upon the information collected, to issue a tax assessment against the legal entity. In this case, the company can present its defence by filing a written appeal against the assessment at the local office of the tax administration (see section 1.11.3.).

Some specific taxpayers are subject to “differentiated” and “special” tax monitoring rules, which consist in periodical cross-checking of macroeconomic variables, the taxpayer’s economic-tax behaviour and information regarding the taxpayers’ collection of listed taxes and contributions, for the purpose of verifying any inconsistencies. Those rules apply to major taxpayers, taxpayers with large debts before tax authorities, taxpayers with significant payroll, among others. According to Ordinance 5,018/2020, published in the DOU of 24 December 2020, the “differentiated” tax monitoring is applicable in 2021 to corporate taxpayers that meet at least one of the following conditions:

item.p: annual gross income equal to or exceeding BRL 250 million (regarding the second fiscal year prior to the auditing);
declared tax debits in the tax return (Declaração de Débitos e Créditos Tributários Federais, DCTF) equal to or exceeding BRL 30 million (regarding the second fiscal year prior to the auditing);
social security debts equal to or exceeding BRL 30 million (regarding the second fiscal year prior to the auditing);
a payroll amount equal to or exceeding BRL 70 million (regarding the second fiscal year prior to the auditing); or
import and export income equal to or exceeding BRL 150 million (regarding the second fiscal year prior to the auditing).

section.p: For 2021, the “special” tax monitoring applies to corporate taxpayers that meet at least one of the following conditions:

item.p: annual gross income equal to or exceeding BRL 1 billion (regarding the second fiscal year prior to the auditing);
declared tax debits equal to or exceeding BRL 70 million (regarding the second fiscal year prior to the auditing);
payroll equal to or exceeding BRL 100 million (regarding the second fiscal year prior to the auditing); or
social security debts exceeding BRL 70 million (regarding the second fiscal year prior to the auditing).

section.p: Besides these criteria, the tax authorities may also apply parameters for selecting companies for “differentiated” and “special” tax monitoring in 2021.

topic.title: Access to bank information
topic.p: According to article 5 of the Federal Constitution, bank details can only be revealed upon the request of a judicial court during a judicial proceeding. However, on 24 February 2016, the STF concluded the judgment of five actions questioning the constitutionality of article 6 of Complementary Law 105/2001 (Lei Complementar 105/2001), which authorizes tax authorities to access taxpayers' bank information during administrative proceedings. By a majority of votes, the Court decided for the constitutionality of the rule and, as a result, confirmed tax authorities' right to access taxpayers' bank information without the need of a prior judicial order issued by a judicial court. The decisions were given in Extraordinary Appeal (Recurso Extraordinário, RE) 601,304 and Direct Actions for Unconstitutionality (Ação Direta de Inconstitucionalidade, ADI) 2390, 2386, 2397 e 2859.

By allowing access to bank information during administrative proceedings (i.e. without judicial order), Complementary Law 105/2001 violates the bank secrecy rule in the constitutional article. The Court stated that there is no violation of taxpayers' bank secrecy in view of the fact that tax authorities are obliged to respect fiscal secrecy. In this regard, according to the Court, access to bank information by tax authorities means only the exchange of secret information between two organs that are bound by the same obligation of secrecy.
The decisions in the Direct Actions for Unconstitutionality have effect on all taxpayers.

section.title: Dividends, interest and royalties
section.p: Under article 10 of Law 9,249/1995, dividends paid out of after-tax profits are not subject to withholding tax.
Interest is subject to withholding tax at rates described in section 1.10.3.
Royalties paid by legal entities to resident individuals are subject to withholding tax at the progressive rates applied to individual income tax (see Individual Taxation section 1.10.).
Regarding withholding tax on payments to non-residents, see section 7.3.9.

section.title: Subcontract payments
section.p: In specific cases, payments made by legal entities to other legal entities may be subject to withholding taxes as an advance payment of their CIT liability and of the PIS and COFINS liability.
Articles 714 to 717 of the RIR list the services for which payments are subject to an income withholding tax when provided by a legal entity to another legal entity. See section 1.10.3. for rates.

In addition, Law 10,833/2003 provides a list of services for which payments made by legal entities to other legal entities require that CSLL, PIS and COFINS be withheld. See section 1.10.3. for rates.
Fees paid by a legal entity to an individual for independent personal services are subject to withholding tax at source at the progressive rates (see Individual Taxation section 1.10.).

section.title: Fees for technical and other services
section.p: See section 1.11.9.2.

section.title: Other
section.p: A withholding income tax is levied at the progressive rates given in Individual Taxation section 1.10. on monthly salaries and wages paid to employees. This tax is final but, if the taxpayer has other types of income, income from dependent personal services must be included in his taxable base for individual income tax purposes, with a credit for the tax already paid.
Corporate taxpayers are also required to withhold the social security contributions due by their employees on the monthly salaries and wages. For rates, see section 1.10.

section.title: Local income tax
section.p: No such tax applies.

section.title: Business tax on income
section.p: No such tax applies.

section.title: Social Contribution on Net Profits (Contribuição Social sobre o Lucro Liquido, CSLL)
section.p: CSLL is established in article 195(I) of the Federal Constitution and is governed by Law 7,689/1988, as modified by Law 8,034/1990 and Law 11,727/2008.
CSLL is imposed on corporate taxpayers and, in theory, it is destined to finance the federal social security system.

The taxable base of the CSLL is very similar to the taxable base of the IRPJ for taxpayers subject to the actual profit regime. The difference relies on minor inclusions and deductions that are specific for CSLL purposes. For this reason, the CSLL is generally viewed as an actual income tax.

With regard to companies subject to the presumed profit regime, the taxable base of the CSLL is 12% of their monthly gross revenue (same percentage applicable to the IRPJ), with regard to commercial companies in general and 32% of the gross revenue, with regard to companies engaged in the rendering of services. Capital gains and other income are fully added to the taxable base.
Under Law 9,316/1996, CSLL may not be deducted from the IRPJ taxable base nor from its own taxable base.
The use of accumulated losses follows the same principles of the IRPJ.

The prevailing opinion among tax scholars and of case law of the administrative courts was that the CSLL was only covered by tax treaties signed by Brazil before the introduction of CSLL on 1 January 1989. In the Oxiteno case, regarding the treaties signed by Brazil with Austria and Spain, the CARF decided that the CSLL is covered by such treaties because it was created before the countries signed their treaties and it was substantially similar to income tax. However, a different chamber of the same court decided that the CSLL is not covered by the treaties signed by Brazil with Austria and Spain because it is not a tax but a social contribution and the treaties were only meant to cover taxes. With regard to tax treaties signed after 1 January 1989, the CSLL would only be included in the substantive scope if it was expressly mentioned either in the treaty in the list of taxes covered or in the protocol. In view of the different opinions, Law 13,202/2015 finally stated that, for interpretation purposes, tax treaties concluded by Brazil do include the CSLL in their substantive scope.
For CSLL rates, see section 1.10.1.

section.title: Contribution for the financing of social security (Contribuição para o Financiamento da Seguridade Social, COFINS)
section.p: COFINS was created by Complementary Law 70/1991, as amended by Complementary Law 85/1996 and Laws 9,718/1998 and 10,833/2003, and is regulated by Normative Instruction 1,911/2019.
COFINS is a contribution imposed on all legal entities and, in theory, it is destined to finance the social security system.

COFINS is imposed on the taxpayer’s gross revenue, regardless of the source and denomination. Under the applicable laws, some items may be deducted from the taxable base, such as the IPI and ICMS (the exclusion of ICMS from the taxable base was confirmed by the Federal Supreme Court in Appeal 574,706), cancelled sales, restitutions, income from the sale of fixed assets and non-conditional discounts. On top of that, income from the export of goods and services is not subject to COFINS. For the purpose of this exemption, Normative Ruling 1/2018 clarified that export of services occurs when the renderer of the service "operates from the domestic market" using his own means available in national territory in order to meet a "demand from another (foreign) market" in favour of "the service taker that operates in such other (foreign) market". Accordingly, the renderer of the service "operates from the domestic market" when he initiates the provision of the service in the national territory through preparatory acts prior to the material rendering of the service, such as to the planning, identification of the indispensable expertise or the mobilization of the material and intellectual resources necessary for the service. The service taker "operates in the foreign market" when its demand for the service occurs abroad and must be satisfied outside the national territory.
Law 13,043/2014, broadened the definition of gross income for the purpose of COFINS by including any revenue connected to the core activity of the company.

There are two distinct regimes for the assessment and collection of COFINS. The first, regulated by Law 9,718/1998, is the cumulative regime and the second, introduced by Law 10,833/2003, is called the non-cumulative regime.

Under the cumulative regime, COFINS is imposed at a general 3% rate on the taxpayers’ gross revenue, without the deduction of any credits. The cumulative regime is mandatory for legal entities adopting the presumed profit regime for CIT purposes. Additionally, financial institutions are also obliged to adopt the cumulative regime but, with regard to those entities, a 4% rate applies.

Still in connection with the assessment of COFINS by financial institutions, the applicable laws and regulations (mainly IN 1,285/2012 and IN 1,544/2015) provides for several exclusions from the taxable basis, so that the effective COFINS rate is usually lower than 4%.

Under the non-cumulative regime, COFINS is imposed at a 7.6% rate over the taxpayers’ gross revenue but, in this case, the deduction of credits expressly listed under article 3 of Law 10,833/2003 is allowed. The idea of the non-cumulative regime is to reduce the effects of the imposition of COFINS with regard to the several stages of the production chain.

The COFINS non-cumulative regime, however, is not a straightforward offsetting regime, under which all amounts previously paid with regard to one good or service within the production chain may be used as a credit. In fact, COFINS credits are calculated via the application of the 7.6% rate over the amounts incurred for the acquisition of inputs, lease and rental payments, and electricity, among other items listed by article 3 of Law 10,833/2003.

Despite of the tax authorities’ restrictive interpretation of the concept of inputs, a broader concept has been applied by the Superior Court of Justice decisions, the most recent one issued on 22 February 2018. The Superior Court of Justice decision follows the same reasoning already applied by the lower courts, according to which expenses that are essential for providing the services or producing the goods should be taken into consideration for assessing the credits, even when they are not listed. These decisions could lead to a new trend to conceptualize inputs for COFINS purposes with a more beneficial approach towards taxpayers.

Until 30 June 2015, financial income derived by companies subject to COFINS under the non-cumulative regime was subject to those contributions at a 0% rate (except for the receipt of interest on net equity from domestic subsidiaries). However, as of 1 July 2015, the rate is increased from 0% to 4% by Decree 8,426/2015. The 0% rate remained, though, for financial income derived from foreign exchange fluctuation related to the following transactions: (i) exports of goods and services, (ii) liabilities resulting from loans and financing agreements and (iii) hedging transactions carried out on the stock exchange, futures or over-the-counter market for the purpose of protecting the investor against price or rate variations, provided that the contract: (a) is related to the operational activities developed by the legal entity and (b) aims at protecting the legal entity’s rights and liabilities.

The constitutionality of the 4% rate levied on financial income was under discussion at the Superior Court of Justice (in Appeal RESP 1,586,950), in view of the fact that COFINS tax rates can only be raised under a law (not a decree) in accordance with the constitutional principle of strict legality. However, on 9 October 2017, the Superior Court of Justice ruled that Law 10,865/2004 authorizes the Federal Executive Branch to increase, reduce and restore COFINS rates by decree and, therefore, the increase is constitutional.

The non-cumulative regime is mandatory for those entities assessing the CIT based on the actual profit regime. However, with regard to some specific revenues, COFINS is due based on the cumulative regime (even if the general regime adopted by the taxpayer is the non-cumulative one). In this sense, the revenues derived in view of the performance of public transportation services, educational services, marketing and call centre services, travel agent services, among several others listed in article 10 of Law 10,833/2003, are subject to the cumulative regime.

In addition to that, with regard to some specific activities, COFINS is imposed based on specific rates and taxable basis, such as in connection with the sale by importers and producers of petroleum-based products and ethanol. In those cases, the rates vary in accordance with the type of product and whether or not the party is a producer or an importer. Currently, the rates vary from 6.9% to 47.4%, depending on the type of product. Some special regimes for the collection of COFINS are also available with regard to the sale of ethanol and petroleum products, under which the COFINS contribution is calculated based on a fixed price multiplied by the number of cubic metres or tons involved in the transaction.

See section 1.9. for some relevant tax incentives related to COFINS. In any case, there are other special regimes and tax incentives applicable to specific situations and activities developed by corporate taxpayers. Indeed, there are several exemptions and 0% rates applicable to specific products and services, based on their description and tax classification codes.

Law 10,833/2003 also created a withholding tax regime for COFINS in respect of certain service payments, including those for cleaning, security, professional and credit services. The withholding tax is treated as an advance payment of the COFINS liability. IN 459/2004 establishes the rules for taxpayers in respect of this withholding tax regime. For details on the withholding obligations, see section 1.10.3.4.

Finally, Law 10,865/2004 introduced the imposition of COFINS in connection with the import of goods and services by Brazilian corporate taxpayers. The COFINS-Import is not imposed on gross revenue but rather on the customs value of the imported good or the price of the contracted services. The taxable base of the COFINS-Import levied on the import of goods is the customs value of the goods. Previously, the value of the imported goods for the purpose of the COFINS-Import was determined on the basis of a formula laid down by the federal tax authorities, which took into account the value of the goods and the taxes levied on their import. The taxable base of the COFINS-Import levied on the import of services remains, however, calculated on the basis of such a formula, disclosed by the federal tax authorities (Normative Instructions 572/2005 and 1,401/2013). The import of services for the purpose of COFINS-Import is considered to exist when services are executed in Brazil or when they are executed outside Brazil but the “result” is verified in Brazil. There is controversy in respect of what “result” means for the purpose of this rule, which can lead to discussions on the levy of COFINS-Import.

Several private rulings (e.g. Private Rulings 316/2017 and 74/2019) clarify that the outbound payment, credit, delivery or remittance of royalties is not subject to COFINS-Import. For this purpose, the term “royalties” is understood to include income from the licensing of the use of software. If technical service or assistance is also provided (mixed contract), COFINS-Import is levied on the related fees, provided that these amounts are separately identified in the contract. If the contract is not clear in respect of what amount is related to royalties and what amount is related to the provision of technical service and assistance, the total amount of the contract will be deemed to be fees for technical service and assistance and will, thus, be subject to COFINS-Import.

According to Private Ruling 153/2017, the taxable event triggering COFINS-Import of services occurs upon the payment, credit, delivery or remittance of the income to the non-resident person. In the specific case of credit, it is sufficient for the configuration of the taxable event that the paying source in Brazil registers the payment obligation in its accounting records. Private Ruling 544/2018 clarified that there is no levy of COFINS-Import in the case of a payment made by a non-resident person to another non-resident person for services provided to a resident of Brazil.

According to Law 13,137/2015, the standard rate levied on the import of goods is 9.65%. The import of listed products may also trigger rates higher than the standard 9.65% (e.g. certain medications and vaccines are taxed at the rate of 13.03%; listed perfumery, toiletries and personal hygiene products are taxed at the rate of 16.48%; listed machines and vehicles at the rate of 12.57%). The import of service is subject to the standard rate of 7.6%.

With regard to taxpayers assessing COFINS based on the non-cumulative regime, the amounts paid as a COFINS-Import may be discounted as credits for the assessment of COFINS due in connection with the taxpayers’ gross revenue. Law 12,973/2014 clarified that income arising from the sale of long-term assets is not subject to COFINS (the same applies to fixed assets).

An additional 1% rate of COFINS applies from 1 April 2022 to 31 December 2023 on the import of certain products (e.g. shoes, fur and leather, gloves, vehicles, parachutes) (Law 14,288/2021) - this additional 1% rate had been previously levied but was subsequently revoked by Provisional Measure 774/2017.

Until 31 December 2022, a zero COFINS rate applies on internal transactions and the import of listed types of fuels (e.g. diesel, biodiesel, liquefied petroleum gas, petroleum derivatives and natural gas).

In view of the COVID-19 pandemic, a zero COFINS rate applies for entities under the emergency programme for the recovery of the events sector (Programa Emergencial de Retomada do Setor de Eventos) (Law 14,148/2021 and Ordinance 7,163/2021).

Companies are required to specify on invoices and receipts the taxes charged (percentages), which are part of the total amount of the product’s sales price or the price for the provision of services, including COFINS. In this sense, companies must list the amount of municipal, state and federal taxes levied for each product described in the invoices and receipts sold. Alternatively, such information could also be displayed on a panel in plain view within their establishments. Companies failing to comply with these requirements are subject to administrative penalties.

section.title: Contribution to PIS (Contribuição para o programa de integração social e para o programa de formação de patrimônio do servidor público, PIS)
section.p: PIS was created by Complementary Laws 7/1970 and 8/1988. This contribution is regulated by Laws 9,715/1998, 9,718/1998 and 10,637/2002, Provisional Measure 1,858-6/1999 and Normative Instruction 1,911/2019.

Corporate taxpayers are subject to the PIS contribution, which is imposed based on their gross revenue. PIS is very similar to COFINS in connection with the mechanics for its assessment and collection – the reason why they are jointly referred to. In this sense, as it happens with COFINS, there are two distinct regimes for the assessment and collection of PIS. The first, regulated by Law 9,718/1998, is the cumulative regime and the second, introduced by Law 10,833/2003, is called the non-cumulative regime.

Based on Law 9,718/98, under the cumulative regime, legal entities are subject to the imposition of PIS on their gross revenue at the rate of 0.65%. The same deductions for COFINS purposes are allowed for determining the PIS basis calculation (see section 2.3.2.). The 0.65% rate also applies for financial institutions and the provisions of IN 1,285/2012 also apply in order to allow some deduction in the taxable basis. Income from the export of goods and services is not subject to PIS. For the purpose of this exemption, Normative Ruling 1/2018 clarified the meaning of export of services, which is the same applicable for the purpose of the exemption from COFINS (see section 2.3.2.).
Law 13,043/2014, broadened the definition of gross income for the purpose of PIS by including any revenue connected to the core activity of the company.

topic.title: Employer’s contribution to the unemployment severance fund (contribuição ao fundo de garantia por tempo de service, FGTS)
topic.p: To ensure severance payment upon termination of employment, employers must deposit every month 8% of their total payroll into blocked bank accounts linked to each employee (the so-called FGTS contribution).

If an employee is dismissed or retires, he may withdraw the amount deposited in his blocked account. If an employee voluntarily changes jobs, the amount accumulated in the account will continue to increase by the contributions of the new employer. If an employee is dismissed without motivation, the employer must pay a penalty of 50% of the amount deposited during that employee’s years of service.

topic.title: Industrial social service contribution (serviço social da indústria, SESI)/commercial social service contribution (serviço social do comércio, SESC)
topic.p: The SESI/SESC contribution is an additional payroll tax that is levied at a rate of 1.5% on the employer’s payroll for the purposes of cultural and educational facilities of workers.

topic.title: National service of industrial apprenticeship contribution (serviço nacional de aprendizagem industrial, SENAI) and National service of commercial apprenticeship contribution (serviço nacional de aprendizagem comercial, SENAC)
topic.p: The SENAC contribution is a payroll tax that is levied at a rate of 1.0% or 1.2% of the workers’ payroll.

In order to fund the national services of industrial and commercial apprenticeships, employers must contribute monthly an amount equal to a percentage defined by reference to their payroll and the number of their workers. For employers with up to 500 workers, the contribution rate is 1% of their payroll and for employers with more than 500 workers, the contribution rate is 1.2%.

topic.title: Brazilian service for the support of small and medium-sized enterprises contribution (serviço Brasileiro de apoio à pequena e média empresa, SEBRAE)
topic.p: The SEBRAE contribution is another payroll tax that is levied as an additional contribution to SESI/SESC and SENAI/SENAC at the rate of 0.3% on the employer’s payroll for the purposes of promoting small enterprises.

section.title: Social security contributions
section.p: The Brazilian social security system is financed by the contributions of employers, employees and the federal government. Employers are required to pay social security contributions and charges based on the payroll (see below) as well as contributions based on their gross income. For social contributions on gross revenue, see sections 2.3.1. to 2.3.3.

topic.title: Contribution of the Employer to the Social Security (Contribuição Patronal Previdenciária para a Seguridade Social)
topic.p: Employers are subject to a contribution to the social security system which is calculated based on a general 20% rate on the monthly payroll (according to the Federal Supreme Court, including the maternity leave salary in the taxable base is unconstitutional). There is no ceiling for these contributions. Financial institutions pay an additional 2.5% on their monthly payroll.
Legal entities must also pay this contribution on the fees paid to any self-employed individuals as a consideration for the rendering of services.

In addition to paying their own contribution of 20% on the monthly payroll, employers must also withhold and remit the social contributions of their employees and the self-employed individuals with whom they have contracted – for details, see Individual Taxation sections 3.1. and 3.2. The contribution withheld in this case is limited to the application of the applicable rate to the contribution salary established by social security authorities (which is the basis for the imposition of the social security contributions due by the employees). For 2022, the maximum contribution salary is BRL 7,087.22.
Under Law 9,711/1998, companies must also withhold 11% on the payments made to other companies for the rendering of specific services.

Under Law 11,457/2007, the Brazilian Revenue Service (RFB) is responsible for managing the collection of the social contributions while the National Social Security Institute (INSS) only manages payment of social security benefits.
Until 31 December 2023, certain business sectors may opt to collect social contribution on gross income instead of the standard social security contribution (see below).

topic.title: Social Contribution on Gross Income (Contribuição Previdenciária sobre a Receita Bruta, CPRB)
topic.p: Under Law 12,546/2011, as amended by Law 13,670/2018 and regulated by Normative Instructions 1,436/2013 and 1,812/2018, listed business sectors may opt to collect social contribution based on a percentage of their gross revenues (Contribuição Previdenciária sobre a Receita Bruta, CPRB) instead of collecting the standard social contribution of 20% on the payroll – before 30 November 2015, the CPRB was not an option but obligatory. Under Law 12,546/2011 as amended by Laws 14,020/2020 and 14,288/2021, the option for the CPRB is available until 31 December 2023.

According to Private Ruling 10,022/2015, for the applicability of the CPRB only the main economic activity of the entity is taken into consideration. As a result, entities are subject to CPRB, provided that the main economic activity figures in the list of activities subject to this contribution. The fact that the secondary activity is in the list of activities is not enough to trigger the levy of CPRB. Further, Private Ruling COSIT 193/2015 clarified that, in the case that no revenue was derived by the company in the previous calendar year, the main economic activity to be considered for the applicability of the CPRB is the one which is expected to produce the highest revenue among the activities described in the constitutive act of the company.

Approximately 56 business sectors were initially entitled to this contribution based on gross income, but this number was significantly reduced by Law 13,670/2018. Currently, construction companies and infrastructure works, vehicles industry, machinery and equipment industry, textile, information technology, communication technology and freight transport services are among those still figuring in the list. The applicable rates vary from 1% to 4.5% according to the business sector or products manufactured. In case of the provision of certain services, companies must withhold 3.5% on payments made to companies subject to CPRB.

As this mechanism is based on gross income from the products and services specifically listed by the government and not the entire activity developed by the taxpayer, entities engaged in the manufacturing of some listed and non-listed products must adopt a mixed system for the calculation of the social security contribution.

The mechanism considers the specific products listed by the government and not the entire activity developed by the taxpayer. Therefore, entities that are engaged in the manufacturing of some listed and non-listed products must adopt a mixed system for the calculation of the social security contribution.

For the purpose of calculating the social contribution, gross revenues are comprised of (i) the revenues arising from the rendering of services, (ii) the revenues arising from the sale of goods, and (iii) commissions and fees when the entity is acting on behalf of third parties in the sale of goods. However, the following should not be considered gross revenues: revenues arising from exports, cancelled sales, unconditional discounts and the IPI and ICMS included in the prices charged by the taxpayer.

topic.title: Workers compensation insurance (seguro de acidente do trabalho, SAT)
topic.p: A contribution to SAT must be made by employers for the purposes of providing compensation on the death or disability or for employment-related accidents of their employees.

Employers must pay a monthly premium calculated on the payroll. The rates vary according to the level of accident risk related to the company business activity: 1% (low risk), 2% (medium risk) or 3% (high risk).

As from 2010, Brazilian authorities introduced the accident prevention factor (fator acindentário de prevenção, FAP), which must be taken into account in the definition of the amount due as SAT. The FAP may double the amount of the SAT contribution or reduce it by 50%, based on the number and seriousness of labour accidents that took place in the previous year.

topic.title: Education contribution (salário educação)
topic.p: Salário educação was established by Decree-Law 1,422/1975 and regulated by Decree 87,043/1982. This contribution is regulated by Law 9,766/1998.
For the purpose of investing in education, commercial, industrial and farming enterprises must choose to either:

item.p: provide free instruction (first grade) to both employees and their children between 7 and 14 years of age; or
pay an educational contribution of 2.5% of the employer’s total payroll.

topic.p: The following entities are exempt from this contribution:

item.p: federal government, states, the federal district and municipalities;
public institutions;
community schools, religious or charitable organizations;
cultural organizations defined by regulation; and
hospital and social assistance organizations provided they meet certain requirements stated by law.

section.title: Net worth tax
section.p: There is no net worth tax in Brazil.

section.title: Business tax on capital
section.p: There is no business tax on capital in Brazil.

section.title: Real estate tax
section.p: There are two different taxes on real estate – the municipal tax on real estate (imposto sobre propriedade territorial urbana, IPTU) and the federal tax on rural land (imposto territorial rural, ITR). These taxes are mutually exclusive (the same property may not be subject to both at the same time).
Privately owned buildings open to the general public (e.g. museums, private areas occupied by gardens or parks) are usually taxed at nominal rates or exempt from tax.
See section 14.2. for taxes on transfer of capital.

topic.title: Municipal tax on real estate (imposto sobre a propriedade territorial urbana, IPTU)
topic.p: Urban land and buildings are subject to a municipal real estate tax on a yearly basis.
Real estate taxes on urban property are used not only to raise revenue but also as an indirect mean of enforcing municipal regulations in matters such as construction, housing and landscaping.
The tax is levied on urban land and buildings, including land located within urban areas that is not used for agricultural or entertainment activities. The taxpayer is the owner of the property.

For the purposes of this tax, the urban areas of a city or town are those having at least two of the requirements indicated by law, such as pavements, water mains, sewerage facilities, street lights and public schools within 1.5 miles of the property.

The tax is assessed annually on the market value of the property, as disclosed by municipal tax authorities (valor venal). The appraisal procedure is governed by law with varying degrees of sophistication depending on the municipality.
Tax rates are determined by each municipality. The rates may vary considerably, e.g. from 0.5%, 1%, 2% to 3.5% and may be progressive in view of the value attributed to the property and its location.

topic.title: Federal tax on rural land (imposto territorial rural, ITR)
topic.p: The federal tax on rural land (ITR) is provided for by article 153, VI of the Federal Constitution, currently governed by Law 9,393/1996, and it is imposed annually on the ownership or possession of rural land located outside the urban zone.

ITR is a federal tax assessed by the Brazilian Revenue Service. Under article 153, paragraph 4 of the Federal Constitution, the ITR must have progressive rates and is destined to promote a more rational and intensive use of rural land.
An exemption from ITR applies in respect of:

item.p: land explored by the owner or holder and his family with the eventual help of other persons, provided that their combined area does not exceed a certain limit (30, 50 or 100 hectares, depending on the location) and that the owner or holder has no urban property;

land explored by a production association or a cooperative, under certain conditions, provided that the total area does not exceed a certain limit (30, 50, 100 hectares, depending on the location) and the holder and his family have no other property; and
land located in certain specified areas (e.g. Occidental and Oriental Amazon, Mato Grosso’s Pantanal and Poligono das Secas) provided that the total area does not exceed a certain amount of hectares.

topic.p: ITR is calculated on the “taxable value of the bare land”, defined on 31 December of the previous year. The calculation of the taxable value of the bare land is defined by law and takes into account the amount resulting from the multiplication of the value of the bare land (value of the property after certain deductions, as declared by the land owner, based on market standards) by the ratio which the taxable area (value of the total area after certain deductions) bears to the total area.

If tax authorities object to the value of bare land declared by the land owner, they may assess a taxable base for the imposition of the ITR, based on the price of other land in the same region and other information available in the RFB’s electronic system.

The tax rates are provided by the Annex of Law 9,393/1996 and vary from 0.03% to 20% in accordance with the number of hectares of land and the ratio which the area actually used bears to the total useful area of the land.

section.title: Shareholders and Directors of Resident Companies
Dividends in general
section.p: Dividends and similar profit distributions derived as from 1 January 1996 and paid by resident companies out of after-tax profits are exempt from income tax. As a result of the exemption, no withholding tax is therefore applied.

section.title: Individual shareholders
section.p: Dividends are exempt from tax.

section.title: Substantial corporate shareholders
section.p: Dividends are exempt from tax.

section.title: Portfolio corporate shareholders
section.p: Dividends are exempt from tax.

section.title: Hidden profit distribution
section.p: A disguised distribution of profits is deemed to occur if a legal entity:

item.p: transfers assets to its individual or corporate administrators, owners or controlling shareholders or next of kin for a price notoriously lower than the current market value of such assets;
acquires assets from persons described in (1) for a price notoriously higher than the current market value of such assets;
gives up deposits or advance payments made to persons described in (1) in order to obtain a preferential right to the purchase of assets;
transfers preferential rights to the subscription of securities to persons described in (1) for no value or for a price lower than the current market value of such rights;
makes payments of rents, royalties or technical assistance fees to persons described in (1) for an amount that is notoriously higher than current market prices; or

concludes any other transaction with persons described in (1) in terms more favourable to such persons than those prevailing in the market or than those that would govern transactions with third parties.

section.p: As dividends paid by resident companies are not subject to taxation, the amounts representing a disguised distribution of profits are added to the legal entity’s profits or disallowed as a tax deduction, as the case may be.

The “disguised distribution of profits” test does not apply where the taxpayer substantiates that the transaction was concluded in the interest of the legal entity, under fair terms or under terms that would govern transactions with third parties.

section.title: Individual shareholders
section.p: As a general rule, capital gains derived by resident and non-resident individuals from the transfer of any property or rights thereon, including the disposal of shares in a resident company, are subject to a final withholding tax at a rate of 15% (a 25% rate applies if the shareholder is located in a low-tax jurisdiction; see section 10.6.).
However, certain capital gains are exempt from income tax, including:

item.p: gains derived from the sale of low-value assets and rights, provided the sale price does not exceed BRL 35,000; and

gains derived by non-residents on the Brazilian financial and capital markets, provided that such residents have registered such investments based on specific rules issued by the Central Bank of Brazil, are exempt from withholding income tax. This exemption applies to portfolio investments effected through the Brazilian Stock Exchange, as well as to investments made in local private equity funds, under specified conditions and rules issued by the Central Bank of Brazil.

section.p: See also Individual Taxation sections 1.7. and 7.3.1.6.

section.title: Substantial corporate shareholders
section.p: There is no special regime of taxation of capital gains derived by substantial corporate shareholders, who are subject to the general rules, i.e. gains are included in the taxable base for CIT purposes (see section 1.7.1.).

For capital gains derived by resident companies from the disposal of shares of non-resident companies, see section 7.2.1.5.; for capital gains derived by non-resident companies from the disposal of shares of resident companies, see section 7.3.3.5.

section.title: Portfolio corporate shareholders
section.p: Portfolio corporate shareholders are subject to the general rules of taxation of capital gains, i.e. gains are included in the taxable base for CIT purposes.

For capital gains derived by resident companies from the disposal of shares of non-resident companies, see section 7.2.1.5.; for capital gains derived by non-resident companies from the disposal of shares of resident companies, see section 7.3.3.5.

section.title: Purchase by a company of its own shares
section.p: Brazilian companies are allowed to redeem their shares, provided that this decision is taken in view of a shareholders’ resolution. From the perspective of the shareholder, redemption of shares is viewed as a type of disposition and therefore subject to capital gains taxation. The simple disposal of the shares to the company is also subject to capital gains taxation, based on the general rules related to capital gains taxation.
