In general, Brazilian companies are allowed to acquire their own shares, provided that the amount of the acquired shares does not exceed the amount of capital reserves and earnings and does not imply a reduction of the share capital. Some specific rules apply to publicly held companies, as provided by the CVM.

The profits made by a Brazilian company in view of the disposal of its own shares, previously kept as treasury stock, are not subject to CIT. Likewise, losses potentially incurred upon said transactions are not deductible for CIT purposes.

section.title: Liquidation
section.p: In case of liquidation, assets allocated by a company to its shareholders, quotaholders or members may be either valued at their book value or fair market value. In the latter case, if the market value exceeds the book value, a taxable capital gain arises and is subject to CIT at the level of the liquidating company.
From the perspective of the shareholder, the liquidation of a company does not bring tax effects.

section.title: Directors
section.p: Fees, including bonuses and income under profit sharing programmes, paid to directors and managers of legal entities, are subject to individual income tax, and the progressive rates apply. See Individual Taxation section 1.3.4. for details.
Fees paid to corporate members of a board of directors are also taxable at the level of the beneficiary.

section.title: Resident and non-resident companies
section.p: For the definition of resident entity, see section 1.1.5. As the law does not discuss the concept of non-resident, an entity is considered to be non-resident in Brazil if not covered by the rules defining the concept of resident entity.

section.title: Definition under domestic law
section.p: Brazilian tax law does not provide for a concept of permanent establishment. However, it allows non-residents to operate in Brazil upon the filing of a request with the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Development seeking an authorization to carry out business activities locally through branches, which are subject to tax in Brazil under the same rules applicable to resident companies.

In addition, and without making reference to the term permanent establishment, Brazilian tax law addresses situations under which a non-resident taxpayer may constitute a taxable presence in Brazil without being formally registered in the country. These rules are not expressly related to determining whether there is a permanent establishment in Brazil, although the tax authorities could, in principle, rely on them to assess CIT on local “taxable units” of non-residents. One situation refers to non-residents that are subject to corporate income taxes on profits derived in Brazil from the sale of imported goods through official representatives (mandatários) or commissionaires (comissários) (articles 159(3) and 468 of the RIR), or from the direct sale of imported goods through local agents or representatives (a type of agency permanent establishment) (articles 469 and 612 of the RIR). In this respect, Private Ruling 4/2013 (Solução de Consulta or Processo de Consulta) confirmed that when the agent has binding powers and the invoicing is done directly by the non-resident, the profits of the non-resident enterprise are determined by applying a profit percentage on the gross revenue. This is the first guideline issued by tax authorities on the PE subject. However, this assessment and actual taxation does not happen in practice.

The other situation that may constitute a taxable presence in Brazil refers to the concept of a business or professional unit, where a person conducts business activities without being formally registered with the competent authorities to do so (unincorporated business unit). There is no definition of a business unit in the Brazilian tax legislation. However, under the Civil Code (articles 966, 982 and 986 of Law 10,406/2002), a business unit is the complex of assets aligned for conducting business activities. Although the Civil Code does not provide for details, such definition may serve as guidance to Brazilian tax authorities and taxpayers to determine whether or not the activities conducted locally by a non-resident qualify as a business unit.

Despite the lack of a definition of permanent establishments in the law, the country-by-country regulations (see section 10.2.2.) referred to a permanent establishment as a fixed business installation through which an entity exercises, wholly or partly, its business activity in a different jurisdiction (Normative Instruction 1,681/2016). The definition follows with a list of examples, including “a place of management, a branch, an office, a factory, a workshop, a mine or any place of extraction of minerals and a construction site only when it exceeds the period of 12 months”. While normative instructions are administrative acts that are hierarchically below the law, they may serve as a basis for the tax authorities to challenge operations that are not being taxed in Brazil.

Brazilian tax law does not allow non-residents to optionally carry out business in Brazil as a business unit. If Brazilian tax authorities verify that a non-resident is conducting business in Brazil as a business unit without registering its activities as prescribed by law, a tax assessment may be imposed on the non-resident. There are no court cases dealing with situations where a non-resident has entered into local business transactions through an unregistered business unit.

There are only few cases regarding the recognition of permanent establishments in Brazil – private rulings and administrative decisions (Private Ruling 4/2013 and Decisions CARF 2202-003.114 and 2202-003.063, both from 2016) and rare judicial decisions (e.g. AMS 00224789620014025101 of 2009).

section.title: Definition under treaties
section.p: As a general rule, the definition of permanent establishment provided by tax treaties concluded by Brazil follows the OECD Model.

section.title: General principles
section.p: Resident companies are taxed on worldwide income on an accrual basis, following the general CIT principles (article 25 of Law 9,249/1995).
For voluntary disclosure of non-declared assets kept abroad, see section 7.2.4.

section.title: Business profits
section.p: Profits of permanent establishments (such as branches, representation offices and agencies), as well as undistributed profits from affiliated and controlled entities abroad, are converted into Brazilian real and added to the results of the Brazilian legal entity on 31 December of every year, regardless of effective distribution, under the provisions of Brazilian CFC rules.

After constant discussions on the validity and constitutionality of the Brazilian CFC rules, and subsequent to the decision issued by the Supreme Court on the matter (see section 10.4.), Law 12,973/2014 introduced the new Brazilian CFC regulations. Amongst other changes, a distinction is made on the taxation of controlled companies and affiliate companies – the latter is only subject to the automatic taxation under certain circumstances.

The law is generally effective as of 1 January 2015. However, taxpayers could elect to implement the new CFC rules and other regulations for the calendar year 2014. For details on CFC rules, see section 10.4.).

Provided that the jurisdiction in which the permanent establishment, affiliated or controlled company is located, has financial and accounting standards for the preparation of financial statements, the profits will be recognized in Brazil, considering such standards (i.e. there is no recalculation according to domestic rules). A tax credit equivalent to the income tax paid abroad on the same profits is usually granted.
The offsetting of losses incurred in the foreign jurisdiction against the profits derived in Brazil is not allowed.
Remittances for the capitalization of the permanent establishment abroad is considered an investment and thus not subject to withholding income tax.

Payments to the permanent establishment abroad are considered transactions between related parties under Brazilian legislation (article 23 of Law 9,430/1996). Therefore, deductions are subject to transfer pricing rules (see section 10.2.). Deductions of payments of interest made by the Brazilian legal entity to its permanent establishment abroad are subject to thin capitalization rules (see section 10.3.).

section.title: Dividends
section.p: Companies must include foreign-source dividends in their taxable base for CIT purposes. A credit is granted for the taxes paid abroad up to the limit of the Brazilian CIT liability on such income.

section.title: Interest, royalties and other income
section.p: Foreign-source interest and royalties paid to resident entities are normally included in the business profits of the recipient and subject to CIT.

section.title: Capital gains
section.p: As a general rule, foreign-source capital gains realized by legal entities are usually treated as ordinary income for tax purposes and subject to CIT.

section.title: Foreign losses
section.p: Under article 25, paragraph 5, of Law 9,249/1995, foreign-source losses may not be offset against the taxable profit generated in Brazil.

However, under Normative Instruction 213/2002 and Normative Instruction 1,520/2014, foreign-source losses generated by a foreign controlled company (or an affiliated company taxed under the regime of controlled foreign companies) may be set off against profits of the same foreign company, as a general rule, for the purpose of taxation under CFC regime. In this case, the 30% limitation for the offsetting of tax losses, applicable with regard to profits derived within the domestic operations, does not apply.

Law 12,973/2014 introduced a temporary possibility (until 2022) for consolidating the results derived by controlled foreign companies, provided that such results are attributable to active income and that the foreign controlled entities:

item.p: are not located in a country with which Brazil does not have an exchange of information agreement or agreement with a specific clause on exchange of information on tax matters (an exception is made if the controlling company discloses the digital booking accounts and supporting documents, amongst other requirements);
are not (or are not directly or indirectly controlled by an entity) located in a low-tax jurisdiction;

do not benefit (or are not directly or indirectly controlled by an entity that benefits) from a privileged tax regime or a tax regime with a nominal income tax rate lower than 20% (the so-called “under-taxation” regime (regime de subtributação)); and
generate a percentage of at least 80% of active income.

section.p: The positive result after consolidation must be added to the taxable base of the controlling company in Brazil. Losses after consolidation may be carried forward and be set off against profits of the same controlled subsidiaries.

For CFC rules and consolidation purposes, Law 12,973/2014 and Normative Instruction 1,520/2014 define active income as income directly obtained as a result of the entity’s own business activities, with the exclusion of:

item.p: royalties, interest and dividends;
shareholding interest;
rents;
capital gains (except in relation to shareholding interest with a holding period of at least 2 years); and
financial investments and financial intermediation.

section.p: In case the entity is a financial institution, interest and income related to financial investments and financial intermediation are considered active income. Dividends and profits arising from investments acquired until 31 December 2013 in a company with more than 80% of active income are also considered active income for consolidation purposes.

section.title: Other taxes on income
section.p: There is also relief from double taxation in respect of the CSLL (see section 2.3.1.) levied on foreign-source income.

section.title: Taxes on foreign capital
section.p: Brazilian tax law does not impose any taxes on capital. However, as reviewed in section 14.6.4.3., a tax applies to the performance of foreign exchange transactions to bring funds into Brazil for the performance of investments. Until 2017, a regime applied for voluntary disclosure of non-declared assets and regularization of undeclared (or incorrectly declared) funds, goods and rights with lawful origin which had been remitted or kept abroad or repatriated by resident individuals or legal entities (Regime Especial de Regularização Cambial e Tributária, RERCT) (Law 13,254/2016).

section.title: Emigration
section.p: There is no deemed disposal of assets on emigration. This concept is not envisaged under Brazilian law.

section.title: Double taxation relief
section.p: Legislation concerning double taxation relief includes article 465 of the RIR, Law 9,249/1995, Law 9,430/1996 and Normative Instruction 213/2002, while Law 12,973/2014 and Normative Instruction 1,520/2014 contain double taxation relief applicable under CFC rules.

Brazil taxes not only foreign-source income derived by resident companies (whether directly or through a branch), but also the income derived by foreign controlled or affiliated companies in proportion to the ownership percentage held by the Brazilian parent. Unilateral relief is granted to corporate taxpayers by means of an ordinary foreign tax credit system. Relief granted under tax treaties is applicable regardless of whether the relief is foreseen in domestic law (e.g. Divergence Ruling 8/2014).

Taxes paid abroad on income directly derived by a Brazilian-resident taxpayer may be claimed as a credit against the domestic tax liability. This foreign tax credit is limited to the amount of domestic tax that is imposed on the foreign-source income. For these purposes, the Brazilian tax liability includes both IRPJ and CSLL – see the Introduction. Excess credit may be carried forward indefinitely.

Brazilian tax authorities hold the position that resident entities opting for the presumed profit regime of taxation (see section 1.2.1.) and directly providing services abroad are not allowed to offset taxes paid abroad with taxes paid in Brazil (Divergence Ruling 8/2014). However, this prohibition does not apply if the service is provided within countries with which Brazil has signed a tax treaty where the elimination of international double taxation is agreed through the use of the credit method, without restrictions connected to the regimes of taxation opted by the taxpayer in Brazil. This is also understood as a confirmation that Brazil allows the granting of credit based on tax treaties only (that is, regardless of whether it is foreseen under domestic law).

Under CFC rules (see section 10.4.), an ordinary foreign tax credit is available for the tax on profit distributions by foreign subsidiaries and for the underlying tax paid by the distributing subsidiary in the jurisdiction where the foreign entity is located. As a general rule, the foreign tax credit must be calculated separately for each company, with no consolidation allowed for different subsidiaries (i.e. a per-company limitation).

However, Law 12,973/2014 introduced a temporary possibility (until 2022) for consolidating the results derived by controlled subsidiaries with “active income”, provided that certain conditions are met (see section 7.2.2.). In case the results of the controlled companies are consolidated, the foreign tax to be considered is the one related to the taxes paid by the entities which results have been consolidated.

According to Law 12,973/2014, until 2022 Brazilian entities with foreign controlled companies acting in certain business sectors are entitled to a fictitious credit of 9% to be offset against the tax due on the profits of such foreign subsidiaries, provided that certain conditions are met (for details, see section 10.4.).

With regard to foreign branches, the foreign tax credit is subject to a per-country limitation, i.e. the taxes paid by the branch may be consolidated with the taxes paid by other branches located in the same jurisdiction.

For purposes of computing the credit, a qualifying foreign tax is a tax levied on profits and which is paid by the non-resident subsidiary or branch, irrespective of the type of tax imposed by the country concerned.
The credit allowed in a fiscal year may not exceed the amount of tax attributable to the foreign income computed by applying the Brazilian CIT rate to the foreign taxable income.
The amount is converted into BRL according to the exchange rate on the day on which the income is recognized on the books of the Brazilian company.

The document attesting the payment of the tax abroad must be certified by tax authorities of the jurisdiction in which the tax was paid and by the Brazilian Embassy in the relevant country. However, as clarified in Private Ruling 155/2018, the certification is not necessary if the taxpayer demonstrates that, pursuant to the legislation of the other country, the document itself is sufficient proof of payment of the foreign tax.
For double taxation relief in tax treaties signed by Brazil, see section 7.4.1.2.

section.title: Business profits
section.p: General rules outlined in section 7.2.6. apply.

section.title: Dividends
section.p: General rules outlined in section 7.2.6. apply.

section.title: Interest, royalties and other income
section.p: General rules outlined in section 7.2.6. apply.

section.title: Capital gains
section.p: General rules outlined in section 7.2.6. apply.

section.title: General
section.p: For the definition of non-resident company and permanent establishment of a non-resident company, see section 7.1.1. and section 7.1.2. Entities established under foreign law and permanent establishments outside of Brazil are treated as separate taxable persons, in the case of a non-resident of Brazil.

Although Brazil does not refer to the concept of permanent establishment (see section 7.1.2.), for practical reasons the following sections refer to the recognized foreign taxable presences in Brazil (i.e. official representatives (mandatários), commissionaires (comissários), local agents and business units) as permanent establishments.

On 1 July 2021 and 8 October 2021, Brazil signed joint-statements with other Inclusive Framework members with an agreement to implement a two-pillar solution to address the tax challenges arising from the digitalization of the economy. The solution includes a plan to re-allocate part of taxing rights over large and highly profitable enterprises from their home countries to jurisdictions in which goods or services are supplied or consumers are located (market jurisdictions), regardless of whether these enterprises have a physical presence there (Pillar One). This new taxing right for market jurisdictions (the so-called Amount A) would affect multinational groups with a global turnover above EUR 20 billion and profit before tax above 10%. A multilateral convention for implementation of Pillar One and with the requirement to remove all digital service taxes and other relevant similar measures (as well as not to introduce such measures in the future) is expected to be signed (see also section 14.6.4.5.).

section.title: Immigration
section.p: There are no rules regarding valuation of assets in case of immigration. This concept is not envisaged under the current Brazilian legislation.

section.title: General
section.p: Permanent establishments (branches) in Brazil of non-resident persons are taxed as ordinary resident taxpayers and are subject to the same rules as applicable to resident taxpayers for the determination of the taxable income.

Payments made by the permanent establishment to its head office are considered transactions between related parties under article 23 of Law 9,430/1996; therefore, transfer pricing rules and thin capitalization provisions are applicable (see section 10.2.).

Payments made from Brazilian sources to non-resident companies without a permanent establishment in Brazil are subject to withholding income tax at the different rates, depending on the nature of the payment (see section 7.3.4.).

section.title: Business profits
section.p: Permanent establishments (branches) in Brazil are subject to the same rules applicable to resident taxpayers for the determination of the taxable income. Expenses incurred by a permanent establishment are deductible only if incurred by the permanent establishment itself. Expenses incurred by the foreign head office on behalf of the permanent establishment are not deductible under Brazilian legislation. There are no specific rules dealing with allocation of income between head offices and permanent establishments.

In circumstances where the permanent establishment does not maintain the proper accounting books, taxable income is assessed through the determined profit method (lucro arbitrado) – see section 1.2.1. – by applying percentages (ranging from 1.92% to 45% depending on the business activity) on the gross income.

In theory, taxable profit from the direct sale of imported goods through local agents or representatives (a type of agency permanent establishment) (see section 7.1.2.1.) is also determined through the determined profit method. However, this assessment and actual taxation does not happen in practice.

In general, Brazil does not tax business income of non-resident entities through the recognition of permanent establishments and subsequent assessment of attributed profits, but through the application of withholding taxes, such as the one applicable on the outbound payment of service fees (see section 7.3.4.4.1.), which is allowed by most treaties signed by Brazil (see section 7.4.1.6.5.).

section.title: Dividends, interest and royalties
section.p: Permanent establishments of non-resident companies are subject to the same rules applicable to resident companies. There are no specific rules regarding dividends, interest and royalties derived through a permanent establishment.

section.title: Other income
section.p: There are no specific rules for income derived through a permanent establishment. Permanent establishments of non-resident companies are subject to the same rules applicable to resident companies. See section 7.3.4.4. for withholding tax on direct payments to non-residents.

section.title: Capital gains
section.p: Permanent establishments of non-resident companies are subject to the same rules applicable to resident companies. For the treatment of capital gains, see sections 1.7. and 1.10.2.

For withholding tax on direct payment of capital gains to non-resident entities, see section 7.3.4.4.2. However, when both parties (seller and purchaser) are non-resident persons, capital gains from the disposal of assets or rights located in Brazil are subject to tax in Brazil, which must be paid by a registered representative of the non-resident purchaser in Brazil. This representative is legally liable for the collection of the income tax on capital gains due by the non-resident seller.
For indirect transfer of assets, see section 10.6.3.

section.title: Withholding taxes
section.p: Generally, a non-resident entity without a permanent establishment is subject to final withholding income tax. Rates vary depending on the type of income.

Where no special rate is provided, a general final withholding tax rate of 15% on the gross amount applies. In general, payments made to entities residing in low-tax jurisdictions under Brazilian law are subject to withholding income tax at a 25% rate, unless specific rules apply. Resident companies are required to withhold income tax at the maturity date of the debt or at the remittance of the values abroad, whichever occurs first (and not upon recognition of the debt in the accounting records), as confirmed in Appeal Case 1,864,227 at the Superior Court of Justice.

Law 9,481/1997 lists certain payments made to non-resident persons which are subject to a 0% withholding tax rate. The list includes commissions paid by exporters to agents located abroad and certain interest payments (see section 7.3.4.2.). Exemptions are also granted by Law 13,315/2016 to listed services (see section 7.3.4.4.1.).
For treaty rates, see section 7.4.1.5.

section.title: Dividends
section.p: Dividends and other profit distributions paid to non-resident entities out of profits derived as from 1 January 1996 are exempt from income tax. However, the taxation of dividends at source at the rate of 15% is being considered by the National Congress under Bill 2337/2021.

section.title: Interest
section.p: Interest on loans paid to non-resident entities is subject to a general final 15% withholding tax on the gross amount of the payment. Interest paid to entities located in low-tax jurisdictions (see section 10.6.) is subject to withholding tax at a 25% rate. Interest on net equity (see section 1.4.5.) is subject to withholding income tax at a 15% rate on the gross amount (a 25% rate applies if paid to persons located in low-tax jurisdictions).

Interest derived by non-resident companies in connection with investments in Brazilian financial and capital markets, made according to the rules set forth by the National Monetary Commission, is subject to corporate income tax at the rate of 15%.

Interest derived by non-resident companies in connection with investments in Brazilian financial and capital markets is subject to the same rules applicable to resident companies (i.e. at regressive rates ranging from 22.5% to 15%, depending on the lifetime of the transaction – see section 1.10.3.2.) in the following cases:

item.p: if the investment is not made in accordance with the National Monetary Commission; or
if the foreign investor is resident in a low-tax jurisdiction.

section.p: The withholding tax rate is reduced to 0% on income derived by non-resident companies from bonds and securities acquired as of 1 January 2011 and publicly traded by Brazilian legal entities regulated by the CVM or by the National Monetary Commission and classified as non-financial institutions, provided certain conditions are met, including:

item.p: no resale commitment assumed by the buyer; and
no authorization for repurchase by the issuer of the paper in the first 2 years or for early settlement of redemption or prepayment.

section.p: This benefit does not apply to persons in low-tax jurisdictions.

A zero rate benefit applies to income derived by non-resident companies from investment funds that have at least 85% – 67% in the first 2 years – of their portfolio in such bonds and securities, provided certain conditions are met. The zero rate benefit also applies to income from investment funds that have at least:

item.p: 85% (67% in the first 2 years) of their portfolio in debentures issued by legal entities specifically incorporated for the implementation of infrastructure projects or for carrying on research, development and innovation projects (investimentos em pesquisa, desenvolvimento e inovação – PD&I projects); or
95% (67% in the first 2 years) of their portfolio in investment funds meeting the previous requirement.

section.p: There are some other tax exemptions and zero-rated taxes regarding interest paid to non-resident entities, such as the exemption for interest paid on loans granted by non-resident entities, located or not in a low-tax jurisdiction, when such credit is used for the financing of exports (Law 9,481/1997).

section.title: Royalties
section.p: Royalty payments to non-resident entities are subject to a final withholding tax at the rate of 15% on the gross amount (article 767 of the RIR). Royalties paid by resident entities to non-residents as consideration for the transfer of technology, trademarks and patents, and for the supply of technical, administrative or scientific assistance, are also subject to the contribution for intervention in the economic domain (CIDE) – see section 14.6.4.4. This contribution is not subject to any withholding mechanism; rather, it is imposed directly on the Brazilian payer. The CIDE contribution is not imposed on cross-border payments of software licence fees, except for payments involving the acquisition of software rights (transfer of technology).

The payment of royalties does not trigger the payment of ICMS or IPI (Brazilian federal and state VATs). Divergence Ruling 18/2017, published in the DOU of 5 April 2017, determined that outbound payments made by importers for rights over the sale or distribution of software to final consumers in Brazil, who are granted a licence for the use of software, are considered royalties and are thus subject to withholding tax at the rate of 15%. This Divergence Ruling changed the initial understanding of the tax authorities (as expressed in Divergence Ruling 27/2008) that such payments are considered payment for the purchase of goods and therefore only subject to ICMS.
If the beneficiary of the royalties is located in a low-tax jurisdiction (see section 10.6.), the withholding income tax rate is 25%.

Declaratory Interpretative Act 7/17, published in the DOU of 26 December 2017 consolidated the position of the tax authorities on the payments made by Brazilian parties to foreign beneficiaries in consideration for the right to distribute and/or to commercialize software. Accordingly, such payments qualify under Brazilian tax legislation as royalties and are thus subject to withholding tax at the rate of 15% (25% if the beneficiary is resident in a low-tax jurisdiction).

Brazilian tax treaties normally provide that the treatment of technical services and technical assistance fees follows the treatment of royalties. Specific provisions are included for this purpose in the protocols or in declaratory acts issued by the tax authorities after the treaties are signed – for details on the controversy over the topic, see section 7.4.1.6.5.

section.title: Service fees
section.p: Non-residents without presence in Brazil deriving fees from the provision of general services are subject to withholding tax at 25% on the gross amount. In the case of payment for technical services and management fees, the withholding tax rate is reduced to 15%. The Brazilian paying source is in this case required to pay the CIDE contribution, which is imposed at a 10% rate. For details on the CIDE contribution, see section 14.6.4.4. The definition of technical service, which is found in article 17(2)(a) of Normative Instruction 1,455/2014, generally covers services that depend on specialized technical knowledge or that involve technical assistance or consultancy services. According to Private Ruling 99001/2021, the provision of “software as a service” (SaaS) is considered a provision of technical services since it requires specialized knowledge in computer science and results from automated structures with clear technological content; thus it is subject to the 15% final withholding tax.
An exemption applies to outbound payments made to non-resident persons for (Normative Instruction 1,645/2016):

item.p: educational, scientific or cultural purposes, including tuition fees, congress or seminar fees and proficiency exam fees; and
covering medical and hospital expenses related to medical treatment abroad (including treatment of dependants).

section.p: In this respect, Private Ruling 661/2017, published in the DOU of 27 February 2018, clarified that outbound payments to foreign individuals or legal entities for training services offered to professionals who are resident in Brazil are subject to withholding tax at the rate of 15%. These payments are qualified as outbound payments for technical services (the rate is increased to 25% in the case of payments to persons located in low-tax jurisdictions) and not as outbound payments for educational or scientific purposes, which are exempt.

Private Ruling 153/2017, published in the DOU of 22 March 2017, explained that the taxable event triggering withholding tax in the case of payments of service fees to non-resident persons through “income crediting” (crédito de rendimento) occurs upon the recognition of the payment obligation in the accounting records of the paying source in Brazil, provided that the economic or juridical availability of the income is characterized.

Brazilian tax treaties normally provide that the treatment of technical services and technical assistance fees follows the treatment of royalties. Specific provisions are included for this purpose in the protocols or in declaratory acts issued by the tax authorities after the treaties are signed – for details, see section 7.4.1.6.5.

section.title: Capital gains
section.p: Capital gains derived by non-residents are generally withheld at source by the Brazilian payer, unless specific rules apply. Capital gains realized outside of Brazil in transactions involving assets or rights located in Brazil are subject to Brazilian income tax even if the transaction involves only non-resident parties. In this case, the registered representative of the non-resident purchaser in Brazil is legally liable for the collection of the income tax on capital gains due by the non-resident.

With effect from 1 January 2017, Law 13,259/2016 (which resulted from the conversion of Provisional Measure 692/2015) established progressive final rates ranging from 15% to 22.5% applicable to capital gains derived from the disposition of assets by resident individuals (and consequently to non-resident companies, as the tax treatment applicable to non-resident persons in such scenario is the same as the one applicable to individuals), as follows (previously, a general rate of 15% applied):

item.p: 15% on the portion of the gains not exceeding BRL 5,000,000;
17.5% on the portion of the gains amounting to between BRL 5,000,001 and BRL 10,000,000;
20% on the portion of the gains amounting to between BRL 10,000,001 and BRL 30,000,000; and
22.5% on the portion of the gains exceeding BRL 30,000,000.

section.p: If the beneficiary is resident in a low-tax jurisdiction, the applicable rate is 25%.

In the calculation of capital gain, the acquisition cost of the assets in Brazil must be proved. If non-residents are unable to prove referred cost, it is deemed to be zero, as provided by Normative Instruction 1,662/2016.

Gains derived by non-residents as a result of the sale of shares or other securities issued by Brazilian listed entities on the Brazilian stock exchange or on the organized over-the-counter market are exempt from tax, provided that the investments are registered under specific rules and the beneficiary is not located in a low-tax jurisdiction. If these conditions are not met, a 15% rate applies. An exemption under the same conditions also applies to investments made in local private equity funds. Capital gains from investments in stock funds, from swaps and from operations on future markets outside the stock exchange are subject to withholding tax at the rate of 10%.
For indirect transfer of assets, see section 10.6.3.

section.title: Withholding procedure
section.p: Resident companies are required to withhold income tax at the maturity date of the debt or at the remittance of the values abroad, whichever occurs first (and not upon recognition of the debt in the accounting records), as confirmed in the Appeal Case 1,864,227 at the Superior Court of Justice.
In case there is a tax treaty in force, the treaty rate is directly applicable, but the beneficiary generally needs to produce a certificate of residence for these purposes.

In practice, the commercial banks acting on the remittance of the fund abroad will act as gatekeepers requesting a proof of payments for the applicable taxes. Without such proof, they may refuse to process the payment order. Although banks are not personally liable for the taxes, they are still subject to sanctions that may be imposed by the central bank.

section.title: Branch tax
section.p: No branch tax or remittance tax is levied on profits of a permanent establishment in Brazil (article 757 of the RIR).

section.title: Other taxes on income
section.p: There are no other taxes on income. However, some types of service fees paid to non-residents may be subject to the ISS (see section 14.6.4.2.).

section.title: Taxes on capital
section.p: There is no net worth or capital taxes on capital. For real estate taxes, non-resident companies are subject to the municipal tax on real estate (imposto sobre a propriedade territorial urbana, IPTU) and the federal tax on rural land (imposto territorial rural, ITR) – see section 5.3. – only related to real estate located in Brazil.

section.title: Closure of branch/permanent establishment
section.p: Upon liquidation of a branch, the assets registered by the local establishment may be transferred to the non-resident entity, based on their book value or at market value.
If the market value is considered, the difference between the book value and the market value is added to the CIT taxable base and generally subject to tax.

If the book value is considered and such value is compatible with the investment value registered with the Central Bank of Brazil, no withholding income tax applies. If such amount exceeds the investment value, the positive difference is treated as a capital gain and subject to withholding tax at progressive rates (see section 7.3.4.2.) or at a 25% rate if the beneficiary is located in a low-tax jurisdiction (see section 10.6.).

section.title: Administration
section.p: Non-resident entities are not required to file tax returns in Brazil. Non-residents without taxable presence in Brazil are not required to file tax returns. Income tax is normally charged through a withholding tax system.
A non-resident with a branch formally registered in Brazil must self-assess its own income tax liability under the rules applicable to resident companies.

Non-residents owning assets and rights in Brazil (e.g. real estate, vehicles, share participations, bank accounts and investments in the Brazilian financial and capital markets) must register as taxpayers with the Brazilian federal tax authorities. They must also appoint a local representative in Brazil and notify the federal tax authorities of the appointment. Nevertheless, no tax return needs to be filed.
Non-resident entities are not obliged by the Brazilian domestic law to withhold taxes on payments to companies resident in Brazil.

Following the approval of the Brazil-United States FATCA Model 1A Agreement (2014) by the Brazilian Chamber of Deputies, Normative Instruction 1,571/2015, published in the DOU of 3 July 2015 and in force as of that date, regulates the obligation of Brazilian financial institutions to provide information on financial operations to Brazilian tax authorities through the implementation of a digital program for FATCA reporting. Accordingly, Brazilian financial institutions are obliged to provide to the Brazilian Federal Revenue Service information on financial operations and accounts of US citizens and entities through the digital program e-Financeira.

The information received by the Brazilian Federal Revenue Service must be forwarded to the US Internal Revenue Service (IRS), which is committed to proceed in the same manner regarding information on bank accounts held by Brazilian persons in the United States. The e-Financeira is obligatory in respect of events that occurred as of 1 December 2015 and must be filed each semester.

The e-Financeira is also used for the purpose of disclosing financial accounts as a result of the Multilateral Competent Authority Agreement‎ for the Common Reporting Standard (CRS MCAA) on the automatic exchange of financial account information pursuant to the OECD/G20 Common Reporting Standard (CRS), signed by Brazil on 21 October 2016 and implemented through Normative Instruction 1,680/2016.

section.title: Treaty policy
section.p: Brazilian tax treaties generally follow the UN MC and the OECD MC.
For policy on tax sparing credits, see section 7.4.1.6.2.

Law 13,202/2015, published in the DOU of 9 December 2015, clarified that tax treaties signed by Brazil cover the social contribution on net profits (Contribuição Social sobre o Lucro Líquido, CSLL). Although the taxable bases of IRPJ and CSLL are very similar, the "taxes covered" article in tax treaties signed by Brazil expressly covers only IRPJ. Therefore, questions have been raised on whether the treaties signed by Brazil also apply to CSLL, under the "substantially similar taxes" argument. Law 13,202/2015 clarified the matter by setting forth that, for the purpose of interpretation, tax treaties signed by Brazil also apply to CSLL. As expressly stated in the law, this provision has interpretative powers, meaning that its application is retroactive to periods prior to the publication of the law.
For the mutual agreement procedure, see section 1.11.3.
For other relevant aspects in Brazilian tax treaty policy, see section 7.4.1.6.5.

section.title: Treaty relief from double taxation
section.p: Generally, Brazilian tax treaties provide for the ordinary credit method to relieve double taxation; however, a few treaties provide for the exemption method.

section.title: Tax treaties signed but not yet in force
Limitation on benefits provisions
section.p: In the most recent treaties concluded by Brazil an article stipulating that the provisions of the convention do not prevent a contracting state from applying the provisions of its tax law regarding thin capitalization and controlled foreign corporations is normally included. Some treaties also provide additional rules regarding the limitation of benefits deriving from the DTT for parties that do not reside in the contracting states.

section.title: Tax sparing credit
section.p: The effect of tax exemptions granted by some countries to non-resident investors is not intended to be nullified by levies in the investor’s country of residence. To that effect, certain tax treaties of Brazil contain provisions granting a fixed foreign tax credit in the country of residence on certain categories of foreign income paid by a Brazilian source, even if such income is exempt from withholding income tax in Brazil or subject to a low level of taxation under Brazilian law.

Tax-sparing credit is generally provided under tax treaties mainly with regard to interest and royalties arising in Brazil and paid to a resident of the other contracting state. In general, considering that the domestic rates are currently lower than those provided under the treaties, the sparing credit in the jurisdiction of the beneficiary is higher than the withholding income tax paid in Brazil upon the remittance of interest and royalties.

section.title: Special provisions for offshore activities
section.p: No special provisions for offshore activities are provided under Brazilian tax treaties.

section.title: Excluded individuals
section.p: Brazilian tax treaties contain no provisions dealing with excluded individuals. The treaties apply to residents of the contracting states and, as a rule, Brazilian tax treaties contain the standard wording of article 4 of the OECD Model.

section.title: Other special provisions
section.p: Brazilian tax treaties normally provide that other income, income not dealt with specifically in other provisions of the tax treaties, may be taxed at source.

Brazilian tax authorities have historically adopted a restrictive approach regarding the application and interpretation of tax treaties, avoiding or reducing the limitations on Brazilian taxing rights. This position has been highly criticized by the Brazilian legal community and has also raised some concerns from other contracting states with regard to tax treaties concluded with Brazil.

The treaty article that raises the majority of the discussions is article 7 (Business Profits), which generally follows the wording contained in the OECD Model. The Brazilian tax authorities adopt a very restrictive approach in order to deny the application of this treaty provision, which would generally result in the application of withholding taxes on remittances for technical services and technical assistance.

In this respect, Brazil used to apply withholding tax on payments for technical services and assistance not involving the transfer of technology, even when a tax treaty applied, on the basis of Ruling 01/2000. Tax authorities argued that the payment of such income could not be classified as business profit (article 7) but rather as gross income (i.e. before deductions) under Brazilian domestic legislation. Therefore, article 21 of tax treaties signed by Brazil would apply (article 21 in treaties signed by Brazil normally does not follow the OECD Model and grants taxing rights to both the source country and the residence country). This issue has been taken to federal courts and there are decisions supporting both positions. In 2012, the case Copesul reached the Superior Court of Justice, where a unanimous decision was given in favour of the application of the business profit article in the Brazil-Canada Income Tax Treaty (1984) and in the (currently terminated) Brazil-Germany Income and Capital Tax Treaty (1975).

Brazil’s National Treasury Attorney’s Office (PGFN) then issued a significant opinion (PGFN/CAT 2,363/2013), in which it revisited the tax authorities’ long-standing position on the interpretation of the business profits article in tax treaties signed by Brazil in this respect. PGFN expressed its opinion in favour of the application of the business profit article to payments for the provision of technical service and technical assistance without the transfer of technology. On the other hand, the PGFN also suggested that the royalties article is applicable in case of treaties where technical services and technical assistance is covered by this article – most treaties signed with Brazil include “technical services and technical assistance” within the scope of the royalties article (generally by the protocol of treaties).

As a result, on 20 June 2014, tax authorities issued Ruling 05/2014, which revoked Ruling 01/2000, to determine that the provision of technical services and technical assistance (with or without the transfer of technology) is subject to:

item.p: the royalties article, in case of treaties where technical services and technical assistance is covered by this article;

the independent personal services article in respect of the provision of technical services and technical assistance related to the technical capacity of one person or a group of persons (except if the royalties article applies); or
the business article in all remaining cases.

section.p: As a result of the position of the tax authorities, private rulings have been issued confirming (or rejecting) the application of withholding taxes and the qualification of the income under several treaties. For example, on 1 July 2015, Private Letter Ruling 153/2015 was issued in regard to the interpretation and application of the Brazil-France Income Tax Treaty (1971). Accordingly, income paid by Brazilian sources to individual or legal entities resident in France in consideration for technical services or technical assistance, with or without transfer of technology, falls under the business article and therefore is not subject to withholding tax in Brazil. The application of the business article in this case is due to the fact that this treaty neither characterizes payments in consideration for technical services or technical assistance as royalties nor do the services provided in the specific case of the ruling fall within the scope of the provision on independent professional services and independent workers. On 26 May 2020, the Superior Court of Justice confirmed the application of the business profit to the payments made to a service provider resident in France, in the absence of a permanent establishment in Brazil (Special Appeal 1618897).

The same understanding was given by Private Ruling 65/2018, published in the DOU of 28 May 2018, in respect of payments for technical services or technical assistance under the Brazil-Sweden Income Tax Treaty (1975). Private Ruling 155/2016 (Solução de Consulta 155/2016), published in the DOU of 30 November 2016, and Private Ruling 5/2017 (Solução de Consulta 5/2017), published in the DOU of 18 January 2016, confirmed that income paid by Brazilian sources to individual or legal entities resident in Argentina and Canada for technical services or technical assistance, with or without transfer of technology, is subject to withholding tax at a rate of 15% in Brazil according to the protocol of treaties signed with those countries. On 5 December 2018, Private Ruling 2017/2018 clarified that outbound payments for technical services or technical assistance provided by companies resident in Finland are not subject to withholding taxes in Brazil according to the Brazil-Finland Income Tax Treaty (1996). This understanding has been confirmed in Private Rulings 6017/2019 and 99,006/2020.

In July 2020, the Regional Federal Court of the 3rd Region decided that withholding tax applies to outbound payments for the provision of technical services and assistance under the Brazil-Germany tax treaty (no longer effective), the Brazil-Spain tax treaty and the Brazil-Argentina tax treaty (cases 0024442-10.2001.4.03.6100, 5023086-93.2018.4.03.6100 and 0004819-10.2014.4.03.6130, respectively).
For the compatibility of Brazilian CFC rules and tax treaties, see section 10.4.

section.title: Treaties on administrative assistance

entry.p: Mutual administrative assistance and cooperation in customs matters

section.p: Brazil has signed the multilateral Convention on Mutual Administrative Assistance in Tax Matters, as amended by the 2010 protocol. On 1 June 2016, Brazil deposited its instrument of ratification. The convention and the amending protocol entered into force on 1 October 2016 and is effective since 1 January 2017. On 21 October 2016, Brazil joined the MCAA (2016) on the automatic exchange of country-by-country (CbC) reports, which is based on article 6 of the Convention on Mutual Administrative Assistance in Tax Matters, as amended by the 2010 protocol. The agreement was implemented through Normative Instruction 1,681/2016 published in the DOU of 29 December 2016.

On 27 July 2017, the tax authorities of the BRICS countries (Brazil, Russia, India, China (People’s Rep.) and South Africa) signed a Memorandum of Cooperation (MoC) in Hangzhou. The MoC intends to strengthen multilateral tax cooperation between the BRICS countries in order to improve tax compliance and protect tax bases.
On 20 July 2017, Brazil and the United States also concluded a bilateral Competent Authority Agreement for the exchange of CbC reports.

section.title: Foreign account reporting agreements
section.p: On 21 October 2016, Brazil joined the CRS MCAA on the automatic exchange of financial account information pursuant to the OECD/G20 CRS. The agreement was implemented through Normative Instruction 1,680/2016, published in the DOU of 29 December 2016. The agreement is effective as of 1 January 2017.
Brazil has also signed an intergovernmental agreement to improve international tax compliance with respect to the US Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) – see section 7.4.3.1.

section.title: Foreign account reporting agreements not signed
Transportation (tax) treaties
section.p: The following transportation tax treaties are currently effective:

section.title: Inheritance and gift tax treaties
section.p: Brazil has not concluded inheritance and gift tax treaties.

section.title: Social security agreements
section.p: Brazil has signed and ratified the Ibero-American Organisation Social Security Treaty (2007) between Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Paraguay, Peru, Portugal, Spain, Uruguay and Venezuela. The treaty is in force as of 1 May 2011 and became effective for Brazil on 1 August 2011, following the signature of the Implementation Agreement on 19 May 2011 (as requested by article 31(1) of the treaty).

The treaty becomes effective for countries as from the date of signature of the Implementation Agreement. To date, the following countries have ratified the treaty and signed the Implementation Agreement: Argentina (31 May 2016), Bolivia (18 April 2011), Brazil (19 May 2011), Chile (1 September 2011), Ecuador (20 June 2011), El Salvador (17 November 2012), Paraguay (28 October 2011), Peru (20 October 2016), Portugal (23 July 2012), Spain (13 October 2010) and Uruguay (26 July 2011).
Brazil has also signed and ratified the MERCOSUR Social Security Treaty (1997) with Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay. The treaty is in force and effective as of 1 June 2005.
In addition, the following bilateral social security agreements concluded by Brazil are effective:

section.title: Group Taxation
section.p: There is no group taxation regime in Brazil.

section.title: Change of business entity
section.p: The conversion of companies from one kind (such as a limited liability company) to another (such as a joint-stock company) has no tax implications.

A change of business activity, on its own, has no effects on the company’s accumulated tax losses. However, a change of business activity combined with a change of control implies the impossibility of future enjoyment of the tax losses previously accrued.

section.title: Companies
section.p: Assets and rights transferred by a legal entity as a result of a merger or division (such as a spin-off) may be valued at either their book value or fair market value, at the discretion of the company. If the fair market value is adopted, the difference between the book value and the fair market value is treated as a capital gain to the company and subject to CIT (see section 2.3.1.).
The company resulting from a merger is liable to the taxes due by the former companies up to the date of such merger.

A company undergoing a merger or division must prepare a balance sheet and other financial reports and calculate its taxable profit up to the date on which the merger or division occurs (separately from the financial reports from the previous taxable period).

Each company must file a separate tax return and pay any tax due at the time of the reorganization, unless the merged and the merging entities were under common control since the tax year prior to the merger event, the situation in which only the merged entity is required to file a return. In any case, one of the merging companies may not reduce its tax liability by deducting the outstanding losses of another. However, in the case of a partial division, the company that is divided may offset its own tax losses in the proportion to the equity it retains after the division.

section.title: Shareholders
section.p: In general, there are no tax consequences to the shareholders with regard to mergers and divisions. The shareholder of the merged entity, as a general rule, receives a shareholding interest of the company surviving the merger and books such investment based on the same acquisition cost previously registered in connection with the merged company.

In a partial split, the acquisition cost of the shareholder in connection with the entity subject to the split corresponds to the percentage of the equity of the company that remained after the spin-off, applied to the original acquisition cost registered for such entity. The difference in the acquisition cost is migrated to the cost to be registered in connection with the investment in the company resulting from the split.

As highlighted in section 9.2.1., mergers and divisions may have tax consequences to the company, whenever the assets of the entity object of the corporate transaction are valued at any amount higher than book value (situation where a taxable capital gain is derived by the company). This, however, does not affect the shareholders.

section.title: Companies
section.p: In general, there are no direct tax consequences to the company that was acquired by another entity or individual (i.e. the change of control of a given company does not affect such entity).

The only aspect that is important to be considered is that if there is a change of control of the company cumulated with a change in the business activity of that same company, such entity will lose the right to enjoy its operating tax losses. See section 1.8.1.

section.title: Shareholders
section.p: If the value received by the shareholder, in cash or in kind, for the shares previously held in a company is higher than the acquisition cost registered in relation to said investment, the shareholder will derive a taxable capital gain (comprised of the positive difference between the acquisition cost and the disposition value).

Capital gains derived by legal entities are subject to CIT at a maximum aggregate 34% rate. See section 1.7. Capital gains derived by resident individuals are subject to individual income tax at a 15% rate.

section.title: Purchase of an existing business
section.p: There are no specific tax rules applied to the purchase of an existing business.

From the perspective of the tax succession rules, if a company acquires the going concern of another entity, it will have subsidiary liability for the tax debts of that entity directly connected with the acquired going concern. The subsidiary liability means that tax authorities may only charge the entity that acquired the going concern after actions were first addressed to the entity that sold the going concern and is the effective taxpayer.

section.title: Company
section.p: See section 6.1.8.

section.title: Shareholders
section.p: Income tax is levied on the amount distributed to shareholders in excess of the value of the share capital initially invested. Profits exempt from tax and other income already taxed but not yet distributed are not subject to tax.

section.title: General anti-avoidance rules
section.p: In 2001, general anti-avoidance rules were introduced for both domestic and international transactions (article 116 of the National Tax Code). Tax authorities may disregard transactions carried out with the purpose of hiding taxable events or of modifying the tax liability. The general anti-avoidance rule requires further regulation by an ordinary law to set conditions, criteria and procedures to be followed by tax authorities. Such regulation has not yet been enacted, which triggered discussions regarding the limits of what is considered legal in tax planning and the need for a case-by-case analysis by the tax authorities.

Nevertheless, although there are no statutory provisions currently applicable authorizing tax authorities to disregard transactions, such approach has been repeatedly adopted mainly on the basis of the concept of simulation existing in article 167 of the Civil Code and in article 149 (7) of the National Tax Code. Indeed, there is a current trend of Brazilian tax authorities and the tax courts to disregard structures lacking economic substance and business purpose (e.g. administrative decisions 9101-002.429, 1201-001.640/2017 and 9101-002.392/2016, issued by the CSRF).

On 20 April 2022, the Federal Supreme Court ruled that the general anti-avoidance rule in article 116 of the National Tax Code is constitutional but may only apply in the case of sham or fraud and cannot be applied to disregard businesses legitimately carried out by taxpayers. The power to disregard acts or business transactions provided by this article is thus limited to legal acts or transactions carried out with the intention of dissimulating or concealing a tax-triggering event.

Specific anti-avoidance rules apply under Brazilian legislation, i.e. special tax treatment for outbound payments to residents in low-tax jurisdictions, transfer pricing, thin capitalization and CFC rules.

topic.title: Special tax treatment for outbound payments to residents in low-tax jurisdictions
topic.p: Payments of certain types of income (e.g. interest and royalties), as well as capital gains earned by entities resident in low-tax jurisdictions, are generally subject to withholding tax at the rate of 25%. Also, certain tax benefits, which are generally available to non-residents of Brazil, are not granted to parties located in low-tax jurisdictions.
For the deductibility of payments made to legal entities located in low-tax jurisdictions, see section 10.6.
For the definition of low-tax jurisdiction and privileged tax regime, see section 10.6.1.

section.title: Statutory framework
section.p: The transfer pricing rules adopted by Brazil in 1996 – with new rules introduced by Law 12,715/2012 – deviate from the OECD Transfer Pricing Guidelines. Despite generally following the methodology suggested by the OECD Guidelines, Brazilian law adopted fixed margins for the various methods, regardless of the specific situation of the taxpayer or peculiarities of the business. The criteria for searching for and adopting comparables are not clearly regulated. The transfer pricing rules expressly authorize only two comparability factors: specific contractual terms and some differences in characteristics of similar products, services or rights. In addition, there is not much leeway for advance pricing agreement (APA) procedures. The related-party test covers various relationships and is not restricted to associated enterprises.

Transfer pricing rules apply to transactions between related parties. However, transactions between a Brazilian resident and a company resident in a low-tax jurisdiction or benefiting from a privileged tax regime (see section 10.6.1.) are subject to Brazilian transfer pricing rules, irrespective of whether the two parties qualify as associated enterprises.

Brazilian transfer pricing rules currently do not apply to cross-border payments of trademark or patent royalties, nor to fees payable as compensation for the transfer of technology or for the rendering of technical, administrative or scientific assistance services. Such transactions should be registered with the INPI and the Brazilian Central Bank.

Under Normative Instruction 1,312/2012, Brazilian transfer pricing rules also apply to intercompany back-to-back transactions, even if the goods or services do not enter or leave the country, that is, even if there is no effective import or export transaction, but the transaction is carried out by a Brazilian company and a foreign affiliated company.

topic.title: Future changes to Brazilian transfer pricing system
topic.p: On 28 February 2018, the OECD and Brazil launched a joint project examining the similarities and gaps between the Brazilian and OECD approaches to valuing cross-border transactions between associated firms for tax purposes. The project also assesses the potential for Brazil to move closer to the OECD’s transfer pricing rules. The alignment of Brazilian transfer pricing rules with the OECD policy is considered an important step for any future process of accession to the organization, as on 29 May 2017 Brazil presented an official request for initiating a process to join the OECD.

On 11 July 2019, a joint statement by the OECD and Brazil on the transfer pricing project was issued. The assessment of the strengths and weaknesses of existing transfer pricing rules and administrative practices:

item.p: identified 30 issues in the Brazilian transfer pricing framework;
tested the issues identified against the policy objectives of transfer pricing rules; and

revealed that (i) a large number of the gaps or issues identified lead to instances of double taxation and create BEPS risks, leading to potential loss of revenue; (ii) significant international tax uncertainty results from the misalignment of rules; and (iii) despite unintended negative consequences, the Brazilian system is characterized by its ability to bring simplicity and practicability to the process of performing a transfer pricing analysis, such as the possibility of overcoming challenges related to the lack of comparables and profitability levels, predictability and domestic certainty, requirement of only limited administrative and financial resources, and involvement of reduced costs and time – all of these leading to the ease of tax administration and tax compliance.

topic.p: Two options for greater alignment with the OECD Transfer Pricing Guidelines were explored and developed in the key final deliverable of the project. The first option seeks to immediately align Brazilian transfer pricing rules with the OECD Guidelines. The second option discusses the same process, but structured into stages of gradual implementation over a longer period of time. According to the joint statement, the most appropriate approach for a gradual alignment would be “to set the conditions for a progressive transition of bringing taxpayers into the new system in the short term, which could for instance be based on a specific threshold and initially concern the largest taxpayers operating in Brazil, and, thereafter, by lowering the threshold based on an analysis of the population of taxpayers, as many times as deemed necessary (in the longer term)”. Both options consider how to maintain a number of elements of simplification, which provide ease of tax administration, ease of tax compliance and tax certainty (i.e. the fixed margins approach – for example, in the form of carefully tailored safe harbours or rebuttable presumptions).

The joint statement also concluded that the time is ripe to make political decisions regarding whether to align and how this alignment should be carried out, and that the specific implementation needs of Brazil will be important in considering the way forward. With the objective of aiding this process of political decision-making and planning of the possible implementation, a blueprint or implementation roadmap is to be developed, outlining the key areas to be addressed.

On 18 December 2019, a joint report was issued with proposals for a “full and immediate alignment” (i.e. immediately aligning the Brazilian transfer pricing rules with the OECD standard, including the arm's length principle and the guidance for its application contained in the OECD Guidelines and other relevant guidance, and making the new rules and regulations applicable to all taxpayers immediately) and for a “full and gradual alignment” (involving the same process, but structured in stages so as to allow for the gradual implementation of the new and/or amended provisions over a longer period of time) of the Brazilian transfer pricing rules with the OECD standard. A partial alignment was also considered, but eventually dismissed by the report as a viable option. Partial alignment would imply that significant gaps remain in the system, which may have negative effects on tax certainty and the compliance burden, as well as carrying risks of persistent double taxation and loss of tax revenue.

On 30 July 2020, the OECD and the Brazilian tax authorities launched a survey for taxpayers with business interest in Brazil as well as other stakeholders to give input regarding the development of safe harbours as well as other simplification measures that can contribute to enhanced tax certainty. The survey included questions on the identification of situations where specific safe-harbour regimes may be needed and the use of the available comparables and of APAs.

On 12 April 2022, the tax authorities and the OECD presented the main features of a new transfer pricing system for Brazil. The new system will be composed of rules addressing the general principles that apply to transfer pricing, which would be in line with the OECD standards. In addition, it will provide rules on specific types of transactions (e.g. intangibles, financial transactions) and on certain topics that are relevant from a transfer pricing perspective (e.g. royalties).
The main features of the new transfer pricing system are the following:

item.p: incorporation of the arm's length principle in Brazilian legislation;
a new scope of application of transfer pricing rules. Rules in force only apply to import, export and loans, but the new legislation will apply to all types of transactions;
introduction of a definition of "related parties", as well as a list of situations that will fall under this definition (e.g. parent companies, subsidiaries);
rules on the delineation of transactions, based on relevant characteristics (functions performed, assets involved, risks borne, contractual terms, business strategies and market conditions);

introduction of the transactional net margin method and profit split method in Brazilian legislation. The application of other methods will also be authorized (e.g. the valuation method in the case of unique and valuable intangibles);

introduction of a rule on the application of the most appropriated method, according to the characteristics of the relevant transaction, availability of information and degree of comparability between the transaction under review and transactions carried out between non-related parties. Currently, taxpayers may freely choose the method to be applied;
choice of tested party, either domestic or foreign, when it is relevant for the application of the specific method;

a comparability analysis will be at the centre of transfer pricing. The new system will provide guidance on comparability. Participants pointed out that, at present, a comparability analysis is partially present in Brazilian legislation, but there are some limitations in its application (e.g. comparability factors to be considered and application of fixed margins);

on transfer pricing adjustments: the tax authorities will be authorized to make primary adjustments in case of non-compliance with the arm's length principle. Secondary adjustments would be made to address consequences of profit shifting. The new system will include the possibility of making corresponding adjustments in the case of the application of MAP mechanisms to reduce double taxation;

on commodities transactions: the new system will focus on the application of the arm's length principle. The ultimate objective of the new rules will be to capture the market value of the commodity. The new system will provide the possibility of performing comparability adjustments supported by evidence. The date of conclusion of the transaction will be accepted by the Revenue Service if it is aligned with market practices and duly supported by documentary evidence;

on intangibles: the new system will provide general guidelines and will define intangibles for transfer pricing purposes. It will also introduce the DEMPE functions for allocation of income, and include guidance on how to deal with transactions related to unique and valuable intangibles (e.g. the use of valuation methods). Royalty deductibility limitation rules will be reviewed to ensure their effectiveness as an anti-avoidance measure;
introduction of rules on intra-group services, including safe harbour rules for low-value-adding services;
introduction of rules on cost contribution arrangements;
introduction of specific rules on business restructurings;

on scope of financial transactions: current legislation in Brazil only applies to loan transactions and interest paid under such loans. The new system will expand this scope to cover all types of financial transactions carried out between related parties (e.g. cash pooling and guarantees);
on tax certainty: legislation will design safe harbours in line with economic reality and the Revenue Service will be authorized to conclude advance pricing agreements; and

obligation to prepare a Master File and a Local File in addition to the country-by-country report currently foreseen in legislation. Additionally, a new penalty system in line with these new obligations will be implemented.

topic.p: The next step of the project includes consultations with different sectors, in particular with industries that will be the most affected by this new system. A bill proposal will then be submitted to the National Congress. Subsequently, implementation aspects will be addressed by the Revenue Service to provide more legal certainty (e.g. compliance aspects, dispute prevention, simplification measures, safe harbours and adoption of regulations).

section.title: Documentation and disclosure requirements (including penalties)
section.p: Law 9,430/96 provides that the average costs and prices must be ascertained through (i) official publications and reports issued by the government of the buyer or the seller, (ii) a statement from the tax authorities of such countries, in cases where Brazil has an exchange of information agreement with the other country and (iii) research by companies or organizations of undeniable technical knowledge or technical publications, which specify the sector, the period, the companies analysed and the margin determined, as well as identifying – per company – the collected data. These reports and research will be accepted as evidence only if, in the course of their preparation, international evaluation methods were respected and the reports and research refer to a time contemporaneous to that of the relevant income tax liability.
Documents presented by the taxpayer may be disqualified by an official order of the Federal Revenue Service if they are deemed to be inadequate or inconsistent.

Under article 43 of Normative Ruling 1,312/12, the only documents that are deemed adequate to serve as proof are price publications resulting from researches conducted under the responsibility of international organizations such as the World Trade Organization or the OECD. However, publications may be disqualified by the Secretary of Revenue if they are deemed to be inconsistent or untrue.

Brazilian law adopts absolute and relative assumptions, which is to say that, whenever transactions occur among associated entities, the taxpayer must prove through one of the predetermined methods that the agreed consideration respected the arm’s length principle.

Brazilian law does not specify the documents required from taxpayers. It is merely necessary that the taxpayer provide the necessary documentation to prove that the agreed consideration in the transaction is in line with the arm’s length principle. From a practical perspective, taxpayers usually provide sales agreements, invoices, income tax returns and spreadsheets as supporting documentation. Any documentation in a foreign language must be translated into Portuguese by a sworn translator.

There are no specific transfer pricing-related penalty charges in Brazil. There are, however, general penalties for underpayment of corporate income tax (see section 1.11.5.). Therefore, upon a tax audit, if the tax authorities take the position that a transfer pricing adjustment was not calculated correctly and, therefore, there was an underpayment of corporate income tax, the above penalties and interest will be applicable to such tax difference.

topic.title: CbC reporting
topic.p: Normative Instruction 1,681/2016 provided for the CbC reporting obligation for any final holding company of multinational groups that is resident for tax purposes in Brazil and whose economic group has earned consolidated revenues higher than BRL 2.26 billion or EUR 750 million in the fiscal year prior to the fiscal year of the report.

Through the CbC reporting, the Brazilian Revenue Service will have access to information aggregated by each jurisdiction in which the multinational group operates, comprising the following items: (i) consolidated revenues, segregating those obtained in transactions with related and unrelated parties; (ii) income or losses before income tax; (iii) income tax and, in the case of Brazil, also the amount of CSLL paid; (iv) the income tax outstanding; (v) the capital stock; (vi) retained earnings; (vii) the number of employees, workers and other associates; and (viii) tangible assets different than cash and cash equivalents. In addition, the reporting entity shall identify: (i) each entity that is a member of the multinational group and its jurisdiction of residence for tax purposes; (ii) the place of incorporation (only when the tax residence does not correspond to the place of incorporation); and (iii) the nature of its main economic activities.

Multinational companies that are obliged to fill in the CbC report must provide information from the economic group to the Brazilian Revenue Service, which will exchange this information with the other countries under the joined the MCAA (2016) on the automatic exchange of CbC reports (signed on 21 October 2016). On 20 July 2017, Brazil and the United States also concluded a bilateral Competent Authority Agreement for the exchange of CbC reports. On 27 November 2018, the tax authorities initiated the exchange of CbC reports with other jurisdictions.

section.title: Transfer pricing methods and practice
section.p: Although based on the OECD Guidelines, as expressly recognized by the reasoning (Exposição de Motivos) of Law 9,430/2000, as presented by the Brazilian Congress, the Brazilian transfer pricing rules deviate from the OECD Guidelines in several aspects. Despite generally following the methodology suggested by the OECD Guidelines, Brazilian law adopted fixed margins for the various methods, regardless of the specific situation of the taxpayer or peculiarities of the business (i.e. no functional analysis is provided for under Brazilian transfer pricing rules). The criteria for searching for and adopting comparables are not clearly regulated. The transfer pricing rules expressly authorize only two adjustments to allow the comparability of transactions: specific contractual terms and some differences in characteristics of similar products, services or rights. In addition, there are no APA procedures. The related-party test covers several relationships and is not restricted to associated enterprises. On 28 February 2018, the OECD and Brazil launched a joint project to assess the potential for Brazil to move closer to the OECD’s transfer pricing rules – for details, see section 10.2.1.

From a litigation perspective, Brazilian tax authorities started focusing on this issue and some assessments were brought against taxpayers in recent years. Litigation precedents have not yet been consolidated to address firm guidance that can be simply adopted by companies searching for an ideal transfer pricing methodology in Brazil.

Brazilian transfer pricing methods vary, depending on the type of transactions, i.e. import or export. For example, a resident entity receiving royalty payments from abroad is considered to have performed an export.

topic.title: Transfer pricing rules for import transactions
topic.p: Under Brazilian transfer pricing rules, there are currently four methods for determining the price limit for products, services or rights imported by Brazilian companies from related parties:

item.p: Comparable uncontrolled price: based on the average price of identical or similar products or services applied in purchase and sale transactions carried out in either the internal or external market under similar payment conditions. Under Law 12,715/2012, as of January 2013, if the comparable is based on transactions performed by the taxpayer himself, those operations must represent at least 5% of the total amount of import transactions carried out with related parties in the same tax year. If the transactions in that given year do not reach the 5% threshold, the taxpayer may also consider the transactions performed in the previous year, adjusted by currency fluctuations.
