Resale price less profit margin method: up to December 2012, the method is based on the average resale price of the goods applied by the importer in transactions with independent parties, less unconditional discounts, taxes, brokerage fees and profit margin of (i) 60% of the resale price of the final product, less the deductions mentioned above and less costs aggregated in Brazil by the importer, in case of imported goods used in the production process, or (ii) 20% of the resale price of the imported good, in general. As of 2013, the profit margin to be considered under the resale price method does not change in view of the destination of the product – simple resale or manufacturing – being fixed for both cases. The margin is linked to the economic sector of the importer, as follows:

entry.p: Optical, photographic and cinematographic equipment and tools
Dental, hospital or medical machines, devices and equipment

item.p: Cost-plus method: based on the average production cost of identical or similar products, services or rights in the jurisdiction in which such products, services or rights were originally produced, increased by taxes paid in such jurisdiction and with a fixed profit margin of 20% of the cost net of taxes.

Quote price for imports: based on the average price of the daily medium quotes of products and rights subject to a public price, based on internationally known stock exchanges, adjusted by the applicable premiums. This method is mandatory for commodities with public prices in commodities and future exchanges. Law 12,715/2012 (which introduced such method) authorized its application to goods without prices in commodities and future exchanges, in relation to which the prices could be compared to those from independent data sources provided by internationally known research institutes. For the purposes of this method, commodities are those defined by law and listed in the annexes of Normative Instruction 1,312/2012, as amended by Normative Instruction 1,395/2013. Such administrative rule also defines the eligible stock exchanges for the purposes of applying the method.

topic.p: If more than one method applies, the company may elect the method resulting in the highest import price in order to prove its compliance with Brazilian transfer pricing rules. If the average price paid by the Brazilian importer exceeds the average price determined under these methods, a transfer pricing adjustment is required and, as a consequence, the amount paid in excess will be added to the taxable base of the importer and subject to CIT. Conversely, if the average price paid by the Brazilian importer is less than the price determined under Brazilian transfer pricing rules, no tax adjustment is required.

topic.title: Transfer pricing rules for export transactions
topic.p: Whenever the average sales price of goods, services or rights exported by a Brazilian company in a taxable year is less than 90% of the average price applied in sales of the same goods, services or rights by such company in the domestic market within the same taxable year and under similar payment conditions, the price of those goods, services or rights will be validly determined by the tax authorities under one of the five methods established by Brazilian law. The applicable methods are:

item.p: Comparable uncontrolled price: based on the average price of identical or similar services, products or rights practised by a Brazilian company with foreign independent parties, in the same taxable year and under similar payment conditions.

Wholesale price in the country of destination, less profit margin: based on the average sales price of identical or similar products, applied in the wholesale market of the country of destination of the exported products, under similar payment conditions, less local taxes and less a 15% fixed profit margin for the wholesale transaction.

Retail price in the country of destination less profit margin: based on the average sales price of identical or similar products, applied in the retail market of the country of destination of the exported products, less taxes and less a 30% fixed profit margin.

Acquisition or production cost, plus taxes and profit margin: based on the average acquisition or production costs of the exported products, services or rights, increased by Brazilian taxes and with a 15% fixed profit margin, calculated on costs and taxes.

Quote price for exports: based on the average price of the daily medium quotes of products and rights subject to a public price, based on internationally known stock exchanges, adjusted by the applicable premiums. This method is mandatory for commodities with public prices in commodities and future exchanges. Law 12,715/2012 (which introduced such method) authorized its application to goods without prices in commodities and future exchanges, in relation to which the method must be adopted based on independent data sources provided by internationally known research institutes. For the purposes of this method, commodities are those defined by law and listed in the annexes of Normative Instruction 1,312/2012. Such administrative rule also defines the eligible stock exchanges for the purposes of applying the method.

topic.p: Brazilian law adopts some safe harbour rules for transfer pricing of export transactions. Under the first general safe harbour rule, which is expressly provided by the law, a taxpayer is deemed to have applied an appropriate transfer price when the average export sales price is at least 90% of the average domestic sales in the Brazilian market during the same period and under similar payment terms. A second safe harbour allows, as a general rule, a difference of up to 5% between the actual price and the comparable price. In the case of commodities, a difference of up to 3% is accepted between the parameter price obtained through the use of PCI (price under import quotation) and PCEX (price under export quotation) methods and the tested price.

Two other safe harbours aim at simplifying the application of the transfer pricing rules (these two other safe harbours are not considered true safe harbours because the tax authorities remain required to observe the transfer pricing methods and may, in theory, assess the taxpayers). The first establishes that if the exporter is able to prove that the net commercial profit derived from the export transaction is equal to at least 10% of the export income, based on the annual averages of the calendar year and the two last taxable periods, and provided that the net export revenue to related entities does not exceed 20% of the total net export revenue, the exporter may prove the appropriateness of its transfer pricing exclusively based on the export transaction documents. The other safe harbour rule provides that if the exporter is able to prove that the net export income does not exceed 5% of the total net income in the same calendar year, the exporter may prove the appropriateness of its transfer pricing exclusively based on the export transaction documents. Both safe harbour rules are not applicable to the transactions subject to the quote price for exports method.

If more than one method applies, the company may adopt the one resulting in the lower export price. If the average price applied by the Brazilian company in its export transactions exceeds the average price obtained under the above-mentioned methods, no adjustment is required. Conversely, if the average price applied by the Brazilian company is lower than the price obtained under the above-mentioned methods, a transfer pricing adjustment is required and, thus, the existing difference will be added to the taxable base.

On 24 September 2008, the Brazilian Revenue Service issued Administrative Rule 222 (Portaria 222), by means of which new regulations were issued for Brazilian corporate taxpayers willing to claim changes on the predetermined profit margins provided for by the Brazilian transfer pricing methods, as reviewed above. Under these regulations, the claim can be made by a corporate taxpayer individually or by a trade union/business class association. The claim must be supported by several documents established by the mentioned rule. No request can be presented for past taxable periods. There are no public cases in which a change of margins was accepted by tax authorities.

topic.title: Transfer pricing rules for cross-border loans
Inbound loans
topic.p: In the case of intercompany loans not registered with the Central Bank of Brazil, interest expenses payable by Brazilian companies in favour of non-resident related parties or entities located in low-tax jurisdictions or privileged tax regimes are deductible for corporate income tax purposes up to the amount determined by the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate (LIBOR), increased with a 3% annual spread. As all loans entering into Brazil must be registered with the Central Bank of Brazil, this provision does not have practical implications.

However, under the current transfer pricing rules, interest payments made to non-resident related parties or to persons located in a low-tax jurisdiction or benefiting from a privileged tax regime are only deductible up to the amount calculated on the basis of the rates established below, in addition to a spread determined by the Brazilian Ministry of Finance (article 249 of Decree 9,580/2018 and article 22 of Law 9,430/1996):

item.p: the rate of Brazilian sovereign bonds issued in USD in foreign markets, in case of transactions in USD subject to a fixed interest rate;
the rate of Brazilian sovereign bonds issued in BRL in foreign markets, in case of transactions in BRL subject to a fixed interest rate; and
LIBOR for a period of 6 months, in all other cases.

topic.title: Outbound loans
topic.p: In relation to outbound loans, taxpayers are required to recognize for CIT purposes a minimum interest revenue based on the same parameters outlined above, i.e. LIBOR for USD deposits with a 3% annual spread for agreements executed up to 31 December 2012 and different rates, depending on the characteristics of the transaction, for agreements executed as of 1 January 2013.
Ordinance 427/2013 defined that, when determining the minimum revenue amount to be recognized, the annual spread shall be 2.5%.

Finally, Brazilian transfer pricing rules currently do not apply to cross-border payments of trademark or patent royalties, nor to fees payable as compensation for the transfer of technology or for the rendering of technical, administrative or scientific assistance services, which are subject to specific deductibility limits and requirements.

Transactions between a Brazilian company and a company resident in a low-tax jurisdiction or benefiting from a privileged tax regime (see section 10.6.) are subject to Brazilian transfer pricing rules, irrespective of whether the two parties qualify as related parties.

section.title: Corresponding adjustments
section.p: There are no specific transfer pricing rules in this regard.

section.title: Secondary adjustments
section.p: There are no specific transfer pricing rules in this regard.

section.title: Thin capitalization rules
section.p: Brazilian thin capitalization rules are set forth by Law 12,249/2010, under articles 24 and 25. Accordingly, deductibility restrictions for CIT purposes apply with regard to interest payments made in connection with (i) loans granted by related persons (article 24) and (ii) loans granted by (related or unrelated) persons located in low-tax jurisdictions or benefiting from privileged tax regimes, as classified under Brazilian tax law (article 25).

Under Brazilian thin capitalization rules, interest paid by a Brazilian company to a foreign related party (individual or legal entity) who is neither located in low-tax jurisdiction nor benefiting from a privileged tax regime may be deducted for CIT purposes only if the interest expense is necessary for the company’s activities and the following thresholds are cumulatively met (article 250 of Decree 9,580/2018 and article 24 of Law 12,249/2010):

item.p: in situations in which the related party holds an interest in the Brazilian entity, the value of the indebtedness towards such creditor does not exceed two times the value of the equity stake held by said investor in the equity of the Brazilian subsidiary (i.e. the debt must be lower than 200% of the equity value of the investment);

in situations in which the related party does not hold an interest in the Brazilian entity, the value of the indebtedness towards such creditor does not exceed two times the value of the capital of the Brazilian company (i.e. the debt must be lower than 200% of the value of the capital); and

in all aforementioned cases the overall indebtedness of the Brazilian company with related parties abroad does not exceed two times the equity value stake of the Brazilian company held by all related parties (i.e. total indebtedness lower than 200% of the equity stake held by all related parties). However, in the case of indebtedness exclusively with related persons abroad that do not hold interest in the Brazilian company, the overall indebtedness of the Brazilian company with all such related parties must not exceed two times the value of the capital of the Brazilian company).

section.p: Interest paid by a Brazilian entity to a foreign creditor (related or not) resident in a low-tax jurisdiction or benefiting from a privileged tax regime may be deducted for CIT purposes only if: (i) the interest expense is necessary for the company’s activities and (ii) the amount of the Brazilian entity’s indebtedness to all entities located in low-tax jurisdictions or benefiting from privileged tax regimes does not exceed 30% of the equity of the Brazilian borrower (article 251 of Decree 9,580/2018 and article 25 of Law 12,249/2010).
In cases where thresholds are not met, the exceeding amount of interest paid will not be considered necessary for the company’s activities and, therefore, will not be deductible for CIT purposes.

For purposes of determining the total indebtedness, all financing forms must be considered, regardless of their registration with the Central Bank of Brazil. With regard to the deductibility of interest expense, interest payments exceeding the limits outlined above are not allowed as deductible expenses for CIT purposes (i.e. only the proportion of interest higher than the limit is considered non-deductible for CIT purposes).
Brazilian thin capitalization rules do not bring any other tax consequences, apart from the restrictions on interest deductibility.

section.title: Limitation on the deductibility of interest on net equity
section.p: In addition to dividends, a company may elect to make a payment of JCP – see section 1.4.9.3.

Under Laws 9,249/1995, the Brazilian legal entity is allowed to deduct from its CIT base the JCP amount paid or credited to the shareholder. Under Law 9,249/1995 and the regulations issued by the Brazilian Revenue Service (article 75 of Normative Instruction 1,700/2017), two limiting criteria must be observed for purposes of calculating and deducting JCP:

item.p: the first criterion refers to the amount payable as JCP. Such amount must be determined based on the pro rata variation of the TJLP (long-term interest rate published by the Central Bank of Brazil) applied to the equity accounts of the corporate taxpayer (capital, capital reserve, profits reserve, etc.); and
under the second criterion, the deductibility of JCP expenses is limited to the higher of (i) 50% of the current year’s net profit or (ii) 50% of the company’s total retained earnings accounts.

section.p: The general limitation applicable to outbound remittances made from Brazil to persons located in a low-tax jurisdiction or benefiting from a privileged tax regime (i.e. deductibility conditioned to the fulfilment of certain requirements – see section 10.3.3. and 10.6.1.) is not applicable to JCP.

section.title: Limitation on the deductibility of payment of interest to persons in low-tax jurisdiction or benefiting from a privileged tax regime
section.p: As a general rule for all outbound remittances made from Brazil (therefore covering also outbound payment of interest), payments made to persons located in a low-tax jurisdiction or benefiting from a privileged tax regime are only deductible if (i) the identification of the beneficial owner of the payment is provided; (ii) the proof that the beneficiary carries out the activity for which it is paid is provided; and (iii) documents that can indicate the payment and the receipt of the good, service or right are provided (article 252 of Decree 9,580/2018 and article 26 of Law 12,249/2010) – see section 10.6.1.

section.title: Limitation on deductibility of interest under transfer pricing rules
section.p: Under Brazilian transfer pricing rules, interest payments made to non-resident related parties or to persons located in a low-tax jurisdiction or benefiting from a privileged tax regime are only deductible up to a the amount calculated on the basis of the rates established below, in addition to a spread determined by the Brazilian Ministry of Finance (article 249 of Decree 9,580/2018 and article 22 of Law 9,430/1996) (see section 10.2.3.):

item.p: the rate of Brazilian sovereign bonds issued in USD in foreign markets, in case of transactions in USD subject to a fixed interest rate;
the rate of Brazilian sovereign bonds issued in BRL in foreign markets, in case of transactions in BRL subject to a fixed interest rate; and
LIBOR for a period of 6 months, in all other cases.

section.title: Controlled foreign company
section.p: Under the current Brazilian CFC rules, in force as of 1 January 2015 (as introduced by Law 12,973/2014 and regulated by Normative Instruction 1,520/2014), profits of (directly and indirectly) controlled foreign companies (and of foreign permanent establishments) are converted into BRL and added to the results of the Brazilian legal parent for tax purposes (corporate income tax and CSLL) in proportion to the ownership percentage, regardless of actual distribution, irrespective of the jurisdiction in which the controlled foreign company is located and irrespective of whether profits arose from active or passive activities. Profits of affiliated companies abroad may be also added to the results of the Brazilian entity if certain requirements are not met (see details of both regimes further below).

Law 12,973/2014 does not refer to the taxation of the “profit” of the controlled foreign companies, but to the taxation of the “variation of the investment value equivalent to the profit” of the controlled foreign companies (although in practice they are the same) as a way to support the interpretation in the sense that there is no taxation at the level of the foreign company but at the level of the Brazilian company (and thus prevent the argument of unconstitutionality or incompatibility of the CFC rule with article 7 of tax treaties).

On 22 January 2020, the CARF judged the Votorantim case (decision 1302-004.272), in which it was held that the Brazilian tax authorities cannot make tax adjustments in the profits of the CFC for the purpose of determining the taxable profit in Brazil. In this case, the tax authorities disallowed the deduction of financial expenses recognized by the company domiciled in Austria upon the issuance of “jouissance rights”, which resulted in an increase in the profit to be taxed in Brazil under the CFC regime.

According to the decision, the tax authorities cannot make tax adjustments in the results obtained by the legal entity abroad, since the tax legislation establishes that the profit earned abroad that is to be subject to taxation in Brazil under the CFC regime must be calculated in accordance with the accounting rules in force in the foreign country where the affiliated or controlled company is located.

Before 1 January 2015, Brazilian CFC rules did not provide for different tax treatments for controlled and affiliated foreign companies. According to the previous rules, profits of both types of subsidiaries were included in the results of the Brazilian entity, regardless of actual distribution and of whether these profits arose from active or passive activities and of the jurisdiction in which the controlled or affiliated company was located.

On 10 April 2013, the STF ruled that the old Brazilian CFC rules were unconstitutional in regard to foreign affiliated companies located outside a low-tax jurisdiction. The court confirmed, however, the constitutionality of the old Brazilian CFC rules in regard of foreign controlled companies located in low-tax jurisdictions. The decision, given in the Direct Action of Unconstitutionality 2,588, was binding on all taxpayers. According to the decision, the old Brazilian CFC rules could no longer apply to foreign affiliated companies located outside a low-tax jurisdiction. The rules remained applicable to foreign affiliated companies located in a low-tax jurisdiction and to foreign controlled companies located outside a low-tax jurisdiction, since the court did not reach a decision on the constitutionality of the old Brazilian CFC rules in those cases (see BR: SFC, 10 Apr. 2013, 2,588, Case Law IBFD).

Nevertheless, in the judgment of Extraordinary Appeal 541,090 on the same day, the Supreme Federal Court confirmed the constitutionality of Brazilian CFC rules in regard of foreign controlled companies located outside a low-tax jurisdiction. The decision is not binding on all taxpayers, but establishes case law on the matter (see BR: SFC, 10 Apr. 2013, 2,588, Case Law IBFD).
In view of the STF decision, Brazil amended its CFC rules, which led to the current CFC regimes applicable as of 1 January 2015 and explained below.

topic.title: Regimes for controlled and affiliated foreign companies
topic.p: A controlled foreign company is one in which the investor holds, directly or via related parties, rights that assure, on a permanent basis, the power to elect the majority of the directors and to prevail in corporate decisions. An affiliated company is one in which the investor has significant influence, considered as the power to take part in the definition of the company’s financial and operating policy, however, without holding control over the company. A presumed significant influence occurs whenever the investor holds 20% or more of the shareholding interest of the company, without holding control. Brazilian parent companies of affiliated companies abroad are, however, deemed to be controlling parent company for the purpose of CFC rules in the case this company holds, together with other related persons (resident or non-resident in Brazil) more than 50% of the affiliated company’s capital.

The new CFC rules regarding controlled companies have not changed significantly from the old regime. Accordingly, profits derived by all controlled foreign companies of Brazilian entities continue to be subject to automatic taxation in Brazil (in proportion to their participation), irrespective of the jurisdiction in which the controlled company is located, and regardless of whether or not the profits are legally or economically available to the Brazilian entity and of whether they arose from active or passive activities. An ordinary foreign tax credit is available for foreign taxes levied on profit distributions, if any, and an indirect credit has been introduced for the underlying corporate tax paid by the subsidiary (or permanent establishment) abroad. The indirect credit is allowed (in proportion to the Brazilian entity’s participation) in respect of corporate income tax paid by the foreign controlled entity (or foreign permanent establishment) on the positive results recognized and taxed in Brazil under CFC rules. This amount must be converted into BRL based on the exchange rate determined by the Brazilian Central Bank (if the foreign currency has no quotation, the amount is converted into USD and subsequently to BRL).

The payment of tax abroad must be evidenced by means of an official document issued by the foreign tax authority and validated by the Brazilian consulate/embassy in the foreign country. The amount of the indirect credit is limited to the amount of corporate income tax and CSLL due in Brazil on such results. Excess credit may be carried forward indefinitely.

Losses of directly and indirectly foreign controlled companies cannot be offset against the profits of the parent company in Brazil. Such losses can only be offset against profits generated by the foreign controlled or affiliated company on an entity-by-entity basis: the positive results of each entity are calculated individually and added to the results of the Brazilian company while the losses of each entity may be offset against the positive results of each entity only (for details on the offsetting of foreign losses under CFC rules, see section 7.2.2.) (article 79 of Law 12,973/2014). This tax treatment was highly debatable. However, the STJ, in the trial of Special Appeal 1.161.003-RS (the Marcopolo case), held that losses of foreign controlled and affiliated companies may only be offset against profits generated by the same company abroad. However, a consolidation of the results is possible until 2022 and under certain circumstances (see details below under Consolidation for controlled subsidiaries with active income).

Law 12,973/2014 modified, however, the technique to include such profits of a foreign subsidiary on a current basis by requiring the Brazilian parent to revalue its investments annually such that the local accounting results (before tax) of that subsidiary for the relevant calendar year are included in the valuation. The results of each controlled subsidiary must be included on a stand-alone basis. These foreign profits are calculated according to the laws of the jurisdiction where the controlled foreign company or permanent establishment is located and are then converted into BRL, using the foreign exchange rate at balance sheet date of the foreign company.

On the other hand, significant changes were introduced in respect of affiliated companies. Previous to Law 12,973/2014, affiliated companies were automatically subject to taxation under general CFC rules. Under the new CFC rules, affiliated companies are in principle not subject to the automatic taxation in Brazil. Profits of foreign affiliated companies are considered distributed to the parent company (and thus subject to taxation) only when credited or paid as specified in Law 12,973/2014. However, this rule only applies if the affiliated company:

item.p: is not (or is not directly or indirectly controlled by an entity) subject to a tax regime with a nominal income tax rate lower than 20% (the so-called “under-taxation” regime (regime de subtributação)); and
is not located in a low-tax jurisdiction nor benefits from a privileged tax regime.

topic.p: In case one of the conditions listed above is not met, the same rules applicable to the controlled foreign entities apply.

Law 13,259/2016 states that resident companies may opt to submit the profits of affiliated companies abroad to the regime applicable to profits of controlled companies abroad. The law also indicates that the tax authorities will establish the form and conditions for this option.

topic.title: Consolidation for controlled subsidiaries with active income
topic.p: The vertical consolidation of the results of subsidiaries, which was permitted in the past, is no longer allowed since 2015. The profits of each controlled company, whether directly or indirectly controlled, have to be calculated individually and then added to the tax base of the controlling company in Brazil.

However, until 2022, the positive and negative results (excluding foreign exchange results) of CFCs may still be consolidated in Brazil by the parent company under certain conditions (e.g. that the CFC is not subject to a favourable tax regime, or that at least 80% of its profits are considered to be active income) (article 78 of Law 12,973/2014). For details, see section 7.2.2. Losses after consolidation may be carried forward and be set off against profits of the same controlled subsidiaries.

topic.title: Exemption for overseas group companies on profits related to certain activities
topic.p: Until 31 December 2019, an exemption (i.e. a carve-out from the CFC regime) was provided to profits earned by (directly or indirectly) controlled or affiliated companies in connection with certain activities (e.g. freight, leasing, rent or provision of services directly related to the exploration and exploitation of oil and natural gas in Brazil). Therefore, such profits were not included in the taxable base of the parent company resident in Brazil, provided that certain conditions were met.

topic.title: Temporary fictitious credit for certain activities
topic.p: Until 2022, controlling entities in Brazil may benefit from a fictitious credit up to 9% to be offset against the tax due on the CFC profits in Brazil, provided that the CFC entities are engaged with one of the following activities: (i) production of food or beverage; (ii) construction; (iii) transformation industry; (iv) mineral extraction; or (v) export, under public concession contracts, of public goods located in the country of residence of the CFC entity.
However, the fictitious credit is not available in the following cases:

item.p: the foreign (directly or indirectly) controlled subsidiary is subject to a low-tax regime (taxed at a rate below 20%); and

the foreign (directly or indirectly) controlled subsidiary’s active income (as defined by law – see section 7.2.2.) is less than 80% of its total income (items such as royalties, interest, rentals and certain dividends are not considered active income).

topic.p: This rule also applies to the results of permanent establishments abroad which are taxed in Brazil under CFC rules.

topic.title: Instalment payments for tax on foreign profits
topic.p: The Brazilian parent company may elect to pay the corporate income tax in relation to the CFC rules annually on a lump-sum basis or in instalments to be paid within 8 years – the first instalment must be equivalent to 12.5% of the tax due. The unpaid tax is adjusted for interest and foreign exchange fluctuations.
However, the tax payment deferral is not available in the following cases:

item.p: the foreign (directly or indirectly) controlled subsidiary is:
resident or owned (directly or indirectly) by a resident in a low-tax jurisdiction or in a jurisdiction with a privileged tax regime; or
subject or owned (directly or indirectly) by a person subject to a low-tax regime (taxed at a rate below 20%); and

the foreign (directly or indirectly) controlled subsidiary’s active income (as defined by law – see section 7.2.2.) is less than 80% of its total income (items such as royalties, interest, rentals and certain dividends are not considered active income).

topic.p: These rules are also applicable to the results of permanent establishments abroad which are taxed in Brazil under CFC rules.

topic.title: Compatibility of Brazilian CFC rules and tax treaties
topic.p: Several Brazilian scholars defend that Brazilian CFC rules are not in line with the provisions of article 7 of the OECD Model. Such article would prevent the taxation of business profits by a state other than the residence state, provided that there is no permanent establishment. Moreover, the Brazilian tax code establishes that tax treaties revoke or modify the internal law; therefore, they should always prevail in case of conflict.

Brazilian tax authorities have adopted a different position. Private Ruling COSIT 18/2013 reflects the tax authorities’ view supporting the consistency of CFC legislation with the provisions of the tax treaties subscribed by Brazil. However, the subject is still open for discussion at judicial and administrative courts. On 24 April 2014, the Superior Court of Justice decided on a leading case (Companhia Vale do Rio Doce v. Federal Union) regarding the application of Brazilian CFC legislation when the controlled company is resident in a treaty jurisdiction. The decision stated that the business profit article in tax treaties signed by Brazil prevents the application of Brazilian CFC legislation. As a result, the Court decided in favour of the taxpayer and denied the application of Brazilian CFC legislation to its controlled foreign companies located in Belgium, Denmark and Luxembourg. The CFC legislation was considered applicable to the controlled foreign company located in Bermuda, as no tax treaty exists with Brazil.

Law 12,973/2014, which amended the Brazilian CFC rules, has no major impact on the discussions, as the basic concept of taxation of undistributed profits of a subsidiary abroad remains in the new rules.

On 21 October 2014, the Federal Administrative Court (Conselho Administrativo de Recursos Fiscais, CARF) decided on a case concerning the compatibility of Brazilian CFC rules and tax treaties. The Court ruled that the Brazilian CFC rules conflict with tax treaties in respect of income tax, but not in respect of the Social Contribution on Net Profits (Contribuição Social Sobre o Lucro Líquido, CSLL) when this contribution is not listed in the treaty. In addition, the Court decided that the CFC rules do not apply to foreign affiliated companies located in a country that is not a low-tax jurisdiction, since according to the STF's decision in the above-mentioned Case 2,588 (see BR: SFC, 10 Apr. 2013, 2,588, Case Law IBFD), foreign affiliated companies located outside low-tax jurisdictions are not subject to CFC rules. The CARF has since then decided in other administrative cases that the taxation in Brazil according to CFC rules is not prevented by tax treaties (e.g. the Belgravia case (decision 9101-003.617, of 6 June 2018); the Centaurus case (decision 9101-003.616, of 6 June 2018); the Petróleo Brasileiro case (decision 9101-003.973, of 17 January 2019); the Ball Beverage case (decision 9101-004.583, of 4 December 2019) and the Votorantim case (decision 1302-004.272, of 22 January 2020)).

section.title: Closely held company
section.p: There are no special provisions regarding closely held companies.

section.title: Other anti-avoidance rules
section.p: Brazil has other anti-avoidance rules implemented – see subsections below.

On 1 July 2021 and 8 October 2021, Brazil signed joint statements with other Inclusive Framework members with an agreement to implement a two-pillar solution to address the tax challenges arising from the digitalization of the economy. The solution includes a plan to ensure that large multinational enterprises (with revenues above EUR 750 million) pay a minimum level of tax on the income arising in each of the jurisdictions where they operate (Pillar Two). A key component of this plan is the Global Anti-Base Erosion (GloBE) rules, which provide for a co-ordinated system of taxation that imposes a top-up tax on profits arising in a jurisdiction whenever the effective tax rate is below the minimum rate of 15%.

section.title: Low-tax jurisdictions
section.p: Law 9,430/1996 introduced the concept of low-tax jurisdiction in the Brazilian legal framework. Article 24 of Law 9,430/1996, established that transactions performed between Brazilian individuals or corporate taxpayers with parties residing in a low-tax jurisdiction must be subject to the transfer pricing rules. For these purposes (i.e. transfer pricing rules), a low-tax jurisdiction was defined by article 24 as a country that does not tax income or that taxes income at a maximum tax rate lower than 20% (17% for countries following international fiscal transparency standards).

Since then, several legal provisions in Brazil have dealt with the concept of low-tax jurisdiction for the purpose of application of the special tax treatment for outbound payments to residents in such jurisdictions.

Some of these legal provisions make an express reference to article 24 of Law 9,430/1996 in order to define a low-tax jurisdiction (in such cases the definition of low-tax jurisdictions for the special tax treatment follows the definition stated by article 24 for transfer pricing rules), whereas other legal provisions make no reference to article 24, but have an autonomous definition of low-tax jurisdiction. This autonomous definition, however, coincides with the definition given in article 24 (above definition). This has an impact in practice, as several amendments were made to article 24 in the following years.

Such amendments (described below) are applicable not only for the purpose of transfer pricing rules but also in other cases for the purpose of the special tax treatment which law indicates article 24 for the purpose of the definition of low-tax jurisdiction. Those amendments are not, however, taken into account for the purpose of the definition of low-tax jurisdiction, other laws that have their autonomous definition (i.e. a low-tax jurisdiction remains, for those cases, a country that does not tax income or that taxes income at a maximum tax rate lower than 20% (17% for countries following international fiscal transparency standards).
The amendments of article 24, applicable to transfer pricing rules and certain special tax treatments, made significant changes to the concept of low-tax jurisdiction for those purposes.

First, in 2002, the concept of low-tax jurisdiction in article 24 was slightly amended via Law 10,451/2002, in order to encompass the jurisdictions that oppose access to the disclosure of a shareholding composition and ownership of assets and rights.

Law 11,727/2008 amended again the concept of low-tax jurisdictions in article 24 and, in addition, introduced new articles that created the concept of “privileged tax regimes”. These changes have been in force since 1 January 2009.

Under the amendment to the concept of low-tax jurisdiction, a paragraph was introduced in article 24 to state that a jurisdiction or territory that does not “grant access to information related to composition of shareholders of legal entities, title or beneficial owner of earnings attributed to non-residents” is considered to be a low-tax jurisdiction (introduced by Law 11,727/2008, referring to the inclusion of paragraph 4 in article 24 of Law 9,430).

The concept of “privileged tax regime” was created by an inclusion of articles 24-A and 24-B in Law 9,430/1996. This concept was created for purpose of classifying new transactions that would be subject to transfer pricing rules. As this was not an amendment to article 24, but an inclusion of new articles, legally the concept of “privilege tax regime” is not applicable for the purpose of the tax treatment of outbound payments to residents in low-tax jurisdictions which law makes reference to article 24, but only for transfer pricing purposes.
Under the new article 24-A, a “privileged tax regime” is one that:

item.label: (i)
item.p: does not tax income or taxes it at a maximum rate lower than 20% (17% for countries following international fiscal transparency standards);

item.label: (ii)
item.p: grants tax advantages to a non-resident entity or individual (a) without the need to carry out a substantial economic activity in the country or a particular territory or (b) that is conditioned on the company not exercising any substantial economic activity in the country or a particular territory – “substantial economic activity” as defined by Normative Instruction 1,037/2010, that is, operational capacity that is appropriate for its purpose, which can be demonstrated, among other factors, by having (i) a sufficient number of qualified employees to develop its activities and (ii) the physical facilities for the exercise of its management and decision making; this concept was later clarified by Normative Instruction 1,658/2016 (see further below);

item.label: (iii)
item.p: does not tax or taxes proceeds generated abroad at a maximum rate lower than 20% (17% for countries following international fiscal transparency standards). Under article 24-B, included in Law 9,430, the Executive may reduce at any time the rates mentioned in article 24-A, exceptionally and on a restricted basis, in respect of countries which are members of an economic bloc to which Brazil is also a party; or

item.label: (iv)
item.p: does not grant access to information related to the composition of shareholders of legal entities, title or beneficial ownership of earnings attributed to non-residents and to economic transactions performed.

section.p: Law 11,941/2009 established that a “privileged tax regime” will be considered to exist if at least one of the characteristics described above is verified.

Decree 8,303/2014, published in the DOU of 5 September 2014, included transactions engaged with persons who benefit from a privileged tax regime in the list of situations for which access to information is considered indispensable for the tax audit. As a result, tax authorities are allowed to examine taxpayers' information in documents, books and registries of financial institutions (including information on deposit accounts and financial investments).

The Brazilian Revenue Service has issued administrative rules listing the jurisdictions considered to be low-tax jurisdictions and listing the foreign countries and forms of entities considered to be privileged tax regimes (most recently, Normative Instruction 1,037/2010).

According to Normative Instruction 1,037/2010, as amended, the following countries are considered low-tax jurisdictions: American Samoa, Andorra, Anguilla, Antigua and Barbuda, Aruba, the Ascension Islands, the Bahamas, Bahrain, Barbados, Belize, the Bermudas, the British Virgin Islands, Brunei, Campione D’Italia, the Cayman Islands, the Channel Islands (Jersey, Guernsey, Alderney and Sark), the Cook Islands, Curaçao, Cyprus, Djibouti, Dominica, French Polynesia, Gibraltar, Grenada, Hong Kong, Ireland, the Isle of Man, Kiribati, Lebanon, Labuan, Liberia, Liechtenstein, Macau, the Maldives, the Marshall Islands, the Mauricio Islands, Monaco, Montserrat, Nauru, Niue, Norfolk Island, Oman, Panama, the Pitcairn Islands, Queshm Island, Saint Helena, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, Saint Peter and Miguelão Island, Saint Vincent, Samoa, the Seychelles, Sint Maarten, the Solomon Islands, Swaziland, Tonga, Tristan da Cunha, the Turks and Caicos Islands, the United Arab Emirates, the US Virgin Islands and Vanuatu.
According to Normative Instruction 1,037/2010, as amended, the following are considered to be privileged tax regimes:

item.p: regarding legislation of Uruguay, the regime applicable to Financial Investment Companies (Safis), until 31 December 2010;
regarding legislation of Denmark, the regime applicable to holding companies which do not develop substantial economic activity;

regarding legislation of the Netherlands, the regime applicable to holding companies which do not develop substantial economic activity – see further below for the “suspension” effect and for the administrative decision on the interpretation of “substantial economic activity”;
with regard to the legislation of Iceland, the regime applicable to International Trading Companies (ITC);
in reference to the Hungarian legislation, the regime applicable to companies incorporated as KFT offshore;

regarding legislation of the United States, the regime applicable to companies incorporated as a state limited liability company (LLC), whose shareholding control is composed of non-residents, not subject to the federal income tax;
regarding legislation of Spain, the regime applicable to companies incorporated as Entidad de Tenencia de Valores Extranjeros (ETVEs) – see “suspension” effect below;
regarding legislation of Malta, the regime applicable to International Trading Companies (ITC) and International Holding Companies (IHC);

regarding legislation of Austria, the holding regime applicable to companies which do not develop substantial economic activity (included by Normative Instruction 1,658/2016 and amended by Normative Instruction 1,683/2016);
regarding the legislation of Costa Rica, the Free Zone Regime (Regime de Zonas Francas, RZF);
regarding the legislation of Portugal, the regime of the International Business Centre of Madeira (Centro Internacional de Negócios da Madeira, CINM); and
regarding Singapore, the following regimes:
special tax rate for non-resident ship owners or charterers or air transport undertakings;
exemption and concessionary tax rate for insurance and reinsurance business;
concessionary tax rate for the Finance and Treasury Centre;
concessionary tax rate for a trustee company;
concessionary tax rate for income derived from debt securities;
concessionary tax rate for a global trading company and qualifying company;
concessionary tax rate for a financial sector incentive company;
concessionary tax rate for the provision of processing services for financial institutions;
concessionary tax rate for shipping investment managers;
concessionary tax rate for trust income to which the beneficiary is entitled;
concessionary tax rate for the leasing of aircraft and aircraft engines;
concessionary tax rate for aircraft investment managers;
concessionary tax rate for container investment enterprises;
concessionary tax rate for container investment managers;
concessionary tax rate for approved insurance brokers;
concessionary tax rate for income derived from managing a qualifying registered business trust or company;
concessionary tax rate for ship broking and forward freight agreement trading;
concessionary tax rate for shipping-related support services;
concessionary tax rate for income derived from managing an approved venture company; and
concessionary tax rate for international growth companies.

section.p: Normative Instruction 1,037/2010 has not been revised to reflect the new income tax threshold standard (17%) established by Ordinance 488/2014.

According to an Administrative Act issued by the Brazilian tax authorities on 25 March 2011, Luxembourg holding companies are no longer considered to be a privileged tax regime, as the regime has lapsed and its transitory period is terminated.

On 20 June 2014, Normative Ruling 1,474/2014 included in the list of privileged tax regimes the Swiss regimes that are applicable to legal entities incorporated as a holding company, domiciliary company, auxiliary company, mixed company and administrative company, whose tax treatment result in the imposition of corporate income tax at a rate lower than 20%, as provided for by the federal, cantonal and municipal legislation.

Moreover, Normative Ruling 1,474/2014 has also listed as privileged tax regime any Swiss tax regime applicable to other types of legal entities by means of the issuance of rulings by the tax authorities, which results in the levy of the corporate income tax at a rate lower than 20% as provided for by the federal, cantonal and municipal legislation.

Jurisdictions listed as low-tax jurisdictions or privileged tax regimes may request a revision of their characterization as low-tax jurisdictions or privileged tax regime (Administrative Rule 1,045, which was enacted in 23 June 2010 and changed some provisions of Administrative Rule 1,037/2010). There may be a suspension of the listing with regard to a certain jurisdiction, at the discretion of the federal Revenue Service Secretary, while the request is being considered.

On 25 June 2010, the Federal Revenue Service published Normative Acts 10 and 11, stating that Switzerland and the Netherlands have filed requests for review. During the analysis of the requests, suspensions have been granted in respect of the two countries. On 18 December 2015, tax authorities issued Normative Act 3/2015, which revoked Normative Act 10 and reintroduced the regime applicable to Dutch holding companies not developing substantial economic activity within the list of privileged tax regimes. On 31 December 2019, the CARF issued a decision in Administrative Procedure 16561.720100/2017-97 (Unilever Brasil Ltda.) on the interpretation and application of the “substantial economic activity” requirement for the purpose of characterizing Dutch holding companies as entities subject to a privileged tax regime under Brazilian tax legislation. The CARF concluded that the taxpayer had not demonstrated that the foreign-related entity had factual economic substance in the Netherlands and, therefore, decided in favour of the National Treasury. In addition, the evidence that the Dutch holding company had premises in the Netherlands and other loan contracts signed with entities in China and Sweden was not sufficient to demonstrate substantial economic activity in the Netherlands. One dissident councillor indicated, however, that the rule considering the Dutch regime applicable to holding companies not developing substantial economic activity as a privileged tax regime was suspended in the year of the assessment (2012) and that its reintroduction in 2015 could not have retroactive effects.

A request for review was also presented by Spain and suspension was granted through Normative Act 22, published on 2 December 2010, regarding the regime applicable to companies incorporated as Spanish foreign participation holding companies (ETVEs).

On 20 June 2014, the Federal Revenue Service published Normative Instruction 1,474/2014, providing that Switzerland is no longer considered a low-tax jurisdiction. However, certain Swiss tax regimes were qualified as privileged tax regimes. Normative Instruction 1,474/2014 also removed the Hungarian KFT regime from the privileged tax regime list. These changes apply retroactively from 1 January 2014.

In general, the following measures are applicable in respect of payments to or transactions carried on with persons located in low-tax jurisdictions or deemed as benefiting from privileged tax regimes:

item.p: Under article 26 of Law 12,249/2010, payments made to persons located in a low-tax jurisdiction or benefiting from a privileged tax regime are not deductible, except if:

the identification of the beneficial owner of the payment is provided – for the purpose of this rule, Law 12,249 defined beneficial owner as any individual or legal entity not constituted with the sole or principal purpose of reducing tax burden and that derives the income on their own account;
the proof that the beneficiary carries out the activity for which it is paid is provided; and
documents that can indicate the payment and the receipt of the good, service or right are provided.
Transfer pricing rules apply, irrespective of whether the two parties qualify as related parties (see section 10.2.).
Thin capitalization rules apply, with a more restrictive limitation on the deductibility of interest payments (see section 10.3.).

A higher withholding income tax rate of 25% (not the general 15%) applies on payments of certain types of income (e.g. interest and royalties), as well as capital gains, whenever earned by entities resident in low-tax jurisdictions (see section 7.3.4.). The increased withholding income tax does not apply to payments made to beneficiaries located in privileged tax regimes, but solely to those resident in low-tax jurisdictions.

Non-application of the tax benefits available for foreign investors investing in the Brazilian financial and capital markets under the mechanisms provided for by Resolution 2,689/2000 issued by the Brazilian Monetary Council (such as tax exemption on gains derived in transactions performed within the stock exchange market).

section.p: On 1 December 2014, Ordinance 488/2014 (Portaria 488/2014), issued by the Ministry of Finance, reduced from 20% to 17% the top rate threshold applicable for the qualification of countries and regimes as a low-tax jurisdiction or privileged tax regime for countries following international fiscal transparency standards. The top rate threshold applicable for countries not following international fiscal transparency standards remains 20%.

Normative Instruction 1,530/2014 of 22 December 2014 established the definition of international fiscal transparency standards and the procedure for reviewing the qualification of countries and territories as low-tax jurisdictions or jurisdictions with a privileged tax regime.
According to Normative Instruction 1,530/2014, countries considered in line with international fiscal transparency standards are those which have:

item.p: signed or negotiated a treaty or agreement with Brazil on the exchange of information or with a provision on the exchange of information for tax purposes, allowing the disclosure of information related to: beneficial owners, shareholding structures, ownership of goods or rights and economic transactions carried out; and
committed to the criteria established at international forums on fiscal evasion of which Brazil takes part, such as the Global Forum on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes.

section.p: On 13 September 2016, the Federal Revenue Service published Normative Instruction 1,658/2016 providing that (i) Ireland, Curaçao (replacing the Dutch Antilles) and Sint Maarten are considered low-tax jurisdictions, (ii) Saint Kitts and Nevis is removed from the list. However, this was a correction due to a duplication in the list, where both Saint Kitts and Nevis and its Portuguese translation Federação de São Cristóvão e Nevis appeared. Therefore, Saint Kitts and Nevis remain as a low-tax jurisdiction, since Federação de São Cristóvão e Nevis was not removed from the list; and (iii) Austrian holding companies are qualified as benefiting from privileged tax regimes.

Furthermore, regarding Danish and Dutch holding companies, Normative Instruction 1,658/2016 clarified that having "substantial economic activity" means that a company has appropriated operational capacity for its purposes, as evidenced, among others factors, by means of having at its disposal (i) a sufficient number of employees to develop its activities and (ii) the physical facilities for the exercise of its management and decisions related to (a) the development of activities in order to get income derived from its assets and (b) the administration of equity interest in order to get income arising from the distribution of profit and capital gain.

The concept of an “undertaxation” regime (regime de subtributação) also exists, but only for the purpose of application of specific CFC rules – i.e. requirements for consolidation of the results (see section 7.2.2.) and for application of the CFC rules to affiliated companies (see section 10.4.). The concept of an “undertaxation” regime is similar to low tax jurisdictions except for the fact that undertaxation regimes are considered to be those with a nominal income tax rate lower than 20%. According to Normative Instruction 1,674/2016, which amended Normative Instruction 1,520, low tax jurisdictions and privileged tax regimes are included in the concept of undertaxation regime.

section.title: Identification of beneficial owner
section.p: Normative Instruction 1,634/2016, published in the DOU of 9 May 2016, introduced a requirement for resident and offshore companies to identify the beneficial owners of their transactions conducted in Brazil. Entities concerned are:

item.p: investment funds and clubs operating under the CVM regulations;

foreign entities either (i) holding real estate, vehicles, vessels, aircraft, bank accounts, investments in financial or capital markets and equity interests in other companies (including other than in the financial market) in Brazil or (ii) performing transactions relating to leasing, chartering of vessels, rental of equipment or simple lease or importation of goods without foreign exchange hedging for the capitalization of companies in Brazil;
unincorporated joint ventures (Sociedades em Conta de Participações) linked to a general partner (sócio ostensivo); and
any other entities that may be of interest to the Federal Revenue Service.

section.p: According to Normative Instruction 1,634/2016, "beneficial owners" are individuals owning, controlling or having significant influence over the aforementioned entities. In addition, "significant influence" means holding (i) over 25% of the company's capital, directly or indirectly; or (ii) the power to represent the majority in decisions and elect the administrators of the entity even if not controlling it.
Normative Instruction 1,634/2016 does not apply to:

item.p: corporations in Brazil and foreign companies whose information on their shareholders is publicly available, provided that they are not located in black or grey-listed jurisdictions;
not-for-profit organizations that are not fiduciary agents and are not located in black or grey-listed jurisdictions;
government entities, central banks or multilateral organizations; and
national investment funds operating under CVM regulations providing identification of the quotaholders to the tax authorities through the digital program e-financeira.

section.p: To be eligible for an exception, the information sent by companies to the Federal Revenue Service must include that on any individuals allowed to represent them, their controllers, administrators and directors, as well as on any individuals or corporations on behalf of whom companies were incorporated.

Administrators of foreign entities that have a corporate taxpayer number in Brazil (CNPJ) are not considered beneficial owners, even if they meet the requirements set (such as owning or controlling the company).
Penalties for not informing the beneficial owner include:

item.p: suspension of the taxpayer’s registration number (CNPJ); and
inability to use bank accounts (except for return of investments to the country or for fulfilling obligations agreed on before the suspension) and financial applications, or to obtain loans.

section.p: The concept of beneficial owner (with another definition) is also used for the purpose of anti-tax haven rules (see section 10.6.1.).

section.title: Indirect transfer of assets
section.p: Brazil does not have specific rules for taxing indirect transfer of assets. The legislation provides only for the taxation of the capital gains of non-residents realized on the direct transfer of assets located within Brazil’s territory. However, the Brazilian tax authorities have attempted to tax indirect transfer of assets in two cases (Administrative Proceedings 19515.003180/2005-22 and 16682.720343/2013­25), on the basis of anti-avoidance rules. In those cases, the Brazilian tax authorities argued that the taxpayer had implemented a sham transaction for having interposed foreign entities followed by multiple transactions undertaken in a short period of time. The CARF agreed with the tax authorities and upheld the argument of sham in both cases.

section.title: Taxation of Special Types of Entity
Holding company
section.p: There is no special tax regime for holding companies in Brazil. Holdings are subject to general corporate income tax rules.
For the treatment of dividends received by holdings, see section 7.2.1.3.

section.title: Partnership
section.p: Brazilian law does not recognize the concept of hybrid entities, i.e. entities with legal personality that are not regarded as taxable units for tax purposes, such as transparent partnerships. Therefore, partnerships existing under Brazilian law are regarded as taxable entities and are taxed according to the tax rules applicable to companies.

section.title: Economic interest grouping
section.p: Brazilian domestic law does not provide special rules regarding economic interest grouping.

section.title: Association and cooperative
section.p: There is no special tax regime in Brazil for associations and cooperatives, such as not-for-profit entities.

section.title: Non-taxable entities
section.p: Under the Federal Constitution, the federal, state or municipal governments may not tax the property or income of, or the services provided by, foundations, churches, political parties, labour unions and non-profitable educational or charitable institutions, provided that the income is derived from activities directly related to the institutional objectives of these bodies.

In order to be an “excluded” entity the following conditions must be fulfilled (article 14 of the National Tax Code): (i) the profits or dividends are not distributed to directors or board members, (ii) all of the appropriate tax and commercial records are maintained and (iii) all of the resources of the entity must be applied in fulfilling their purposes within Brazil.
Social contributions, however, may be levied on the entities by the federal, state or municipal governments, including those imposed on remuneration paid to employees.
Certain entities are also exempt from corporate income tax according to ordinary law (this exemption may be revoked by other ordinary laws) including:

item.p: cooperative societies that do not make any distribution of profits with the exception of a maximum interest payment of 12% per year as remuneration to each member’s paid-up portion of the capital; under Normative Opinion SCT 4 of 15 February 1986, results from any financial investments by cooperative companies (including credit cooperatives) do not benefit from exemptions usually granted to cooperative societies, as they are subject to income tax under ordinary rules (withholding tax, prepayments and annual taxation, as the case may be);
charitable, religious, scientific, cultural, recreational and sporting institutions, foundations or clubs, provided that certain conditions set forth by Law 9,532/1997 are fulfilled;
labour unions and professional associations;
authorized savings and credit associations, organized as civil companies for the purpose of facilitating the purchase of dwellings to their members, or of attracting and promoting savings;
investment companies and mutual investment funds; and
certain public utility corporations in which the federal or state governments have interests.

section.title: Taxation of Special Types of Activity
section.p: There is no special taxation for certain types of activity; however, some tax incentives are linked to certain types of activities (see section 1.9.).

section.title: General
section.p: Brazil has more than one value added tax. The tax on manufactured products (IPI) is levied at federal level on every stage of the production process and on import transactions. In addition, the ICMS is levied at the state level.
This section deals with the IPI. For the ICMS, see section 14.6.4.1.

The IPI is provided for by article 153 (IV, 3º) of the 1988 Federal Constitution and currently regulated by IPI Law 4,502/1964, as amended, and IPI Regulations enacted by Decree 7,212/2010 and Decree 8,950/2016.

IPI is a federal tax imposed on the supply and importation of any type of manufactured product or good. The imposition of IPI respects the non-cumulative principle, under which the tax considered due in prior transactions (including import of products) may be offset against the tax due on subsequent transactions involving the product manufactured by the taxpayer.
Part of the revenue from IPI is shared by the states and the municipalities.

section.title: Taxable persons
section.p: Article 51 of the CTN defines a taxable person as anyone who imports and/or manufactures goods, or to whom the federal legislation applies equivalent treatment.

section.title: General
section.p: Taxable persons are those who import and/or manufacture goods, or to whom the federal legislation applies equivalent treatment. Suppliers and dealers of goods seized or abandoned and taken to auction are also taxable persons for the purposes of IPI.

Under the legal definition, a person is liable to remit IPI whenever there is an import and industrialization of goods, regardless of the legal status of the entity – an exception applies if the person has tax immunity or the goods are exempt from tax, but a written consent of the tax authorities may be needed in this respect.
As a main rule, private individuals are not considered to be taxable persons for the purposes of IPI.
According to precedents set by the STF, products imported by non-taxable legal entities (i.e. service providers) or private individuals (for personal use) are not subject to IPI.

section.title: Groups
section.p: There are no specific rules regarding groups of persons being treated as a single taxable person. However, there are rules to determine the tax base when there is a transfer of products between establishments (permanent establishments or branches) of the same company or related parties. In this respect, related parties are those with which a company has been able to trade in the broadest sense of the term, in conditions that are not reciprocal and do not have the independence that characterizes transactions with third parties outside the company, its management control or any other area of influence in its decisions.

section.title: Supplies of goods and services
section.p: As opposed to the ICMS (see section 14.6.4.1.), the taxable transactions for IPI purposes are supplies by manufacturers and importation by any person of any kind of manufactured product. The levy of IPI on the resale of imported goods carried out by the importer was considered constitutional by the Federal Supreme Court on a decision issued on 21 August 2020.

For the purposes of IPI, manufactured products are those which have been subject to a manufacturing process. “Manufacturing process” means any process changing the nature, performance, completion, display or purpose of a product or improving its readiness for consumption.
Under the applicable law and regulations, manufacturing processes include:

item.p: transformation of raw material or intermediate products into a new product;
improvement of the function, use, or appearance of existing products;
assembly of separate parts to make a new product or separate unit;
packing of finished products in sales containers not destined merely for transportation; and
renovation of used or deteriorated products to make them serviceable.

section.p: Considering that the rendering of services is subject to the ISS (see section 14.6.4.2.), the situation in which a party provides manufacturing services for the benefit of a contracting party (such as in tooling agreements) must be carefully analysed, in order to determine whether such transaction would be subject to the IPI.

The difference between the actual performance of manufacturing activities (subject to IPI) and the rendering of services (subject to the ISS) is based on the destination or use given to the product; if the product is for the personal use or consumption of the contractor or is included in his enterprise’s fixed assets, the actual manufacturing would be deemed an actual service, therefore subject to the municipal ISS. However, if the product is destined for sale or to be applied to other products to be manufactured, the transaction will be considered effective industrialization by the manufacturer, therefore subject to IPI.

section.title: Importation
section.p: The import of products is, in general, subject to IPI. The resale of imported goods carried out by the importer is currently understood as a taxable event of IPI by Brazilian courts.
However, there are some specific exemptions and reductions available under the current framework.

section.title: Place of taxation
section.p: IPI is a federal tax applicable to transactions performed within Brazilian territory by the taxpayer. It is charged, levied and paid to the federal treasury on the manufacture and the importation of goods within Brazil.

Place of taxation of supplies of goods

section.title: Time of taxation
section.p: IPI is assessed on a monthly basis. IPI liability arises:

item.p: when goods exit the taxpayer’s establishment;
on the fourth day after the day on which an invoice is issued, in case goods have not left the establishment until the day before the issuance of the appropriate invoice; and
with regard to import transactions, upon customs clearance.

section.p: When a tooling agreement is in place, the intermediary products, raw materials and packing materials may be supplied with deferral of IPI, provided that certain other conditions are met.

IPI imposed on goods shipped from the production facility to the exporting companies, including trading companies referred to in Decree-Law 1,248/1972, is deferred. Manufacturers shipping their products retain the right to credit the IPI paid on purchases of raw material, intermediate products and packing material applied to the manufacturing of exported goods.

section.title: Taxable amount
section.p: The taxable base for IPI purposes is:

item.p: with respect to imports, the customs value, as increased by customs duties and other charges (freight, insurance, etc.);

with respect to domestic supplies, the total consideration received or to be received for the supply, including ICMS. However, transportation and insurance costs may be excluded from the taxable base, provided that they are invoiced separately; and

with respect to manufacturing entrusted to another taxpayer (tooling agreement), the price of the transaction as increased by the value of raw materials, intermediary products and packing material provided by the contractor.

section.p: Senate Resolution 1/2017, published in the DOU of 9 March 2017, suspends the application of the rule determining the inclusion of the amount of unconditional discounts in the taxable base of IPI. The suspension follows the declaration of unconstitutionality of the rule by the STF. As a result, IPI is not charged on the listed price of the product, but on the actual value of the purchase operation, that is, taking into account unconditional discounts offered at the moment of the sale to exclude the related amount from the taxable base.

section.title: Rates
section.p: IPI rates vary in accordance with the relevant product, based on the tax classification code provided for under the IPI Regulations. The tax classification code is based on the Explanatory Notes of the Harmonized System (NESH) and the External Common Tariff (TEC).

Rates may vary inversely with the necessity of the product (from 365% to nil) and are subject to frequent amendments; thus, superfluous goods (e.g. manufactured tobacco, alcoholic beverages) are subject to high rates while certain semi-manufactured products attract very low rates – some goods are subject to a specific charge of IPI, i.e. a fixed sum imposed on each article of a determined class. A nil rate, in general, is applicable only to essential products. However, this essentiality will depend on the current moment of the Brazilian economy, to the extent that the government may decide to reduce the IPI rate (or even increase, with regard to import transactions) in order to stimulate a determined sector of the economy. The IPI is one of the few taxes under the Brazilian legal system, such that changes in rates do not require the enactment of a new law. Effectively, up to certain limits specified by law, the IPI rates may be freely established by the executive branch, via decree, with immediate effect.

Therefore, the IPI is often used as a tool to allow the intervention of the government in specific areas of the economy, either by reducing rates to stimulate the local production and domestic market of a determined product or by increasing rates, mainly in connection with import transactions, in order to enhance the competitiveness of Brazilian products.
In view of the COVID-19 pandemic, the federal government reduced IPI rates for various items (e.g. plastic, chemicals, food and vegetables).

section.title: Exemptions
section.p: The following activities are exempt:

item.p: preparation of food and refreshments that are sold directly to the consumer without special containers;
production of handcrafts by artisans in their own dwellings without the cooperation of other persons and sold directly by the artisan to the consumer;
production of clothes and similar articles by independent workers and under a direct transaction with the consumer;
the manufacturing of a product in view of a direct order from the consumer or user, provided that professional work is preponderant in manufacturing;
medicines prepared in a pharmacy and sold directly to the consumer;
assembly of products outside the establishment in order to construct buildings, pipelines, factories and similar items;
arrangement, restoration and repair of used articles destined for the same enterprise or carried out under instructions given by a third party;
restoration of defective products, even through the replacement of pieces, provided the restoration is made gratuitously under the producer’s guarantee; and
conversion of an engine in order to run on alcohol.

section.p: Products manufactured for the manufacturer’s own use within the same industrial unit are not taxed.

A constitutional tax exemption applies for books, newspapers, periodicals and paper used for printing purposes. Private Ruling 4,020/2017 clarified that this exemption applies to import and export duties and IPI.
There are several exemptions and 0% rates applicable to specific products, based on their tax classification codes.
For tax incentives on IPI, see section 1.9.

section.title: Input tax deduction
section.p: IPI is charged at each stage of the manufacturing process of products. As in the case of VAT, products that pass through several manufacturing stages (e.g. from raw material to finished goods) are allowed offsetting adjustments to compensate for the IPI paid on each separate transaction. When the production phase is concluded, IPI is no longer imposed and the accumulated financial burden is usually incorporated into the final cost of the product.

Tax paid (input IPI) on raw material, intermediary products and packing material may be offset against the tax liability, provided that such materials or products are used in the production of taxable goods.

Purchases of goods that do not form part of new products but are used in the production of taxable goods may also give rise to an input IPI. This group includes tools that are subject to depreciation or are damaged due to physical contact with the articles which are being produced.

A credit (input IPI) is also granted on specific machinery and equipment produced in Brazil forming part of fixed assets and used solely in the manufacturing process. The eligible items are listed by the Ministry of Finance. The Coordinator of the Tax System declared that purchases of Brazilian-made machinery and equipment connected with industrial development and mining projects approved by the government are entitled to input IPI even if the machinery or equipment in question are not included in the Ministry of Finance’s list. The Supreme Court has ruled that the credit available to the domestic purchaser of Brazilian-made machinery to be used as his enterprise’s fixed assets is a subsidy to the national industry and therefore not applicable to foreign products.

Manufacturers may consider input IPI the tax paid on raw material, intermediary products and packing material purchased from wholesalers that are not taxpayers for IPI purposes. The input IPI is calculated by applying the rate pertaining to the product in question to 50% of its price.

section.title: Registration
section.p: All IPI taxpayers must be registered before the Brazilian Revenue Service (RFB).

section.title: Invoices
section.p: An invoice must be issued for any taxable event to support the operation and make it legal. Invoices are used for registering input and output IPI into IPI books.

Companies are required to specify on invoices and receipts the taxes charged (percentages), which are part of the total amount of the product sale price or the provision of services, including IPI. In this sense, companies must list the amount of municipal, state and federal taxes levied for each product described in the invoices and receipts. Alternatively, such information could also be displayed on a panel in plain view within their establishments. Companies failing to comply with these requirements are subject to administrative penalties.

section.title: Records
section.p: Taxpayers must keep for 5 years specific IPI books for the registration of the IPI due and the recognized credits.

section.title: Returns and payment
section.p: A yearly return with the indication of the IPI ascertainment (Declaração do Imposto sobre Produtos Industrializados, DIPI) should be filed with regard to the operations held in the previous year. The return must be filed (in electronic format or by the Internet) by the last day of March.
Payment of IPI must be made by the 15th day of the month following the month related to which tax was assessed. Different deadlines may be specified for specific cases.

section.title: Interest and penalties
section.p: Late payment is subject to an interest charge based on the SELIC rate (a market interest rate) as from the day following the deadline. With regard to the first month of delay, the applicable interest rate is 1%, and the SELIC is applied from the second month.

A penalty also applies to late payments, at the daily rate of 0.33%, limited to 20%. If a tax assessment is brought by tax authorities against the taxpayer, a 75% penalty applies (such penalty may increase to 150% if sham or fraud is evidenced).

section.title: Appeals
section.p: See section 1.11.3.

section.title: Non-resident taxable persons
section.p: Non-residents are not subject to IPI.

section.p: Not applicable.
