section.p: Not applicable.

section.title: VAT refunds
section.p: Not applicable.

section.title: VAT representatives
section.p: Not applicable.

section.title: Capital duty
section.p: There is no capital duty in Brazil.

topic.title: Municipal tax on the transfer of real estate (imposto sobre a transmissão de bens imóveis, ITBI)
topic.p: The ITBI is levied on the inter vivos transfer of real estate as well as on the transfer or assignment of in rem rights on real estate (except guarantees such as mortgages) and the assignment of rights for the acquisition of such real estate.

ITBI is not levied on the transfer of assets or rights thereto in the case of a capital contribution, nor on the transfer of assets or rights resulting from a merger, consolidation, spin-off or liquidation, unless the prevailing activity of the legal entity receiving the asset or right is (i) the purchase and sale or (ii) rental or leasing of real estate.

The ITBI rate is established by the applicable municipal law (several municipalities apply a 2% rate), and no limits are imposed by the Constitution. The taxable base is the value established by the municipality, taking into account (i) the fair market value of the assets or rights or (ii) the transaction value, whichever is higher. The seller or purchaser (according to the laws of the municipality) is liable for the collection of the tax.

section.title: Stamp duty
section.p: There is no stamp duty on the issuing of securities in Brazil.

Registration and issuing of documents at notaries are subject to certain fees; i.e. issuing and registration of real estate deeds, marriage certificate, etc. Fees vary according to documents and notaries.

section.title: General
section.p: Federal customs duties are levied either on a specific or an ad valorem basis, depending on the nature of the goods imported. Tables of classifications of goods subject to customs duties and customs tariffs are established by a decree that must be published in the DOU.

The Customs Tariff Law of 1957 (Law 3,244/1957, as amended) specifies whether the tariff base of a specified import is “specific” or “ad valorem” and the authorities may charge on either the ad valorem or the specific basis, or both, depending on the circumstances of the importation and which rate results in a greater duty.

The taxable value of imported goods is their c.i.f. (cost, insurance and freight) value and is the normal “open market” price of the goods in question or of similar goods at the time of importation. The price shown on the invoice is generally accepted as the normal price. However, about 10% of total imports are valued according to either minimum value or base price criteria.

An exemption applies to goods up to USD 1,000 purchased for personal use or consumption by travellers arriving by air or sea or USD 500 if arriving by land, river or lake (Ordinance 440/2010 as amended) – quantitative limits may apply for certain goods. For purchases made by travellers at duty-free shops in ports or airports, the exemption applies to goods up to an amount of USD 500 in accordance with Ordinance 307/2014 as amended.
A zero rate applies to products ranging from information technology and telecommunications equipment (e.g. printers, mobile phones and laptops) to hydraulic motors, compressors and drying machines.

To alleviate the impact of inflation, Resolution 317/2022 reduced to 0% the import duty levied on the import of ethanol and six fast-moving consumer goods that are not produced in Brazil, until 31 December 2022.
For the contribution to PIS and COFINS levied on imports, see sections 2.3.2. and 2.3.3.

section.title: Export duty
section.p: Under Decree-Law 1,578/1977, as amended, the government may impose a tax of 30% on exported products, which can be increased to a maximum of 150%.
Currently, however, the export duty is reduced to a zero rate in connection with almost all products.

section.title: Excise duty
section.p: There is no excise tax as so defined. However, the IPI also plays the role of an excise duty for certain products – see section 13.7.

section.title: Insurance premium tax
section.p: A financial transaction tax applies to insurance premiums (see section 14.6.4.3.).

section.title: Motor vehicle taxes
section.p: A state tax on automotive vehicles ownership (imposto sobre a propriedade de veículos automotores, IPVA) applies annually and is charged to the owner of the vehicle. The IPVA is levied on the value of the vehicle at a rate varying according to the federal state (normally between 1% and 4%).

section.title: Environmental taxes
section.p: For contributions levied on the import and commercialization of gasoline, diesel, aviation kerosene (and other kerosene), fuel oils, liquefied petroleum gas (including natural gas and naphtha derived) and ethanol, see section 14.6.4.4.

section.title: Tax on the sale of goods and on the provision of intermunicipal and interstate transportation services and communication services (imposto sobre circulação de mercadorias e services de tranporte intermunicipal, interestadual e de comunicação)
General
section.p: The ICMS is a state tax provided by article 155 (II, 2º) of the 1988 Federal Constitution (as redrafted under the Third Constitutional Amendment of 1993) and regulated by Complementary Law 87/1996.

The ICMS is a type of value added tax – i.e. the ICMS due for prior transactions may be offset against the VAT due on subsequent transactions – and is levied on transactions involving the distribution of goods, the rendering of any type of intermunicipal or interstate transportation services and communication services. ICMS is also levied on import of goods from abroad.

ICMS is regulated by state legislation issued by each state within the limits defined by the Constitution. The finance departments of states (Secretarias da Fazenda) are in charge of the administration and collection of ICMS.

Under specific agreements between the states of the Brazilian Federation (Convênios), states may grant ICMS exemptions, reductions of the taxable base, presumed credits and other tax benefits – for details on the granting of tax incentives, see section 14.6.4.1.8.
For ICMS, the supply of electric power is deemed to be a supply of goods.

section.title: Taxable persons
section.p: As a rule, taxable persons are:

item.p: individuals and legal entities supplying goods or providing intermunicipal and interstate transportation services and communication services and habitually performing these activities with a business aim; and
any person importing goods and services subject to ICMS into Brazil.

section.title: Taxable events
section.p: In general, ICMS is levied on supplies of goods, interstate and intermunicipal transportation services, communication services and imports of goods. Services that are provided together with the sale of goods may be subject to ICMS, provided that such services are not taxed by the ISS (see section 14.6.4.2.).
The following transactions are treated as taxable supplies:

item.p: consignments and transfers of goods, as well as sales;
the transfer of goods from one establishment to another of the same taxpayer, provided that such establishments are located in different states;
the transfer of fixed assets which have been used for less than 12 months, except when the assets are returned to the establishment of origin or to another establishment pertaining to the same owner;

the delivery of merchandise together with the rendering of services if either the service is not included in a list specified in Complementary Law 116/2003 (which lists the services liable for payment of ISS) or the taxation of the service is specifically provided for (e.g. with respect to the sale of foodstuffs, beverages and other merchandise in restaurants, bars, coffee shops and similar establishments);
the entry into the taxpayer’s establishments of goods from another Brazilian state, intended for consumption or to be used as fixed assets;
the purchase at an auction sponsored by the government of imported goods or merchandise under seizure;
the commencement of interstate or intermunicipal transportation services by any means (including viaducts);

the generation, production, transmission, retransmission, repetition, amplification, reception, broadcasting or disclosure of communications of any type, by any process, even when initiated or supplied from abroad; and
the entry into the taxpayer’s commercial, industrial or manufacturing establishment of merchandise by the establishment’s owner (the owner is the taxable person).

section.p: Transactions involving diesel, biodiesel, gasoline, anhydrous ethanol and liquefied petroleum gas are subject to ICMS only once (incidência única), at uniform rates for all states. According to Complementary Law 192/2022, producers and importers of fuels are ICMS taxpayers. The taxable event for ICMS purposes will be considered to have occurred at the time of importation (when from abroad) and upon the departure of the fuels from the taxpayer's establishment (when local).

There are other transactions which are deemed not to be taxable events for ICMS purposes or which are not subject to ICMS under precedents issued by Brazilian courts. In this regard, on 12 September 2014, the Supreme Federal Court confirmed that ICMS is not levied on the import of goods under leasing arrangements.

As from 1 April 2018, federal states were authorized by State Agreement 106/2017 (Convênio ICMS 106/2017) to charge ICMS at the special rate of 5% on standardized digital goods such as packaged software, games, apps and electronic files that are sold to or imported by final consumers and delivered through electronic means (e.g. software downloading, streaming and cloud computing). The taxpayer is the owner of the website or electronic platform by means of which the transaction is made and the tax is collected by the state in which the buyer is located. States may transfer the responsibility of collecting the tax to the financial intermediate (e.g. credit card administrator) or to the final consumer in case the taxpayer is not registered in that state. In import transactions, the collection of the tax must be made by the credit or debit card administrator or the financial company that is a foreign exchange intermediate.

However, states and municipalities have been disputing the taxation of digital transactions, since ISS is levied by municipalities on the provision of services (see section 14.6.4.2.). and ICMS is levied by states on the sale of goods, but these two taxes are mutually exclusive (they cannot be levied on the same transaction). In addition, digital transactions cannot be easily qualified as service or sale of goods according to Brazilian legislation and case law, which causes uncertainty in respect of which tax should be levied. As a consequence, the constitutionality of State Agreement 106/2017 (that authorizes federal states to levy ICMS on digital goods) was being discussed under lawsuit ADI 5,958 at the Federal Supreme Court. However, this lawsuit was closed without judgment in view of the decision given by that Court in ADI 1,945 and 5,659 in the sense that ICMS cannot be levied on the download of software and electronic transfer of data since ISS is already charged on software licensing (see section 14.6.4.2.).

section.title: Place of taxation
section.p: Each federal state levies a value added tax (ICMS) on the supply of goods within the state territory and on intermunicipal transport and communication services rendered in the state territory.

topic.title: Place of taxation of imports
topic.p: For imports, the place of taxation of supplies of goods is the place where the physical entrance of the goods occurs.

topic.title: Place of taxation of interstate acquisitions
topic.p: In cases of interstate supplies when the purchaser uses such supplies for his taxable transactions (i.e. reselling of goods), the tax is levied by the state of origin with a specific rate for interstate transactions, which can be 7% or 12% (a single rate of 4% applies in certain cases), depending on the states involved. However, the state of destination is entitled to a complementary ICMS (“ICMS Complementar”), taxed at specific rates according to the states involved, which is paid by the purchaser.

section.title: Time of taxation
section.p: ICMS is assessed on a monthly basis. Liability to ICMS arises:

item.p: with regard to the supply of goods, when the goods are delivered or the title to the goods is transferred, whichever occurs first;
in the case of imports of goods, upon customs clearance;
when food, drinks or other merchandise are served in restaurants, bars, cafés and similar establishments;
with regard to transportation services between different states or municipalities, when such services are supplied;
with regard to communications services, when they are generated, issued, received, broadcasted or disclosed;
with regard to imported services, when such services are rendered; and
with regard to a combined supply of goods and services, when the goods are delivered.

section.title: Taxable amount
section.p: The taxable amount for supplies of goods and services is the total consideration received or to be received for the supply, including the ICMS itself and any related tax imposed on the transaction, incidental charges (e.g. commission and transport, insurance and advertisement costs) and any subsidies directly linked to the price.

The taxable value of imported goods is the c.i.f. (cost, insurance and freight) value of such goods plus the appropriate IPI and customs duties and any other entry levies (excluding ICMS itself) imposed on the imported goods.

section.title: Rates
section.p: With regard to ICMS, rates are established by each state subject to the following limits:

item.p: a maximum rate is established by the federal Senate;
maximum rates are established by the federal Senate on supplies involving more than one state (interstate rate) when the recipient uses such supplies for his taxable transactions, as follows:
7% if the goods or services are supplied to taxpayers established in the North, North-East, Central West and the state of Espírito Santo;
12% if the goods or services are supplied to taxpayers established in other regions; and
for the purpose of complementary ICMS, a rate equal to the difference between the domestic rate of the destination state and the interstate rate for transactions mentioned above;
a maximum rate of 18% applies to intrastate supplies as well as to supplies involving more than one state when the recipient is the final consumer;

25%, in general, on electricity, fuel, natural gas, transportation and communication services; however, as of July 2022, the applicable rate must be reduced in most states, due to the creation of a federal cap. Accordingly, these products cannot be subject to a rate higher than the state’s average rates (usually 17% or 18%); and
exports of industrial products are granted an exemption with credit for previously paid ICMS.

section.p: For domestic transactions and services rendered within a state, the applicable tax rates are determined by the relevant state (in accordance with the limits established by the federal Senate). The general and maximum rates applicable by each Brazilian state are as follows:

entry.p:

An additional 2% rate applies for financing the State Fund to Combat Poverty and Social Inequality (Fundo Estadual de Combate à Pobreza e às Desigualdades Sociais, FECP).

section.p: A special rate of 5% applies on standardized digital goods such as packaged software, games, apps and electronic files that are sold to or imported by final consumers and delivered through electronic means (e.g. software downloading, streaming and cloud computing).

An increased rate of 25% applies to the supply or importation of certain luxury goods (e.g. weapons, ammunition, manufactured tobacco, perfumes, cosmetics, jewels, alcoholic beverages, imported cars, motorcycles with engine capacity exceeding 250 cc, furs).

Transactions involving diesel, biodiesel, gasoline, anhydrous ethanol and liquefied petroleum gas are subject to a uniform rate for all states to be defined by the National Council of Fiscal Policy (Conselho Nacional de Política Fazendária, CONFAZ), which brings together representatives of the states.

The Brazilian Senate issued Resolution 13/2012 which unified the ICMS rate applicable to interstate transactions involving imported goods. Accordingly, since 1 January 2013, the 7% or 12% rates generally applicable to interstate transactions are replaced by the single rate of 4%. The single 4% rate applies to: (i) simple resale of goods after their import (i.e. without going through any industrial process) and (ii) goods subject to any manufacturing process resulting in other goods or merchandise with over 40% of imported content (such percentage is based on the ratio between the prices of the imported products and the value of the interstate transaction).

The interstate sale of goods to final consumers was subject to ICMS in the state of origin at the applicable internal rate. However, with effect from 1 January 2016, the ICMS levied on those cases is shared between the state of origin and the state of destination as follows (Constitutional Amendment 87/2015 and States Agreement 93/2015):

item.p: the state of origin charges ICMS at the interstate rate; and

the ICMS at a rate resulting from the difference between the interstate rate and the internal rate (what is referred to as the Diferencial de Alíquotas, DIFAL) was charged and shared in proportions until eventually reaching a 100% share for the state of destination in 2019 and subsequent years.

section.p: However, under the Constitution, only a federal complementary law can establish ICMS general rules. In this context, lawsuits were filed to challenge the constitutionality of States Agreement 93/2015 on the grounds that the DIFAL could not be charged prior to the enactment of a federal complementary law. In 2021, the Federal Supreme Court upheld the understanding that States Agreement 93/2015 is unconstitutional, but determined that such a decision should only produce effects as of 2022 in order to provide the Congress with sufficient time to enact a new Complementary Law until the end of 2021. In December 2021, the Congress finally approved Complementary Law 190 regulating the DIFAL charged on interstate sales to final consumers, but the President only signed and published the Law on 4 January 2022. As a result, a new judicial battle has been initiated by taxpayers aimed at having the courts declare that Complementary Law 190/2022 can only be applied as of 2023 in view of the annual principle (i.e. the requirement that a law establishing a new tax or an increase in taxes cannot produce effects in the same calendar year in which it is published) and, therefore, that the DIFAL cannot be charged on sales to final consumers prior to that date. A decision from the Federal Supreme Court on this is pending.

section.title: Exemptions
section.p: The following supplies of goods are exempt:

item.p: manufactured and semi-manufactured products for export;
services supplied to non-resident persons;
electric power, oil, lubricants, liquid and gas fuel for industrial purposes to be used in other states or the federal district;
gold, where legally treated as a financial asset or an exchange instrument; and

books, newspapers and periodicals, including the printing paper. According to a decision of the Federal Supreme Court issued on 8 March 2017 in Extraordinary Appeals 330.817 and 595.676, the constitutional tax exemption for books, newspapers, periodicals and the paper used for printing also covers e-books and e-readers (but excludes tablets, smartphones and laptops, as they have a broader purpose than solely allowing users to read e-books).

section.p: Exports of industrial products are granted an exemption with the right to credit for previously paid ICMS. States also specify other zero-rated transactions.

Under specific agreements between the states of the Brazilian Federation (convênios), in the scope of the CONFAZ, states may grant ICMS exemptions, reductions of the taxable base, estimated credits and other tax benefits.

Nonetheless, over the years, several Brazilian states have granted tax exemptions and reductions without express authorizations from the CONFAZ. As a general rule, these exemptions were granted as tools to attract more business to the states, creating a major issue of harmful tax competition between the Brazilian states. This matter is currently under the spotlight of the Brazilian authorities, and states have been filing lawsuits questioning the legality of the tax incentives granted by other states without the express approval of CONFAZ. The Supreme Court of Justice has already issued decisions recognizing that the state benefits granted without the approval of CONFAZ are unconstitutional and, therefore, invalid. However, the matter is still not fully resolved, and other related issues have surfaced in situations where the benefits are deemed unconstitutional, such as whether or not the state is obliged to claim the unpaid taxes from the taxpayers.

Complementary Law 160/2017, published in the DOU of 8 August 2017, was enacted to modify the rules on authorization of tax benefits by the CONFAZ. Previously, ICMS tax benefits could only be granted with the unanimous approval of the CONFAZ. According to Law 160/2017, the current quorum requirement is of at least: (i) two thirds of all the federal states; and (ii) one third of the federal states of each of the five regions.

The creation of new tax incentives and the extension of existing ones must respect the new limits imposed by the law for the duration of the incentives – varying from 1 to 15 years depending on the industry.

In addition, Complementary Law 160/2017 also determined that the CONFAZ has 180 days from the date of publication of the law to validate all state incentives which are in force. States are also allowed to implement, without requiring approval from CONFAZ, the same incentives introduced by neighbour states in the same region.

section.title: Input tax deduction
section.p: In computing the tax liability, input tax may be credited against output tax, so that in practice only the value added to the taxpayer’s supplies is taxed (this is referred to in Brazil as the non-cumulative principle).

The taxpayer may credit the tax paid to the same state or to other states on goods purchased or imported by him during the tax period against his output ICMS. Under the Federal Constitution, unless otherwise provided (i.e. for exports), exempt and non-taxed transactions do not give rise to a credit to be set off against output ICMS. However, the courts have held that the ICMS spared upon an exempt importation may be credited against the liability arising on the supply of the relevant product (Extraordinary Appeal 114.126-3, First Panel of the Supreme Court).

section.title: Registration
section.p: Due to the fact that ICMS is a state tax, each state has different conditions to apply for registration. In order to carry on a business subject to ICMS, a company must be registered in the General ICMS Taxpayers’ Register (Cadastro de Contribuintes do ICMS).

section.title: Invoices
section.p: An invoice must be issued for any taxable event to support the operation and make it legal. Due to the fact that ICMS is a state tax, different invoices are issued.

Law 12,741/2012 requires companies to specify on invoices and receipts the taxes charged (percentages), which are part of the total amount of the product’s sale price. Companies failing to comply with this obligation are subject to penalties such as fines, suspension and revocation of the licence to operate.
A digital invoice system has been implemented in some states.

section.title: Records
section.p: Taxpayers must keep specific ICMS books for 5 years for the register of entries, selling and ICMS ascertainment. Such books must be certified by the tax authorities. Conditions and specific rules are defined according to each state.

section.title: Returns and payment
section.p: ICMS is calculated by the taxpayer and paid within the next taxable period (next following month). A monthly return must be filed with information regarding the operations held the previous month. Deadlines for filing the return vary in each state.
The tax authorities normally audit the taxpayer’s books in order to confirm the accuracy of the ICMS paid.

section.title: Interest and penalties
section.p: Late payment is subject to an interest charge based on the SELIC rate (a market interest rate) as from the day following the deadline. With regard to the first month of delay, the applicable interest rate is 1%, and the SELIC is applied from the second month.
Due to the fact that ICMS is a state tax, each state applies different rates for penalties.

section.title: Non-resident taxable persons
section.p: Non-resident entities are not subject to ICMS.

section.title: Municipal tax on services
section.p: The ISS applies to services of any nature, except for communication services and intermunicipal and interstate transportation services, which are subject to ICMS.
ISS is provided by article 156 (III, 3º) of the 1988 Federal Constitution (as redrafted under the 3rd Constitutional Amendment of 1993) and currently regulated by Complementary Law 116/2003.

Municipalities may levy taxes on the supply of services (other than the mentioned services subject to ICMS) listed in the Annex of Complementary Law 116/2003. The import of the listed services (i.e. the rendering of services by a non-resident service provider to a client in Brazil) is also subject to ISS. In the case of import of service, the taxpayer is the non-resident person providing the service. However, Complementary Law 116/2003 allows municipalities to determine by municipal law that another person is responsible for the payment of the tax. In addition, the law also indicates that regardless of this rule, in the case of import of service, the service taker in Brazil is also responsible for the payment of ISS. This leads to discussions on who is the actual taxpayer of ISS in the case of import of service and whether this tax is actually a burden on the service taker (as an extra cost in addition to the payment of the service) or the service provider (as withholding tax). This uncertainty may be resolved by municipalities by means of determining who the taxpayer is under municipal law and clarifying how the tax is to be collected. However, many municipalities have not yet issued laws in this respect.

The export of services is exempt from ISS, except if the service is executed in Brazil and the "result" is verified in Brazil – even if the payment of the service fee is made by a non-resident person. In this exceptional case, ISS is due. There is controversy in respect of what “result” means for the purpose of this rule, which can lead to discussions on the application of the exemption.

As a rule, services are subject to tax in the municipality where the supplier’s establishment is located (certain services are however subject to a different rule – see further below). In the case where there is no such establishment, the place of supply is deemed to be the residence of the supplier. Some services are however subject to special rules (e.g. construction works are taxed in the municipality where the services are provided). Complementary Law 157/2016, published in the DOU of 1 June 2017, added other services (i.e. health insurance services, administration of credit and debit cards, leasing, franchising and factoring) to the exceptions and determined that such services are taxed by the municipality in which the client (“service taker”) is located. However, on 23 March 2018, the Federal Supreme Court suspended this amendment in view of the conflicts of jurisdiction between municipalities, which defies the constitutional principle of legal certainty. According to the court, this change requires the concept of “service taker” to be specified in order to avoid serious legal uncertainty and possible double taxation.

Complementary Law 157/2016 also included in the list of services subject to ISS the act of making available audio, video, image or text content through the Internet. The fact that states were also authorized to levy ICMS on digital transactions triggered discussions on the topic (for details, see section 14.6.4.1.3.).

On 4 November 2020, the Federal Supreme Court ruled that only ISS could be levied on software licensing (Direct Actions for Unconstitutionality ADI 5,659 and ADI 1,945). The reporter of the case concluded that, according to the traditional understanding of the Supreme Court, the simple fact that software licensing is included in the list of services attached to Complementary Law 116/03 means that the total value of the transaction is subject to ISS, which prevents ICMS from being levied thereon.

On 24 September 2020, Complementary Law 175/2020 determined that, for the following services, the ISS is due to the municipality where the customer is located: health assistance plans, veterinary assistance plans, fund management, consortia (similar to financial services for the acquisition of assets and real estate), credit and debit cards and leasing. In addition, the amount of ISS collected will be split between the municipality where the service provider is located and the municipality where the customer is located. In order to provide legal certainty to municipalities, these new rules will be implemented gradually. It is envisaged that, as from 2023, 100% of ISS due will be collected by the municipality where the customer is located.

ISS is levied on industrial, commercial or professional service supplies. Services combined with a supply of goods (e.g. repair shops, the operation of hotels and restaurants) are also subject to ISS. As a rule, even if the services involve a supply of goods, the ISS applies only to the portion of the transaction related to the rendering of the listed services (i.e. the price of goods and materials is excluded from the ISS taxable base). On 8 June 2020, the Federal Supreme Court considered the levy of ISS on franchise agreements to be constitutional.

ISS is normally calculated on the fees paid for the service. Certain deductions related to materials supplied by the service provider are allowed. The ISS rate varies from 2% to 5% in view of the type of service and the relevant municipality.

section.title: Tax on financial transactions
section.p: The tax on financial transactions (imposto sobre operações financeiras, IOF) is a federal tax currently levied mainly on currency exchange, credit, securities and insurance transactions. The IOF is not subject to the legality principle, which means that the executive branch may change the IOF tax rate at any time, provided that the rate does not exceed 25%.

Companies are required to specify on invoices and receipts the taxes charged (percentages) on the sale of goods or the provision of services, including IOF. In this sense, companies must list the amount of municipal, state and federal taxes levied for each product described in the invoices and receipts. Alternatively, such information could also be displayed on a panel in plain view within their establishments. Companies failing to comply with these requirements are subject to administrative penalties.
The IOF is currently regulated by Decree 6,306/2007, as amended, and Normative Ruling 1,969/2020.

topic.title: Currency exchange transactions
topic.p: Currency exchange transactions undertaken with regard to inflows of funds to Brazil and the outflows of funds from Brazil are subject to IOF at a general 0.38% rate. The IOF is levied on the amount in BRL received or paid in the transaction.

The Brazilian federal government is allowed to increase the IOF rate up to 25% at any time. However, any increase in rates only applies to future transactions. Some transactions benefit from a 0% rate while other transactions have more burdensome taxation, based on the imposition of a 2% or 6% rate.

In view of the discussions on the accession to the OECD, Brazil committed to eliminate the IOF on currency exchange transactions by 2029. As a result, Decree 10,997/2022 introduced a gradual reduction until 0% of the IOF rate on currency exchange transactions, as follows:

entry.p: Inbound loans with an average term not exceeding 180 days
Credit and debit card transactions, money withdrawal abroad and travel cheques
Currency exchange transactions for the acquisition of foreign currency (in cash) and for the cross-border wire transfer of funds to bank accounts held by resident persons
General rate (when no specific rate applies)

topic.title: Credit transactions
topic.p: Currently, loan transactions granted by legal entities are subject to a daily rate of 0.0041% (if the debtor is a legal entity) or 0.0082% (if the debtor is an individual), plus an additional 0.38%, which is calculated on the principal amount of the loan. A special daily rate of 0.00137% applies in the case the debtor is a legal entity qualified for the simplified regime (Simples Nacional). With regard to transactions with a predetermined principal amount, the imposition of the daily rate is limited to 365 days. Other specific rules apply for the imposition of the IOF on credit transactions where the principal amount is not determined and on insurance and securities transactions.
However, the IOF daily rates levied on credit transactions occurring between 20 September 2021 and 31 December 2021 are increased as follows (the 0.38% rate remains unchanged):

item.p: legal entities or companies: 0.00559% (per day)/2.04% (maximum per year); and
individuals: 0.01118% (per day)/4.08% (maximum per year).

topic.p: Currently, the IOF/Credit is reduced to 0% in relation to transactions (with private or public funds) performed by financial institutions as of 2 April 2013 in situations where the funds are destined for:

item.p: the acquisition, production or leasing of capital goods, including components and related technological services and any related working capital;
the production of consumption goods destined to exportation;
the electric energy sector;
structures related to export transactions of liquid bulk;
engineering projects;
technical innovation;
investment projects related to the formation of technological and productive capacity in high-intensity knowledge fields and engineering sectors; and
projects related to the development of logistics infrastructure related to construction works on highways and railways under a concession contract by the Brazilian government.

topic.p: External credit transactions, considered as those in which the Brazilian party is the debtor, are not subject to the IOF imposed on credit transactions, but solely to the IOF imposed on foreign exchange transactions.

A 0% rate applies on credit transactions contracted by small businesses between 1 April 2022 and 31 December 2023 under the terms of Law 2020 and Law 14,257 of 1 December 2021 (which relate to the National Support Program for Micro and Small Businesses (Pronampe), the Emergency Credit Access Program (PEAC) and the Credit Stimulus Program (PEC)).

topic.title: Shares
topic.p: IOF is levied on the acquisition, transfer, redemption, resettlement or payment for liquidation of securities at the maximum rate of 1.5% on the value of the transaction. A number of exemptions and zero-rate benefits is granted to listed security transactions.

Decree 8.165/2013 reduced from 1.55 to 0% the IOF rate levied on the assignment of shares traded on the Brazilian stock exchange, provided that the transaction has the specific purpose of backing the issuance of depositary receipts traded abroad.

topic.title: Bonds
topic.p: Decree 7,412/2011, which amended Decree 6,306/2007, established new rules regarding the conversion of stock into depositary receipts, specifically with regard to the taxable base, which is currently defined as:

item.p: the fixed price established according to the result of the Book Building process if the conversion of stock into depositary receipts is made within a public offering; or
the number of shares placed under custody multiplied by the trading value of the shares for the preceding day, in other cases.

topic.p: The new rules attribute the liability to pay the tax to the leading coordinator of the offering (in cases of public offerings) and to custodians of the stock assigned (in other cases).

Finally, Decree 7,412 excluded from the scope of the rules on the imposition of IOF/bonds at the rate of 1% per day (limited to the income derived from the transaction) the assignment, renegotiation or redemption of private fixed income transactions.

topic.title: Derivatives
topic.p: Decree 6,306/2007, introduced the imposition of IOF securities with regard to transactions involving currency structured derivatives. Such IOF was imposed at a 1% rate in connection with the notional adjusted value in the acquisition, sale or settlement of derivative instruments executed in Brazil that may have had an impact in the currency exposure of the concerned party. However, according to Decree 8,027/2013, as of 13 June 2013, the IOF rate was reduced from 1% to 0% on transactions involving financial derivatives.

topic.title: Insurance transactions
topic.p: IOF is levied on insurance transactions, including life insurance, labour accidents insurance and insurance on goods. The insured person is subject to IOF at different rates, varying from 0% to 25%, according to the type of insurance, on the amount of premium paid. The tax is collected by the insurance company or financial institution in charge of collecting the premium.

section.title: Contribution for the intervention on the economic domain

topic.title: CIDE-Technology
topic.p: The contribution for intervention on the economic domain (Contribuição de Intervenção no Domínio Econômico, CIDE) applies to taxable events occurring on or after 1 January 2001. This contribution is intended to finance the Programme to Stimulate the Interaction of University-Corporations for the Support of Innovation (Programa de Estímulo à Interação Universidade-Empresa para Apoio à Inovação).

Royalties paid by resident entities to non-resident persons as consideration for the transfer of technology, including trademarks, patents and the provision of technology, as well as payments for the provision of technical service and assistance, are subject to the contribution at a rate of 10% of the gross amount. On 11 September 2018, the CARF issued Binding Decision 127 (Súmula Carf 127) confirming that CIDE must be levied on the import of technical services regardless of whether there is a transfer of technology.

The CIDE taxpayer is the Brazilian company that benefits from the exploitation of the underlying right in Brazil or the beneficiary of the technical services or technical assistance, as the case may be. This means that CIDE is due and payable by the Brazilian licensee and beneficiary of services and thus it is not withheld from the amount of the royalties or service fees to be paid to the non-resident beneficiary. According to Binding Decision 158 (Súmula 158), the withholding tax levied on outbound payments is included in the taxable base of CIDE contribution even if the paying source in Brazil bears the financial burden of the withholding tax.
The CIDE contribution is not imposed on cross-border payments for software licences, except for payments involving the acquisition of software rights (including transfer of technology/source code).

According to Private Ruling 99/2018, CIDE’s taxable base is the net revenue paid to the non-resident person plus the withholding tax levied, regardless of who assumed the economic burden of this withholding tax (the Brazilian source of the non-resident).

In certain circumstances, the CIDE contribution rate is reduced to zero per cent if the company paying the patent or trademark royalties of the service fees benefits from tax incentives targeting certain technology activities (e.g. semiconductors, digital TV).

topic.title: CIDE-Fuel
topic.p: CIDE is also imposed on the import and commercialization of gasoline, diesel, aviation kerosene (and other kerosene), fuel oils, liquefied petroleum gas (including natural gas and naphtha derived) and ethanol (CIDE-Fuel).

For a long period, the CIDE-Fuel was levied at a 0% rate. However, Decree 8,395/2015 reintroduced the CIDE-Fuel charge with effect from 1 May 2015. The CIDE-Fuel is imposed per cubic meter of gasoline and diesel imported or sold. The CIDE-Fuel rates for aviation kerosene (and other kerosene), fuel oils, liquefied petroleum gas (including natural gas and naphtha derived) and ethanol, however, remain at 0%.

topic.title: CIDE-Digital
topic.p: For a proposal on CIDE-digital, see section 14.6.4.5.

section.title: Proposals for the taxation of digitalized economy
section.p: Brazil is currently discussing different proposals for taxation of the digitalized economy – see the proposals further below.

The United States had initially opened investigations into Brazil concerning the taxation of digitalized economy but decided to terminate them based on the finding that the taxes are not yet implemented. However, the United States informed that new investigations may be initiated if Brazil proceeds to adopt the proposed taxes.

On 1 July 2021 and 8 October 2021, Brazil signed joint statements with other Inclusive Framework members with an agreement to implement a two-pillar solution to address the tax challenges arising from the digitalization of the economy, which includes key elements on the allocation of taxing rights to market jurisdictions (Pillar One) (see section 7.3.1.). A multilateral convention with the requirement for parties to remove all digital service taxes and other relevant similar measures is expected to be signed – a detailed definition of what constitutes relevant similar measures will be included in the convention. This means that the proposals below may be affected.

The joint statement signed on 8 October 2021 also states that no newly enacted unilateral measures will be imposed from 8 October 2021 and until the earlier of 31 December 2023 or the coming into force of the expected multilateral convention.

topic.title: CIDE-Digital
topic.p: The Chamber of Deputies is currently examining a proposed bill to create CIDE-Digital to be levied on gross revenue derived by resident or non-resident companies from digital services targeting the Brazilian market. The proposal was submitted to the Chamber of Deputies as Bill 2,358/2020 on 4 May 2020.
Under the proposal, the CIDE-Digital would be levied on gross revenue derived by resident or non-resident companies, provided that they belong to a group deriving in a calendar year:

item.p: annual global revenue exceeding BRL 3 billion; and
gross revenue exceeding BRL 100 million in the Brazilian market.

topic.p: The CIDE-Digital would be levied upon the receipt of revenue (i.e. the taxable event) from:

item.p: the display of advertisements on a digital platform for users located in Brazil;

making available digital platforms that allow users to contact and interact with each other for the purpose of selling goods or providing services directly between each other, provided that one of the users is located in Brazil; and
the transmission of data from users located in Brazil, which has been generated by such users or collected while they were using the digital platforms.

topic.p: The CIDE-Digital would be levied under progressive rates, as follows:

item.p: 1% on gross revenue up to BRL 150 million;
3% on gross revenue between BRL 150 million and BRL 300 million; and
5% on gross revenue exceeding BRL 300 million.

topic.p: Users accessing digital platforms on devices physically located in Brazil will be considered users located in the country. The physical location of the device will be determined based on the IP address that accesses the digital platform, unless the IP has been artificially modified to reflect a different location – in this case, the tax authorities may make use of other available means for assessing geolocation.
The payment of CIDE-Digital is due by the last business day of the month of March of the year following that in which the taxable event takes place.

In its justification section, the Bill refers to the OECD/G20 BEPS Project and the need for unilateral measures to address the lack of taxation of the digital economy until a global solution is agreed. It further indicates that the CIDE-Digital follows the concept of digital taxes proposed by the European Commission and implemented by countries like Italy and France. As CIDE-Digital has the nature of a contribution, the revenue generated therefrom will finance the National Fund for Scientific and Technological Development (Fundo Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico, FNDCT).

topic.title: CSSD
topic.p: On 19 August 2020, a Complementary Bill (Projeto de lei Complementar) was submitted to the National Congress with a proposal to create a contribution on digital services (Contribuição Social sobre Serviços Digitais, CSSD) to be levied on gross revenue derived by resident and non-resident companies from digital services targeting the Brazilian market.

Under the proposal, the CSSD would be levied on gross revenue obtained by resident and non-resident companies provided that they belong to a group deriving, in a calendar year, annual global revenue exceeding BRL 4.5 billion.
The CSSD would be levied upon the receipt of revenue (i.e. the taxable event) from:

item.p: the display of advertisements on a digital platform for users located in Brazil;

making available digital platforms that allow users to contact and interact with each other for the purpose of selling goods or providing services directly between each other, provided that one of the users is located in Brazil; and
the transmission of data from users located in Brazil, which has been generated by such users or collected while they were using the digital platforms.

topic.p: Users accessing digital platforms on devices physically located in Brazil will be considered users located in the country.
The CSSD would be levied at a 3% rate and must be paid by the 10th day of the month following that in which the taxable event takes place.
The CSSD collected would be applied to minimum income programmes implemented by the federal government.

In its justification section, the Bill refers to the OECD/G20 BEPS Project and the need for short-term measures to address the lack of taxation of the digital giants until a global solution is agreed. It further indicates that the CSSD follows the concept of digital taxes proposed by the European Commission and implemented by countries like France.

The justification also points out that the federal government considers that it is necessary to establish minimum income programmes in view of the COVID-19 pandemic and taxing the digital giants would contribute to finance such programmes.

topic.title: CBS
topic.p: A proposal to create a contribution on goods and services (Contribuição sobre Bens e Serviços (CBS)) is currently under discussion at the National Congress. The proposal aims at unifying the existing PIS and COFINS into one contribution on goods and services. According to the proposal, legal entities providing services and selling goods, including non-resident entities in case of imports, would be subject to the CBS at the rate of 12% on gross revenue.

Under the proposal, digital platforms are defined as any legal entity that acts in a remote manner as intermediary between suppliers and buyers in transactions involving the sale of goods and services. Entities providing only one of the following activities are not considered digital platforms: (i) provision of Internet access; (ii) processing of payment; (iii) advertisement; or (iv) search for suppliers, as long as they do not charge the service based on the sales made.

The Bill justification indicates that it follows the recommendations of the OECD/G20 BEPS Project for market jurisdictions to adapt their systems to the digitalization of the economy. It refers to the principle of destination in Action 1 and explains that the Bill kept the taxation on imports and followed the guidelines on simplified registration for digital platforms and other service suppliers in Brazil.

topic.title: COFINS-digital
topic.p: A proposal to create COFINS-digital is currently under discussion at the National Congress. Under the proposal, the receipt of gross revenue by legal entities making use of digital platforms would be subject to the COFINS-digital at a 10.6% rate. Resident and non-resident legal entities would be subject to this contribution, provided they have a monthly gross revenue from digital services provided worldwide exceeding USD 20 million and in Brazil exceeding BRL 6.5 million.

The Bill justification refers to the OECD/G20 BEPS Project and its guiding principle of taxation where consumers are located, regardless of where the company is situated. It also refers to the digital service taxes implemented in France and Spain as examples to be followed.

section.p: In addition, there are various other contributions and fees levied at a federal and state level, including:

Contribution to Direction of Ports and Coastlines (DPC);
Contribution to National Scientific and Technological Development Fund (FNDCT);
Contribution to National Education Development Fund (FNDE);
Contribution to National Institute for Rural Settlement and Agrarian Reform (INCRA);
Contribution to Brazilian Support Service for Small Business and Companies (SEBRAE);
Contribution to National Commercial Apprenticeship Service (SENAC);
Contribution to National Transport Apprenticeship Service (SENAT);
Contribution to National Industrial Apprenticeship Service (SENAI);
Contribution to National Rural Apprenticeship Service (SENAR);
Contribution to Industrial Workers’ Social Service (SESI);
Contribution to Commercial Workers’ Social Service (SESC);
